Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 5, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL, QC - AUGUST 10: Rafael Nadal of Spain prepares to serve against Denis Shapovalov of Canada during day seven of the Rogers Cup presented by National Bank at Uniprix Stadium on August 10, 2017 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. Denis Shapovalov of Canada defeated Rafael Nadal of Spain 6-3, 4-6, 6-7. Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images/AFP\n\nCanadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, temporarily spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had reached the semi-finals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\nNadal described it as the worst loss of the season for him for a number of reasons.\n\n\"Worst loss of the year because I lost against a player with a lower ranking,\" Nadal said. \"At the same time because of the opportunity I had to get back to Number One.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\n\"He won. It is an amazing for him. It is a great story. I am not happy to be part of this story,\" Nadal said.\n\nShapovalov, who is ranked 143rd in the world, quickly got on a roll in Montreal, beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He then defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nNadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe third game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting three times.\n\n\"Was it only 14 minutes?,\" Shapovalov asked. \"It felt like three hours.\n\n\"I just kept fighting. I knew it was going to be really tough. I went for my shots in the big moments and I caught a couple of lines got a little bit lucky.\"\n\nShapovalov said he didn't think he had a chance to win at all before the match. It wasn't until he levelled the sets at one each that he realized he could beat the 10-time French Open champion.\n\n\"The whole day I was like - there's no chance. I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"I went up a break in the second set early and even though he broke me back I felt like - OK, I am capable of breaking him.\n\n\"So when I won that second set I thought let's go one more set and who knows, anything can happen.\"\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\n'Dream come true'\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me.\"\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points, but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nThis is a setback for Nadal in the buildup to the US Open starting August 28 but he still has a chance to regain No. 1.\n\n\"The worst thing is playing bad in matches that really matter,\" Nadal said. \"You have to win these matches. I didn't today. I have another week in Cincinnati and then I have the Grand Slam coming.\"\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer with a 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 victory to reach the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nIn other matches Thursday, Germany's Alexander Zverev defeated Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3, Roberto Bautista outlasted Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2) and Kevin Anderson of South Africa cruised past Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1.", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textEnd": 24, "amb": false, "date": "2017-08-10", "textStart": 15, "freq": 2}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 3798, "textStart": 3789}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T12:45:00Z", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "source": {"uri": "guardian.ng", "title": "guardian.ng", "id": "2274"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:45:00", "url": "https://guardian.ng/sport/nadals-pursuit-of-no-1-derailed-by-canadian-teen/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8615870", "image": "https://guardian.ng/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Rafael-Nadal-640x360.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "12:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Shapovalov advanced to the second round of the Rogers Cup on Tuesday, rallying for a 4-6, 7-6(8), 6-4 victory against Rogerio Dutra Silva of Brazil.\n\nOn triple match point, Shapovalov fired a serve that handcuffed Dutra Silva. The 18-year-old dropped his racket and threw his arms in the air as the center court crowd at Uniprix Stadium erupted in cheers.\n\nThe 143rd-ranked Shapovalov got better as the match progressed, needing 2 hours, 26 minutes to eliminate the 64th-ranked Dutra Silva.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. quarterfinals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, temporarily spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world No.1.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday (Friday in Manila).\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had reached the semi-finals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\nRafael Nadal of Spain prepares to serve against Denis Shapovalov of Canada during day seven of the Rogers Cup presented by National Bank at Uniprix Stadium on Friday in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. AFP PHOTO\n\nNadal described it as the worst loss of the season for him for a number of reasons.\n\n\"Worst loss of the year because I lost against a player with a lower ranking,\" Nadal said. \"At the same time because of the opportunity I had to get back to Number One.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\n\"He won. It is an amazing for him. It is a great story. I am not happy to be part of this story,\" Nadal said.\n\nShapovalov, who is ranked 143rd in the world, quickly got on a roll in Montreal, beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He then defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nNadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe third game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting three times.\n\n\"Was it only 14 minutes?,\" Shapovalov asked. \"It felt like three hours.\n\n\"I just kept fighting. I knew it was going to be really tough. I went for my shots in the big moments and I caught a couple of lines got a little bit lucky.\"\n\nShapovalov said he didn't think he had a chance to win at all before the match. It wasn't until he levelled the sets at one each that he realized he could beat the 10-time French Open champion.\n\n\"The whole day I was like - there's no chance. I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"I went up a break in the second set early and even though he broke me back I felt like - OK, I am capable of breaking him.\n\n\"So when I won that second set I thought let's go one more set and who knows, anything can happen.\"\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nDream come true\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me.\"\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points, but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nThis is a setback for Nadal in the buildup to the US Open starting August 28 but he still has a chance to regain No. 1.\n\n\"The worst thing is playing bad in matches that really matter,\" Nadal said. \"You have to win these matches. I didn't today. I have another week in Cincinnati and then I have the Grand Slam coming.\"\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer with a 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 victory to reach the quarterfinals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nIn other matches Thursday, Germany's Alexander Zverev defeated Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3, Roberto Bautista outlasted Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2) and Kevin Anderson of South Africa cruised past Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1.\n\nAFP", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 3684, "textStart": 3675}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:53:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "title": "Manila Times", "id": "1062"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:53:00", "url": "http://www.manilatimes.net/nadals-pursuit-no-1-derailed-canadian-teen/343864/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8653622", "image": "http://14255-presscdn-0-60.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Nadal20170812-300x225.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:53:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"score": 2, "id": "1338842", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Denis Shapovalov proved that he can win a match even when he's not playing his best tennis.\n\nThat was the case Tuesday when Canada's top prospect for the future fought off four match points in a second-set tiebreaker and defeated Rogerio Dutra Silva of Brazil 4-6, 7-6 (8), 6-4 in the first round of the Rogers Cup Canadian Open tennis championships.\n\n\"It was pretty tough out there, tough conditions,\" said the 18-year-old Shapovalov, who has reached the second round in each of the past two years. \"Dutra Silva is a real fighter. I was struggling a little bit with the rhythm on my serve, I wasn't putting a lot of (first serves) in the first two sets or first set and a half. Then I kind of found my range in the tiebreaker.\n\nThis wasn't a vintage serving game for the left-handed Shapovalov. He put only 50 per cent of his first serves into play, but he came up with the big shots when he needed them. He had four of his 12 aces in the tiebreaker and ended the match with a wide service winner, which forced Dutra Silva off the court on the ad side.\n\nShapovalov took control of the deciding set when he broke Dutra Silva's serve for a 4-3 lead. The Brazilian fell behind 15-40 and Shapovalov ripped a backhand winner for the break.\n\nShapovalov had to dig deep to survive the second-set tiebreaker. He fell behind 3-0 before delivering a pair of aces. Dutra Silva had two match points at 6-4, but an unforced error erased one point and Shapovalov pulled even with a half-volley drop shot for a winner.\n\nA backhand winner and an ace by Shapovalov allowed the Canadian to fight off the other match points and Dutra Silva double-faulted to give Shapovalov a 10-8 win in the tiebreaker.\n\nShapovalov said the match points were a blur, but he remembered saving the third one.\n\n\"I remember I was pretty far back and I went for a backhand down the line, which was pretty good,\" Shapovalov said. \"I wasn't holding back. I just told myself: He's got to win it from me, I'm not going to give it to him. Yeah, I think I did a good job to stay tough out there.\"\n\nShapovalov said the crowd, which included hockey legend Wayne Gretzky, gave him a lift and probably put extra pressure on Dutra Silva.\n\nNext up for Shapovalov is Argentine Juan Martin del Potro, the 2009 U.S. Open champion. That match slated for centre court Wednesday afternoon after Roger Federer plays against Canadian Peter Polansky.\n\nShapovalov wasn't the only player who had to dig deep for a spot in the second round. Pablo Carreno Busta, the 11th seed from Spain outlasted Karen Khachanov of Russia 3-6, 6-3, 6-2 and ninth-seeded David Goffin of Belgium beat Yuichi Sugita of Japan, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4. American serving machine Sam Querrey needed 18 aces and three sets to eliminate French qualifier Vincent Millot 4-6, 7-6 (4), 7-5 and Korean Hyeon Chung beat Spaniard Feliciano Lopez 6-1, 4-6, 7-6.\n\nJack Sock, the 15th-seeded American, defeated Pierre-Hugues Herbert of France 7-6 (4), 6-3 and South African Kevin Anderson beat Israeli qualifier Dudi Sela 6-3, 7-6 (1).\n\nThere's no shortage of star power on centre court Wednesday. In the evening, Canadian Milos Raonic, the No. 6 seed, faces France's Adrian Mannarino after top-seeded Rafael Nadal plays Croatian Borna Coric.\n\nIn doubles action Tuesday, 44-year-old Daniel Nestor and Vasek Pospisil lost to the Spanish team of Roberto Bautista Agut and David Ferrer 4-6, 6-4, 10-2. The other Canadian team of Frank Dancevic and Adil Shamasdin lost to Frenchman Fabrice Martin and Edouard Roger-Vasselin 6-4, 6-2.\n\nphickey@postmedia.com\n\ntwitter.com/zababes1", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-09T02:43:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"uri": "montrealgazette.com", "title": "Montreal Gazette", "id": "2649"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:43:00", "url": "http://montrealgazette.com/sports/denis-shapovalov-shows-mental-toughness-in-comeback-win-at-rogers-cup", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8098917", "image": "http://wpmedia.montrealgazette.com/2017/08/0809-spt-rogers-0536.jpg?w=640", "date": "2017-08-09", "time": "02:43:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-09"}

teenager Denis Shapovalov was amazed he had beaten tennis superstar Rafael Nadal.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont., shocked himself, the crowd that roared with every point he scored and the tennis world with his 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4) victory over top-seeded Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday night at a sold out Uniprix Stadium.\n\nShapovalov dropped to the ground and covered his face in joy and surprise as the cheers reached deafening levels after the match point fell, completing his comeback from a 3-0 deficit in the third-set tiebreaker.\n\n\"It's what I dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa (Nadal), Roger (Federer), Andy (Murray),\" said Shapovalov. \"You know, my dream came true today.\"\n\nThe victory put him into a quarter-final Friday against France's Adrian Mannarino, who beat Hyeon Chung 6-3,6-3.\n\nIt was one of the biggest wins in Canadian tennis history and it came at the tournament that some still call the Canadian Open.\n\nShapovalov became the youngest player to reach the tournament's quarter-finals since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nHe also became the youngest quarter-finalist at a Masters Series tournament ever and is the youngest to beat a player ranked in the top two in the world since Nadal beat Federer in 2004 in Miami.\n\nRead more:\n\nTennis Canada CEO sees great things in nation's young stars: Feschuk\n\nRoger Federer rallies to beat David Ferrer at Rogers Cup\n\nTop-seeded Pliskova reaches Rogers Cup quarter-finals with win over Osaka\n\nShapovalov will reach his goal of moving into the top 100 in the world in a week that saw him save four match points in a first round win over Rogerio Dutra Silva, then beat 2009 U.S. Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round before toppling Nadal.\n\n\"I'm very thankful that I'm in this position,\" said Shapovalov, who had hockey great Wayne Gretzky and Olympic swimming star Penny Oleksiak cheering for him from the seats. \"If I didn't save those four match points in the first round, there wouldn't even be a chance to play Juan Martin or Rafa.\n\n\"It's difficult to say how I was feeling during the match. It was extremely hard physically and mentally. Rafa is such a warrior. I'm just so happy to come out with the win.\"\n\nNadal, who could have claimed the No. 1 ranking if he had reached the semifinals this week, said it was the worst match he played all year, but he had kind words for Shapovalov.\n\n\"He played well,\" the 31-year-old said. \"He has a great potential.\n\n\"I wish him the best. He has everything to become a great player. He played with the right determination in the important moments.\"\n\nShapovalov looked unfazed in facing the biggest opponent of his young career. After Nadal cruised through the first set, Shapovalov kept battling, breaking service while taking a 3-0 lead in the second. When Nadal would start taking control of a game, the younger of the two lefthanders would respond with big serves or impressive forehands down the lines.\n\nNadal fought off two break points to hold serve at 4-2, then earned his own break to win back the momentum from the 2016 Wimbledon junior boys champion, only to see Shapovalov snatch it back and clinch the second set.\n\nThe two held serve through the third. "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 5, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Rafael Nadal of Spain congratulates Denis Shapovalov of Canada for his victory. (AFP)\n\nCanadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, temporarily spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had reached the semi-finals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\nNadal described it as the worst loss of the season for him for a number of reasons.\n\n\"Worst loss of the year because I lost against a player with a lower ranking,\" Nadal said. \"At the same time because of the opportunity I had to get back to Number One.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\n\"He won. It is an amazing for him. It is a great story. I am not happy to be part of this story,\" Nadal said.\n\nShapovalov, who is ranked 143rd in the world, quickly got on a roll in Montreal, beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He then defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nNadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe third game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting three times.\n\n\"Was it only 14 minutes?,\" Shapovalov asked. \"It felt like three hours.\n\n\"I just kept fighting. I knew it was going to be really tough. I went for my shots in the big moments and I caught a couple of lines got a little bit lucky.\"\n\nShapovalov said he didn't think he had a chance to win at all before the match. It wasn't until he levelled the sets at one each that he realized he could beat the 10-time French Open champion.\n\n\"The whole day I was like - there's no chance. I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"I went up a break in the second set early and even though he broke me back I felt like - OK, I am capable of breaking him.\n\n\"So when I won that second set I thought let's go one more set and who knows, anything can happen.\"\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\n'Dream come true'\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me.\"\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points, but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nThis is a setback for Nadal in the buildup to the US Open starting August 28 but he still has a chance to regain No. 1.\n\n\"The worst thing is playing bad in matches that really matter,\" Nadal said. \"You have to win these matches. I didn't today. I have another week in Cincinnati and then I have the Grand Slam coming.\"\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer with a 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 victory to reach the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nIn other matches Thursday, Germany's Alexander Zverev defeated Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3, Roberto Bautista outlasted Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2) and Kevin Anderson of South Africa cruised past Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 3545, "textStart": 3536}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T07:51:00Z", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "source": {"uri": "emirates247.com", "title": "Emirates 24|7", "id": "508"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:51:00", "url": "http://www.emirates247.com/sports/nadal-s-pursuit-of-no-1-derailed-by-canadian-teen-2017-08-11-1.657455", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8562467", "image": "http://cache.emirates247.com/polopoly_fs/1.657456.1502435967!/image/image.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "07:51:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"498181", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 5, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "YOUTH AND POWER. Denis Shapovalov of Canada celebrates his victory over Rafael Nadal of Spain. Photo by Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images/AFP\n\nMONTREAL, Canada - Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarterfinals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday, August 10 (Friday Manila time).\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he reached the semifinals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\n\"He played well. He has great potential,\" Nadal said. \"I wish him the best. He played with the right determination.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov, who is ranked 143rd in the world, had just 3 wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal, beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4.\n\nHe then defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning 7 of the final eight points of the 3rd set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nNadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe 3rd game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting 3 times.\n\n\"Was it only 14 minutes?,\" Shapovalov asked. \"It felt like 3 hours.\n\n\"I just kept fighting. I knew it was going to be really tough. I went for my shots in the big moments and I caught a couple of lines got a little bit lucky but at the end of the day that is what tennis is.\"\n\nShapovalov said he didn't think he had a chance to win at all before the match. It wasn't until he levelled the sets at one each that he realized he could beat the 10-time French Open champion.\n\n\"The whole day I was like - there's no chance. I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"I went up a break in the second set early and even though he broke me back I felt like - OK, I am capable of breaking him.\n\n\"So when I won that second set I thought let's go one more set and who knows, anything can happen.\"\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including some on his second serve. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\n'Dream come true'\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me.\"\n\nNadal won 77% of his first serve points, but had just two aces and 6 double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a 3-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set - ending Federer's 32-set streak - the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said.\n\n\"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nIn other matches Thursday, Germany's Alexander Zverev defeated Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3, Roberto Bautista outlasted Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2) and Kevin Anderson of South Africa cruised past Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1. - Rappler.com", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-10", "textEnd": 531, "textStart": 522}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T00:45:00Z", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "source": {"uri": "rappler.com", "title": "Rappler", "id": "7948"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:45:00", "url": "http://www.rappler.com/sports/by-sport/other-sports/178429-nadals-pursuit-derailed-canadian-teen-shapovalov", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8725968", "image": "https://assets.rappler.com/612F469A6EA84F6BAE882D2B94A4B421/img/A0E2CB26ED6B4C58B0F30FC098E7AA0F/063_829660198-2.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "00:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Backhand"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backhand", "score": 2, "id": "374056", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Peter Polansky"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Polansky", "score": 1, "id": "413449", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Y\u016bichi Sugita"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Y\u016bichi_Sugita", "score": 2, "id": "502853", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Pablo Carre\u00f1o"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Carre\u00f1o", "score": 2, "id": "696665", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Vincent Millot"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vincent_Millot", "score": 2, "id": "789040", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Karen Khachanov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karen_Khachanov", "score": 2, "id": "996772", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Chung Hyeon"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chung_Hyeon", "score": 1, "id": "1338842", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Denis Shapovalov showed why he's regarded as the future of Canadian tennis as he fought off four match points in a second-set tiebreaker and defeated Rogerio Dutra Silva of Brazil 4-6, 7-6 (8), 6-4 in the first round of the Rogers Cup Canadian Open tennis championships on Tuesday.\n\n\"It was a bit stressful, but the crowd pulled me through,\" said the 18-year-old from Toronto, who has reached the second round in each of the past two years. \"I hope we can keep it going.\"\n\nNext up for Shapovalov is Argentine Juan Martin del Potro, the 2009 U.S. Open champion. That match will be on centre court Wednesday afternoon, following Roger Federer's match.\n\nThis wasn't a vintage serving game for the left-handed Shapovalov. He put only 50 per cent of his first serves into play, but he came up with the big shots when he needed them. He had four of his 12 aces in the tiebreaker and ended the match with a wide service winner that forced Dutra Silva off the court on the ad side.\n\nShapovalov took control of the deciding set when he broke Dutra Silva's serve for a 4-3 lead. The Brazilian fell behind 15-40 and Shapovalov ripped a backhand winner for the break,\n\nShapovalov had to dig deep to survive the second-set tiebreaker. He fell behind 3-0 before delivering a pair of aces. Dutra Silva had two match points at 6-4, but an unforced error erased one point and Shapovalov pulled even with a half-volley drop shot for a winner.\n\nAn unforced error and an ace by Shapovalov allowed the Canadian to save the other match points and Dutra Silva double-faulted to give Shapovalov a 10-8 win in the tiebreaker.\n\nShapovalov wasn't the only player who had to dig deep for a spot in the second round. Pablo Carreno Busta, the 11th seed from Spain, outlasted Karen Khachanov of Russia 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, while ninth-seeded David Goffin of Belgium beat Yuichi Sugita of Japan, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2. American serving machine Sam Querrey needed 18 aces and three sets to eliminate French qualifier Vincent Millot 4-6, 7-6 (4), 7-5 and Korean Hyeon Chung beat Spaniard Feliciano Lopez 6-1, 4-6, 7-6 (3).\n\nThere's no shortage of star power on centre court Wednesday. Second-seeded Federer will play Peter Polansky of Toronto at 12:30 p.m.\n\nRafael Nadal, the top seed, will make his tournament debut in the evening session beginning at 6:30 p.m. He will play Croatian Borna Coric. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL: Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he reached the semi-finals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\n\"He played well. He has great potential,\" Nadal said. \"I wish him the best. He played with the right determination.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov, who is ranked 143rd in the world, had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal, beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He then defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nNadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe third game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting three times.\n\n\"Was it only 14 minutes?,\" Shapovalov asked. \"It felt like three hours.\n\n\"I just kept fighting. I knew it was going to be really tough. I went for my shots in the big moments and I caught a couple of lines got a little bit lucky but at the end of the day that is what tennis is.\"\n\nShapovalov said he didn't think he had a chance to win at all before the match. It wasn't until he levelled the sets at one each that he realized he could beat the 10-time French Open champion.\n\n\"The whole day I was like - there's no chance. I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"I went up a break in the second set early and even though he broke me back I felt like - OK, I am capable of breaking him.\n\n\"So when I won that second set I thought let's go one more set and who knows, anything can happen.\"\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including some on his second serve. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\n- 'Dream come true' -\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me.\"\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points, but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said.\n\n\"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world No.1.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7-4) on Thursday, FOX Sports reported.\n\nNadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov on Thursday and Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nThe defeat means injured Brit Andy Murray will hold on to top spot for now.\n\nShapovalov is youngest ATP World Tour Masters 1000 quarterfinalist ever and second youngest player to defeat Nadal since Borna Coric did at 2014 Swiss Indoors.\n\nNadal went 0-for-6 on break points in the third set, sat back and waited for the kid to miss. He didn't.\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10-8), 6-4.\n\nHe defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3, 7-6 (7-4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov after his triumph over world No. 2.\n\n\"The whole day I was like: there's no chance, I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov added.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal praised the teenager's performance, saying, \"He played well. He has great potential,\"\n\n\"I wish him the best. He played with the right determination.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:57:00Z", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "source": {"uri": "iran-daily.com", "title": "iran-daily.com", "id": "2658"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:57:00", "url": "http://www.iran-daily.com/News/198404.html", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8654389", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:57:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"498181", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he reached the semi-finals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\n\"He played well. He has great potential,\" Nadal said. \"I wish him the best. He played with the right determination.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov, who is ranked 143rd in the world, had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal, beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He then defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands. Nadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe third game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting three times.\n\n\"Was it only 14 minutes?,\" Shapovalov asked. \"It felt like three hours.\n\n\"I just kept fighting. I knew it was going to be really tough. I went for my shots in the big moments and I caught a couple of lines got a little bit lucky but at the end of the day that is what tennis is.\"\n\nShapovalov said he didn't think he had a chance to win at all before the match. It wasn't until he levelled the sets at one each that he realized he could beat the 10-time French Open champion.\n\n\"The whole day I was like - there's no chance. I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"I went up a break in the second set early and even though he broke me back I felt like - OK, I am capable of breaking him.\n\n\"So when I won that second set I thought let's go one more set and who knows, anything can happen.\"\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including some on his second serve. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me.\"\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points, but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said.\n\n\"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nIn other matches Thursday, Germany's Alexander Zverev defeated Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3, Roberto Bautista outlasted Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2) and Kevin Anderson of South Africa cruised past Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1. -- AFP", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T22:54:00Z", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "source": {"uri": "pakobserver.net", "title": "Pakistan Observer", "id": "3962"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:54:00", "url": "http://pakobserver.net/nadals-pursuit-no-1-derailed-canadian-teen/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8715093", "image": "http://pakobserver.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Rafael-Nadals-pursuit-of-No.-1-derailed-by-Canadian-teen_1-680x497.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "22:54:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Donaldson", "score": 1, "id": "1339257", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Denis Shapovalov of Canada celebrates after defeating Rafael Nadal of Spain during round of sixteen play at the Rogers Cup tennis tournament in Montreal on Aug. 10, 2017. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Paul Chiasson\n\nEven Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov was amazed he had beaten tennis superstar Rafael Nadal.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill shocked himself, the crowd that roared with every point he scored, and the tennis world with his 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4) victory over top-seeded Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday night at a sold out Uniprix Stadium.\n\nShapovalov dropped to the ground and covered his face in joy and surprise as the cheers reached deafening levels after the match point fell, completing his comeback from a 3-0 deficit in the third-set tiebreaker.\n\n\"It's what I dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa (Nadal), Roger (Federer), Andy (Murray),\" said Shapovalov. \"You know, my dream came true today.\"\n\nThe victory put him into a quarter-final Friday against France's Adrian Mannarino, who beat Hyeon Chung 6-3,6-3.\n\nIt was one of the biggest wins in Canadian tennis history and it came at the tournament that some still call the Canadian Open.\n\nShapovalov became the youngest player to reach the tournament's quarter-finals since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nHe also became the youngest quarter-finalist at a Masters Series tournament ever and is the youngest to beat a player ranked in the top two in the world since Nadal beat Federer in 2004 in Miami.\n\nShapovalov will reach his goal of moving into the top 100 in the world in a week that saw him save four match points in a first round win over Rogerio Dutra Silva, then beat 2009 U.S. Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round before toppling Nadal.\n\n\"I'm very thankful that I'm in this position,\" said Shapovalov, who had hockey great Wayne Gretzky and Olympic swimming star Penny Oleksiak cheering for him from the seats. \"If I didn't save those four match points in the first round, there wouldn't even be a chance to play Juan Martin or Rafa.\n\n\"It's difficult to say how I was feeling during the match. It was extremely hard physically and mentally. Rafa is such a warrior. I'm just so happy to come out with the win.\"\n\nRelated stories:\n\nSportsnet: Shapovalov shoots to star status with win over all-time great Nadal\n\nSportsnet: Denis Shapovalov's upset of Rafael Nadal historic in more ways than one\n\nBig Read: Shapovalov doing what it takes to succeed at tennis's highest level\n\nNadal, who could have claimed the No. 1 ranking if he had reached the semifinals this week, said it was the worst match he played all year, but he had kind words for Shapovalov.\n\n\"He played well,\" the 31-year-old said. \"He has a great potential.\n\n\"I wish him the best. He has everything to become a great player. He played with the right determination in the important moments.\"\n\nShapovalov looked unfazed in facing the biggest opponent of his young career. After Nadal cruised through the first set, Shapovalov kept battling, breaking service while taking a 3-0 lead in the second. When Nadal would start taking a control of a game, the younger of the two lefthanders would respond with big serves or impressive forehands down the lines.\n\nNadal fought off two break points to hold serve at 4-2, then earned his own break to win back the momentum from the 2016 Wimbledon junior boys champion, only to see Shapovalov snatch it back and clinch the second set.\n\nThe two held serve through the third. Nadal went up 3-0, but Shapovalov used two aces to fight back and complete the upset victory over the 10-time French Open champion.\n\nSecond-seeded Roger Federer, a 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 winner over Spain's David Ferrer, isn't one to gloat over his stunning record against Spaniard, who was ranked third in the world in 2013.\n\nWithout playing especially well, the 19-time Grand Slam champion from Switzerland stretched his career record against the Ferrer to 17-0. It started with a win in Vienna in 2003.\n\n\"Maybe in the beginning he was not as good as he is now,\" Federer said of Ferrer. \"Maybe I won five times because I'm better than he was.\n\n\"I was No. 1 in the world. I played him on hard courts also. I didn't play him often on clay. Also, there were many tight matches, so maybe it became a mental thing for him. I have a lot of respect for David. As a person, he's very nice. He's a great fighter on the court. So this type of head-to-head is a bit strange.\"\n\nIn Friday's quarter-finals, second-seeded Federer will face 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain, against whom he is 6-0. Bautista Agut outlasted Frenchman Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (2) in a two hours 56 minutes battle.\n\nUnseeded Argentine Diego Schwartzman posted a strange win over American Jared Donaldson 0-6, 7-5, 7-5 to advance to a quarter-final meeting with Robin Haase, the 52nd-ranked Dutchman who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov of Bulgaria 7-6 (3), 4-6, 6-1.\n\nKevin Anderson of South Africa downed American Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1 and will next play fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev, who ousted 16th seeded Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3.\n\nFederer, who breezed past Canadian Peter Polansky in the second round on Wednesday, looked lost in the opening set, spraying balls long, wide or into the net, but gradually rediscovered at least some of the form that has seen the 36-year-old Swiss put back the clock with two grand slam wins this year.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-10", "textEnd": 169, "textStart": 156}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T09:47:00Z", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "source": {"uri": "citynews.ca", "title": "CityNews", "id": "2068"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:47:00", "url": "http://www.citynews.ca/2017/08/11/richmond-hill-teen-denis-shapovalov-upsets-rafael-nadal-rogers-cup/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8582463", "image": "http://www.citynews.ca/wp-content/blogs.dir/sites/10/2017/08/11/0811-denisshapovalov.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "09:47:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"498181", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarterfinals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he reached the semi-finals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\n\"He played well. He has great potential,\" Nadal said. \"I wish him the best. He played with the right determination.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov, who is ranked 143rd in the world, had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal, beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He then defeated former U.S. Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nNadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe third game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting three times.\n\n\"Was it only 14 minutes?,\" Shapovalov asked. \"It felt like three hours.\n\n\"I just kept fighting. I knew it was going to be really tough. I went for my shots in the big moments and I caught a couple of lines got a little bit lucky but at the end of the day that is what tennis is.\"\n\nShapovalov said he didn't think he had a chance to win at all before the match. It wasn't until he levelled the sets at one each that he realized he could beat the 10-time French Open champion.\n\n\"The whole day I was like - there's no chance. I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"I went up a break in the second set early and even though he broke me back I felt like - OK, I am capable of breaking him.\n\n\"So when I won that second set I thought let's go one more set and who knows, anything can happen.\"\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including some on his second serve. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me.\"\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points, but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said.\n\n\"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nIn other matches Thursday, Germany's Alexander Zverev defeated Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3, Roberto Bautista outlasted Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2) and Kevin Anderson of South Africa cruised past Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1.\n\n\u00a9 2017 AFP", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T06:44:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"uri": "japantoday.com", "title": "Japan Today", "id": "18472"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:44:00", "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/sports/nadal's-pursuit-of-no.-1-derailed-by-canadian-teen", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8552589", "image": "https://japantoday-asset.scdn3.secure.raxcdn.com/img/store/e1/ab/84289584c32e1fc785d2f86568b0ac75377e/e1ab84289584c32e1fc785d2f86568b0ac75377e.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "06:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 2, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "By Kelsey Patterson\n\nMONTREAL -- Canadian Denis Shapovalov admits the epic tiebreak that propelled him into the second round of the Rogers Cup is still \"a little bit of a blur.\"\n\nThe 143rd-ranked Shapovalov survived four match points in a second-set tiebreak on his way to a 4-6, 7-6(8), 6-4 victory over the 64th-ranked Rogerio Dutra Silva of Brazil in the opening round on Tuesday.\n\n\"I don't remember all of them, honestly,\" said Shapovalov, who was granted a wild-card spot in the tournament. \"I wasn't holding back. I just told myself, 'He's got to win it from me. I'm not going to give it to him.'\n\n\"I think I did a good job to stay tough out there.\"\n\nAfter dropping the opening set, Shapovalov's margin for error was slim.\n\nThe Richmond Hill, Ont., native's comeback looked unlikely when he quickly fell behind 3-0 in the second-set tiebreak. He fired back-to-back aces to give himself a fighting chance.\n\nDown 6-4 -- the first match point -- Dutra Silva made an unforced error. Now 6-5, Shapovalov hit a clever drop shot just out of his opponent's reach. On the third match point, Dutra Silva sent his backhand long. Down 8-7, Shapovalov hit his sixth ace of the set to fend off elimination for the fourth time.\n\nWith the Canadian now in front 9-8, Dutra Silva double faulted to give Shapovalov the second-set victory.\n\n\"I'm sure he felt the crowd getting on him,\" said Shapovalov. \"After every match point I saved, they went pretty crazy. It adds to the nerve for the other guy. They were so alive, so intense.\"\n\nIn the third set, Shapovalov fired four aces. He broke Dutra Silva to take a 4-3 lead in the set and never looked back.\n\nOn triple match point, Shapovalov fired a serve that handcuffed Dutra Silva. The 18-year-old dropped his racket and threw his arms in the air as the centre court crowd at Uniprix Stadium erupted in cheers.\n\n\"Obviously after the breaker, I felt the momentum was shifting towards my way,\" said Shapovalov. \"I thought if I could get an early break, it would help me. I think I played really good tennis in the third set.\"\n\nIt's the second straight year that Shapovalov has advanced into the tournament's second round after beating Nick Kyrgios during his opening match in 2016 in Toronto.\n\nThe win is Shapovalov's first on hard court this year (1-3). It's also just his second victory on the ATP world tour in 2017.\n\nHe'll now face Juan Martin del Potro of Argentina, ranked No. 31, in the second round.\n\n\"He's one of my idols,\" said Shapovalov of del Potro. \"Growing up I saw him win the U.S. Open. So it's going to be an extremely tough match. But I live for these moments. I live to be in these matches. I think it's going to be a great battle.\"\n\nShapovalov's service game was his undoing in the first set. He was broken twice in the 41-minute set. Shapovalov's first serve regularly clocked in at over 200 kilometres per hour, but it lacked the accuracy to be effective. The Canadian had an abysmal first-serve success rate of 40 per cent in the opening set.\n\nBut as the youngster's serve improved, so did his confidence.\n\n\"I couldn't really find my rhythm in the first set,\" said Shapovalov. \"I felt like in the tiebreaker I really loosened up and just started going for my serves. I hit a bunch of aces there. In the third set, that kind of continued.\"\n\nEarlier in the afternoon, South Korea's Hyeon Chung upset Feliciano Lopez of Spain 6-1, 4-6, 7-6(3).\n\nChung, ranked No. 56 in the world, took advantage of several mistakes made by the 28th-ranked Lopez, including eight double faults, to win the two hour 16 minute match.\n\nThe opening match on centre court at Uniprix Stadium was supposed to feature 10th-ranked Tomas Berdych, but he pulled out with a rib injury. Berdych's withdrawal ended a streak of 12 consecutive appearances in Canada for the Czech player.\n\n\"I am sorry I have to apologize (to) all my Montreal fans,\" tweeted Berdych. \"I couldn't play, because of my rib disfunction I need to get well to go to office soon!!\"\n\nNo. 85 Ernesto Escobedo took his spot and upset 63rd-ranked Nikoloz Basilashvili in straight sets 7-6(4), 6-4.\n\nIn the final match of the day, third-seeded Dominic Thiem was upset in the second round by Diego Schwartzman 6-4. 6-7, 7-5 in a match that needed two hours 55 minutes. Thiem is the highest-ranked player at the tournament to be eliminated so far.\n\nAlso, American Jack Sock downed Pierre-Hugues Herber 7-6(4), 6-3 in first-round play, while fellow American Jared Donaldson beat Benoit Pare 6-2, 7-5 in the first second-round match of the tournament.\n\nBorna Coric easily defeated Mikhail Youzhny 6-2, 6-4 to set up a meeting with Rafael Nadal in the second round.\n\nPaolo Lorenzo downed American Frances Tiafoe 7-6(3), 0-6, 6-2. American Sam Querrey avoided an upset, rallying to beat qualifier Vincent Millot of France 4-6, 7-6(4), 7-5.\n\nIn doubles, Canadians Vasek Pospisil and Daniel Nestor lost 4-6, 6-4, 10-2 to Spaniards David Ferrer and Roberto Bautista Agut.\n\nMilos Raonic from Thornhill, Ont., was initially scheduled to play his opening match on Tuesday, but a minor injury forced him to postpone it to Wednesday. fought off four match points in a second-set tiebreaker and defeated Rogerio Dutra Silva of Brazil 4-6, 7-6 (8), 6-4 in the first round of the Rogers Cup Canadian Open tennis championships on Tuesday.\n\n\"It was a bit stressful, but the crowd pulled me through,\" said the 18-year-old from Toronto, who has reached the second round in each of the past two years. \"I hope we can keep it going.\"\n\nNext up for Shapovalov is Argentine Juan Martin del Potro, the 2009 U.S. Open champion. That match will be on centre court and the tentative starting time is 12:30 p.m.\n\nThis wasn't a vintage serving game for the left-handed Shapovalov. He put only 50 per cent of his first serves into play, but he came up with the big shots when he needed them. He had four of his 12 aces in the tiebreaker and ended the match with a wide service winner that forced Dutra Silva off the court on the ad side.\n\nShapovalov took control of the deciding set when he broke Dutra Silva's serve for a 4-3 lead. The Brazilian fell behind 15-40 and Shapovalov ripped a backhand winner for the break,\n\nShapovalov had to dig deep to survive the second-set tiebreaker. He fell behind 3-0 before delivering a pair of aces. Dutra Silva had two match points at 6-4, but an unforced error erased one point and Shapovalov pulled even with a half-volley drop shot for a winner.\n\nAn unforced error and an ace by Shapovalov allowed the Canadian to save the other match points and Dutra Silva double-faulted to give Shapovalov a 10-8 win in the tiebreaker.\n\nShapovalov wasn't the only player who had to dig deep for a spot in the second round. American serving machine Sam Querrey needed 18 aces and three sets to eliminate French qualifier Vincent Millot 4-6, 7-6 (4), 7-5 and Korean Hyeon Chung beat Spaniard Feliciano Lopez 6-1, 4-6, 7-6 (3).\n\nThere's no shortage of star power on centre court Wednesday. Second-seeded Roger Federer will play Peter Polansky of Toronto after the Shapovalov-del Potro match.\n\nRafael Nadal, the top seed, will make his tournament debut in the evening session beginning at 6:30 p.m. He will play Croatian Borna Coric. Shapovalov of Canada celebrates his victory over Rafael Nadal of Spain on day seven of the Rogers Cup in Montreal, Quebec, Canada \u00a9 GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA/AFP / Minas Panagiotakis\n\nMONTREAL, Canada, Aug 11 - Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he reached the semi-finals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\n\"He played well. He has great potential,\" Nadal said. \"I wish him the best. He played with the right determination.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov, who is ranked 143rd in the world, had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal, beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He then defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nNadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe third game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting three times.\n\n\"Was it only 14 minutes?,\" Shapovalov asked. \"It felt like three hours.\n\n\"I just kept fighting. I knew it was going to be really tough. I went for my shots in the big moments and I caught a couple of lines got a little bit lucky but at the end of the day that is what tennis is.\"\n\nShapovalov said he didn't think he had a chance to win at all before the match. It wasn't until he levelled the sets at one each that he realized he could beat the 10-time French Open champion.\n\n\"The whole day I was like - there's no chance. I will go and have fun but there is no way I am beating this guy,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"I went up a break in the second set early and even though he broke me back I felt like - OK, I am capable of breaking him.\n\n\"So when I won that second set I thought let's go one more set and who knows, anything can happen.\"\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including some on his second serve. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\n- 'Dream come true' -\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me.\"\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points, but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said.\n\n\"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nIn other matches Thursday, Germany's Alexander Zverev defeated Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3, Roberto Bautista outlasted Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2) and Kevin Anderson of South Africa cruised past Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1.\n\nShares", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 224, "textStart": 218}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T06:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"uri": "capitalfm.co.ke", "title": "Capital News", "id": "333"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:29:00", "url": "http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/11/nadals-pursuit-no-1-derailed-canadian-teen/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8550312", "image": "https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/files/2017/08/3dcd82e350bfcf902ed8316a16b57fa7e6e1a563.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "06:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

{"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Forget all the talk about Denis Shapovalov being the future of Canadian tennis.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill., Ont., has already arrived.\n\nShapovalov reached the quarter-finals of the $4.9-million Rogers Cup Canadian Open men's tennis championships Thursday, going toe-to-toe with top-seeded Rafael Nadal and emerging with a 4-6, 6-3, 7-6 (4) victory. The two left-handers battled for two hours and 46 minutes.\n\nShapovalov, the youngest player in the top 200, has been making his mark on the second-tier Challenger circuit, but his performance this week shows he has no respect for his elders. He reached the third round with wins over Rogerio Dutra Silva and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro. With the win, Shapovalov should crack the top 100 in the rankings for the first time. next week He could go as high as No. 66 if he wins his quarter-final match against Adrian Mannarino. They will play on centre court at 6:30 p.m. Friday.\n\nA single service break provided Nadal with the first set, but the young Canadian was just getting warmed up.\n\nOn two occasions in the second set, Shapovalov fell behind 0-30 on his serve, but he responded by winning four consecutive points. At 4-4, he pulled even with two aces, one of them clocked at 133 miles an hour. He was broken in the seventh game, but Shapovalov broke Nadal's serve a second time at 4-5 to secure the second set.\n\nShapovalov's serve let him down at 1-1 in the third set when he double-faulted three times and faced three break points. But he persevered to win a game that went to deuce 10 times. The players then held serve throughout the set to force a deciding tiebreaker.\n\nNadal had a mini-break on the first point of the tiebreaker, but gave it back with a double-fault for 3-3 and Shapovalov earned his first match point when Nadal netted a backhand to fall behind 6-4. Shapovalov won it on the next point with a forehand winner down the line. Shapovalov recorded two of his nine aces in the tiebreaker.\n\nShapovalov played an aggressive game throughout and had 49 winners and 41 unforced errors. Nadal had only 18 winners and 29 unforced errors.\n\nShapovalov fought off nine of 11 break points and Nadal said he wasn't surprised the youngster went for big shots on those points.\n\n\"He has nothing to lose. Is win-win for him,\" said Nadal, who needed to reach the semifinals here to reclaim the No. 1 spot in the rankings. \"If he loses playing a good match, was good for him. If he lose in straight sets, already he played a good tournament. If he wins, he's amazing. He won. Is amazing for him. Just well done for him. Is a great story, (but) I am not happy to be part of this story.\n\nShapovalov became the youngest quarter-finalist in the history of the ATP Masters 1000 series, which began in 1990.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T04:18:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"uri": "torontosun.com", "title": "Toronto Sun", "id": "2657"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:18:00", "url": "http://www.torontosun.com/2017/08/10/canadas-denis-shapovalov-takes-down-rafael-nadal-at-rogers-cup?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=recommend-button&utm_campaign=Canada's Denis Shapovalov takes down Rafael Nadal at Rogers Cup", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8534930", "image": "http://storage.torontosun.com/v1/suns-prod-images/1297981528613_LARGE_BOX.jpg?quality=80&stmp=1502424654997", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "04:18:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"1338842", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Diego Schwartzman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 1, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jared Donaldson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Donaldson", "score": 1, "id": "1339257", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Even Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov was amazed he had beaten tennis superstar Rafael Nadal.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont. shocked himself, the crowd that roared with every point he scored, and the tennis world with his 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4) victory over top-seeded Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday night at a sold out Uniprix Stadium.\n\nShapovalov dropped to the ground and covered his face in joy and surprise as the cheers reached deafening levels after the match point fell, completing his comeback from a 3-0 deficit in the third-set tiebreaker.\n\n\"It's what I dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa (Nadal), Roger (Federer), Andy (Murray),\" said Shapovalov. \"You know, my dream came true today.\"\n\nThe victory put him into a quarter-final Friday against France's Adrian Mannarino, who beat Hyeon Chung 6-3,6-3.\n\nIt was one of the biggest wins in Canadian tennis history and it came at the tournament that some still call the Canadian Open.\n\nShapovalov became the youngest player to reach the tournament's quarter-finals since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nHe also became the youngest quarter-finalist at a Masters Series tournament ever and is the youngest to beat a player ranked in the top two in the world since Nadal beat Federer in 2004 in Miami.\n\nShapovalov will reach his goal of moving into the top 100 in the world in a week that saw him save four match points in a first round win over Rogerio Dutra Silva, then beat 2009 U.S. Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round before toppling Nadal.\n\n\"I'm very thankful that I'm in this position,\" said Shapovalov, who had hockey great Wayne Gretzky and Olympic swimming star Penny Oleksiak cheering for him from the seats. \"If I didn't save those four match points in the first round, there wouldn't even be a chance to play Juan Martin or Rafa.\n\n\"It's difficult to say how I was feeling during the match. It was extremely hard physically and mentally. Rafa is such a warrior. I'm just so happy to come out with the win.\"\n\nNadal, who could have claimed the No. 1 ranking if he had reached the semifinals this week, said it was the worst match he played all year, but he had kind words for Shapovalov.\n\nHe has everything to become a great player.Rafael Nadal\n\n\"He played well,\" the 31-year-old said. \"He has a great potential.\n\n\"I wish him the best. He has everything to become a great player. He played with the right determination in the important moments.\"\n\nShapovalov looked unfazed in facing the biggest opponent of his young career. After Nadal cruised through the first set, Shapovalov kept battling, breaking service while taking a 3-0 lead in the second. When Nadal would start taking a control of a game, the younger of the two lefthanders would respond with big serves or impressive forehands down the lines.\n\nNadal fought off two break points to hold serve at 4-2, then earned his own break to win back the momentum from the 2016 Wimbledon junior boys champion, only to see Shapovalov snatch it back and clinch the second set.\n\nThe two held serve through the third. Nadal went up 3-0, but Shapovalov used two aces to fight back and complete the upset victory over the 10-time French Open champion.\n\nSecond-seeded Roger Federer, a 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 winner over Spain's David Ferrer, isn't one to gloat over his stunning record against Spaniard, who was ranked third in the world in 2013.\n\nWithout playing especially well, the 19-time Grand Slam champion from Switzerland stretched his career record against the Ferrer to 17-0. It started with a win in Vienna in 2003.\n\n\"Maybe in the beginning he was not as good as he is now,\" Federer said of Ferrer. \"Maybe I won five times because I'm better than he was.\n\n\"I was No. 1 in the world. I played him on hard courts also. I didn't play him often on clay. Also, there were many tight matches, so maybe it became a mental thing for him. I have a lot of respect for David. As a person, he's very nice. He's a great fighter on the court. So this type of head-to-head is a bit strange.\"\n\nIn Friday's quarter-finals, second-seeded Federer will face 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain, against whom he is 6-0.
