reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard\u00b4s chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\nNadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov Thursday, and then Chung Hyeon or Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nShapovalov\u00b4s stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil\u00b4s Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer\u00b4s 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer\u00b4s wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer\u00b4s serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself a set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer leveled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France\u00b4s Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T05:25:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"uri": "geo.tv", "title": "geo.tv", "id": "3799"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:25:00", "url": "https://www.geo.tv/latest/153231-top-seed-nadal-upset-by-canadian-teen-shapovalov", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8542286", "image": "https://www.geo.tv/assets/uploads/updates/2017-08-11/153231_093403_updates.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "05:25:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

great Rafael Nadal, three times a champion in Canada, takes on teenage sensation Denis Shapovalov. Shapovalov will surely once again have the noisy backing of the home crowd, which has so far fired him to victory, but will be facing a huge test against the famed Spaniard. With both playing well so far, a terrific clash should be in store.\n\nPerhaps unsurprisingly considering Shapovalov turned pro just last year he has not yet played Nadal. Indeed, this will be his first contest against one of the 'Big 4'. The gulf in experience between the two is also understandably huge. Shapovalov will be playing just 13th Tour level match. Of the previous 12, he has won five and lost seven. Nadal, in contrast, having turned pro 16 years ago, has played 1034 matches to date in his career, and has won 853 of them. He is also 73 times a titlist at Tour level, which includes 15 Slams and 30 Masters 1000 titles. Shapovalov has a junior Wimbledon title, and two challengers to his name. Good numbers for an 18-year-old, but some way short of Nadal's monumental haul.\n\nNadal, as the top seed in Montreal, enjoyed a first round bye. As a result, he opened against Borna Coric who had defeated Mikhail Youzhny in the first round. The Croatian had previously scored two victories against Nadal, in Basel in 2014 and in Cincinnati last year, where he thrashed Nadal for the loss of just four games. But a repeat of those defeats never looked likely as Nadal dominated the match from start to finish. Coric managed just six points in the opening four games and was swiftly 5-0 down. He managed to save some honour, pulling back one game, but the set was over and Nadal wrapped it up 6-1. The second was marginally more competitive, but Coric could still do little to hurt Nadal. The Spaniard twice broke serve and came away with a 6-1 6-2 victory. A terrific start to his hard court swing.\n\nDenis Shapovalov, a wildcard entrant, did not enjoy the luxury of a first round bye. The Canadian began against Rogerio Dutra Silva in one of the matches of the tournament so far. He dropped the first set to his Brazilian opponent and had to save four break points at 5-5 in the second. He did so, and made it to a tiebreak, where Dutra Silva fashioned four match points. Shapovalov saved them all, including one with a lovely sliced volley off his shoelaces. He took the set when Dutra Silva double faulted facing his set point. From there Shapovalov looked to be in control, breaking with an excellent backhand pass in the sixth game.\n\nHe served it out to love to set up a meeting with his idol and 2009 US Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro. It looked to be a tough test for the Canadian, but he rose to it superbly. That being said, the big Argentine was not at his best, with his forehand misfiring. Shapovalov took the first set quickly, 6-3. The second was a more tightly contested affair. Del Potro got an early break, but couldn't consolidate it. Shapovalov then broke at five games all, to serve for the match. But he played a horrible game to let Del Potro back into the match. In the tiebreak, however, he stepped his game up. Shapovalov met Del Potro's power with plenty of his own, and despite double faulting on his first match point, Shapovalov made no mistake the second time. His excellent run continues.\n\nShapovalov is in many ways the classic attacking baseliner. He launches into his shots whenever he gets the chance and is equally happy teeing off on the backhand and the forehand side. The young Canadian is also a terrific server, particularly off the first delivery. Against that Nadal brings some of the best defences the game has ever seen, equalled only by Novak Djokovic for court coverage, and a topspin forehand that has brought players as great as Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic to their knees with astonishing regularity.\n\nNadal's court coverage will make it a fascinating battle. How Shapovalov responds to a player who moves so much better than anyone he has ever faced will be key. He will have to be prepared to hit, at times, three or four extra shots to win the point without becoming frustrated. Nadal also defends out of the corners better than most, which will be crucial. Nadal must maintain good depth and width throughout, or as Shapovalov has demonstrated, he will hit players off the court. It promises to be one of the classic contests between defence and attack.\n\nNadal looked in frightening form against Borna Coric. Shapovalov has done brilliantly to get as far as he is, but there is a huge difference between beating Dutra Silva and an out of sorts Del Potro and beating Rafael Nadal. Nadal's experience, forehand and court coverage should see him through the match. Though he will likely have to watch a fair few balls fly past him it is difficult to see Shapovalov finding a way through Nadal enough to pull out the win. Nadal in straight sets.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-09T22:00:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"uri": "realsport101.com", "title": "RealSport", "id": "16982"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:19:00", "url": "https://realsport101.com/news/sports/tennis/rafael-nadal-vs-denis-shapovalov-rogers-cup-2017-3rd-round-preview-and-prediction/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8548923", "image": "https://realsport101.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Nadal-Rogers-Cup.jpg", "date": "2017-08-09", "time": "22:00:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

The Canadian Press Canadian Denis Shapovalov won the biggest match of his young career.\n\nEven Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov was amazed he had beaten tennis superstar Rafael Nadal.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont. shocked himself, the crowd that roared with every point he scored, and the tennis world with his 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4) victory over top-seeded Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday night at a sold out Uniprix Stadium.\n\nShapovalov dropped to the ground and covered his face in joy and surprise as the cheers reached deafening levels after the match point fell, completing his comeback from a 3-0 deficit in the third-set tiebreaker.\n\n\"It's what I dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa (Nadal), Roger (Federer), Andy (Murray),\" said Shapovalov. \"You know, my dream came true today.\"\n\nThe victory put him into a quarter-final Friday against France's Adrian Mannarino, who beat Hyeon Chung 6-3,6-3.\n\nIt was one of the biggest wins in Canadian tennis history and it came at the tournament that some still call the Canadian Open.\n\nShapovalov became the youngest player to reach the tournament's quarter-finals since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nHe also became the youngest quarter-finalist at a Masters Series tournament ever and is the youngest to beat a player ranked in the top two in the world since Nadal beat Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\nNadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov Thursday, and then Chung Hyeon or Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\n- Error prone -\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself a set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer leveled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France's Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T05:25:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "title": "News18", "id": "2489"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:25:00", "url": "http://www.news18.com/news/sports/montreal-masters-rafael-nadal-upset-by-canadian-teen-shapovalov-1488405.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8542276", "image": "http://img01.ibnlive.in/ibnlive/uploads/2016/01/nadal_1901getty_750.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "05:25:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\nNadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov Thursday, and then Chung Hyeon or Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself a set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer leveled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France's Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T05:46:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"uri": "nationmultimedia.com", "title": "The Nation", "id": "4219"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:46:00", "url": "http://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/sports/30323513", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8544798", "image": "http://www.nationmultimedia.com/img/news/2017/08/11/30323513/27d2026f28839588a347329198c33323-sld.jpeg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "05:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

after rallying to defeat Rogerio Dutra Silva of Brazil 4-6, 7-6(8), 6-4.\n\nThe 143rd-ranked Shapovalov got better as the match progressed, needing two hours 26 minutes to upset the 64th-ranked Dutra Silva.\n\nOn triple match point, Shapovalov fired a serve that handcuffed Dutra Silva. The 18-year-old dropped his racket and threw his arms in the air as the centre court crowd at Uniprix Stadium erupted in cheers.\n\nShapovalov's victory looked unlikely after he was broken twice in the 41-minute first set. The Richmond Hill, Ont., native's service game was his undoing to start the match.\n\nRead more:\n\nBouchard out of Rogers Cup after first-round loss to Vekic\n\nMonfils, Kyrgios move on at Rogers Cup in Montreal\n\nShapovalov's first serve regularly clocked in at over 200 kilometres per hour, but it lacked the accuracy to be effective. The Canadian had an abysmal first-serve success rate of 40 per cent in the opening set.\n\nBut as Shapovalov's serve improved, so did the youngster grow in confidence.\n\nThe turning point for Shapovalov, who was granted a wild-card spot in the tournament, came in the second-set tiebreak. Down 3-1, the Canadian fired back-to-back aces to even the set.\n\nShapovalov survived four match points in that tiebreak. Leading 9-8, Dutra Silva double faulted to give Shapovalov the second-set victory.\n\nIn the third set, Shapovalov fired four aces, with his first-serve success rate having increased to a respectable 60 per cent. He broke Dutra Silva to take a 4-3 lead in the set and never looked back.\n\nIt's the second-straight year that Shapovalov has advanced into the tournament's second round after beating Nick Kyrgios during his opening match in 2016 in Toronto.\n\nThe win is Shapovalov's first on hard court this year (1-3). It's also just his second victory on the ATP world tour in 2017.\n\nHe'll now face Juan Martin del Potro of Argentina, ranked No. 31, in the second round.\n\nEarlier in the afternoon, South Korea's Hyeon Chung upset Feliciano Lopez of Spain 6-1, 4-6, 7-6(3).\n\nChung, ranked No. 56 in the world, took advantage of several mistakes made by the 28th-ranked Lopez, including eight double faults, to win the two hour 16 minute match.\n\nLopez is now 10-12 in his career at the Rogers Cup.\n\nThe opening match on centre court at Uniprix Stadium was supposed to feature 10th-ranked Tomas Berdych but he pulled out with a rib injury. Berdych's withdrawal ended a streak of 12 consecutive appearances in Canada for the Czech player.\n\n\"I am sorry I have to apologize (to) all my Montreal fans,\" tweeted Berdych. \"I couldn't play, because of my rib disfunction I need to get well to go to office soon!!\"\n\nNo. 85 Ernesto Escobedo took his spot and upset 63rd-ranked Nikoloz Basilashvili in straight sets 7-6(4), 6-4.\n\nBorna Coric easily defeated Mikhail Youzhny 6-2, 6-4 to set up a meeting with Rafael Nadal in the second round.\n\nItaly's Paolo Lorenzo downed American Frances Tiafoe 7-6(3), 0-6, 6-2. American Sam Querrey avoided an upset, rallying to beat qualifier Vincent Millot of France 4-6, 7-6(4), 7-5.\n\nMilos Raonic from Thornhill, Ont., was initially scheduled to play his opening match on Tuesday but a minor injury forced him to postpone it to Wednesday. Hyeon"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chung_Hyeon", "score": 3, "id": "1338842", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6 6-4 7-6 (7/4) yesterday.\n\nNadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov yesterday, and then Chung Hyeon or Adrian Mannarino today.\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6 7-6 (10/8) 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 per cent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere yesterday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6 6-4 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said.\n\n\"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself a set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer leveled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France's Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6 7-6 (7/5) 7 -6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T08:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"uri": "dnaindia.com", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "id": "492"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:28:00", "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-top-seed-nadal-upset-by-canadian-teen-shapovalov-2526574", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8568544", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "08:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

tournament. He's also the second-youngest player to beat Nadal (Coric, 2014 Basel).\n\n\"It's so tough. A lot of the times he just hits a shot that's way too good. I was managing to get a lot back when I could. But, you know, he's honestly the best player I've ever played in my life,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"You could tell why he's won so many Grand Slams. His ball was just so heavy. He's such a warrior out there. So it's honestly, like a dream come true for me to beat a player like that.\"\n\nFor the Spaniard, a return to No. 1 in the Emirates ATP Rankings will have to wait. Nadal would have returned to No. 1 for the first time since June 2014 if he had reached the semi-finals in Montreal.\n\nAndy Murray will remain at No. 1 for another week but at the Western & Southern Open in Cincinnati next week, Nadal and Roger Federer will battle for the top spot.\n\nShapovalov, No. 143 in the Emirates ATP Rankings, is projected to reach a new career high and crack the Top 100 at No. 100. On Friday, he will look to continue his dream run at his home Masters 1000 tournament when he faces Frenchman Adrian Mannarino, who dismissed #NextGenATP Korean Hyeon Chung 6-3, 6-3 to reach his first Masters 1000 quarter-final in his 31 attempt.\n\nBut this much is clear so far: Shapovalov brings an entirely different level of tennis to Court Central. The 18 year old has now knocked off three top ATP World Tour players on that court during the past two years: Nick Kyrgios last year, Juan Martin del Potro earlier this week and Nadal became his latest upset victim in their marathon two-hour and 46-minute battle.\n\n\"It's a very fast pace right now. It's a lot to take in, obviously. But to be honest, I'm very thankful that I'm in this position,\" Shapovalov said. \"If I didn't save those four match points in the first round [against Dutra Silva], there wouldn't even be a chance to play Juan Martin or Rafa. I'm very thankful for that.\"\n\nThe teenager was under no illusions as to the calibre of opponent across the net from him.\n\nWith \"The Great One\" Wayne Gretzky and his wife in attendance, Shapovalov was ready from the start for another high-octane match in the Canadian metropolis. He fought to 3-3 with Nadal in the opening set, but the Spaniard sprinted through the remainder of the opener and looked as if he would need only two sets.\n\nShapovalov, though, came out strong in the second set, and had two chances to go up 5-1. But Nadal fought back and pushed the second set to 4-4 before Shapovalov recovered to even the third-round match.\n\nOn his first set point, the Canadian mishit a return that Nadal lifted long, and Shapovalov raised his arms to roars from his thousands of fans.\n\nThe Canadian had success exchanging forehands with Nadal and was fearless with his shot selection, taking every cheer as encouragement. For the match, the Canadian finished with 49 winners to 41 unforced errors. He delivered nine aces to only two from Nadal.\n\nShapovalov also dealt an effective 1-2 punch while returning, pushing Nadal to one corner before striking a one-handed backhand or forehand up the line.\n\nBut Nadal, a 30-time Masters 1000 titlist, dug in for the decider, as did Shapovalov. Serving at 1-1, the 18 year old erased three break points and held during a 14-minute and 30-second game, showing the Spaniard he was not going away in the final set. For the match, Shapovalov erased nine of 11 break points.\n\nIn the tie-break, it again looked as if Nadal would finally pull away. He jumped out to a 3/0 lead. But this time it was Shapovalov's turn to fight back, and he won seven of the tie-break's final eight points to earn the biggest win of his life. Fittingly, he blasted a forehand winner on his first match point.\n\nAfter the ball sped past Nadal, Shapovalov tossed his racquet and fell to the court, covering his eyes in disbelief. The crowd's cheers soaked their new home favourite and, after he shook hands with Nadal, Shapovalov finished his celebration by saying thanks. He kissed the court and blew kisses to the crowd.\n\n\"I don't know if a lot of players fold or if he just outplays them at the end,\" Shapovalov said. \"I was down 3-0 in the tie-break. I did a good job to regroup. I knew I had to win both the points off my serve. Yeah, then he gave me a double [fault] to tie it up.\n\n\"I just tried to stay calm, tried to play every point, go for my shots. At the end of the day I really tried to keep playing my game and stick to my tactics.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2014-06-", "textEnd": 724, "textStart": 715}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T02:14:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"uri": "atpworldtour.com", "title": "ATP World Tour", "id": "9695"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:19:00", "url": "http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/nadal-shapovalov-montreal-2017-thursday", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8548909", "image": "www.atpworldtour.com/-/media/images/news/2017/08/11/03/07/shapovalov-montreal-2017-thursday.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "02:14:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"MONTREAL -- Roger Federer advanced to the semifinals of the Rogers Cup and was joined later Friday by Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov, who followed his upset of Rafael Nadal with another three-set victory.\n\nThe 18-year-old left-hander from Richmond Hill, Ontario beat France's Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 and awaits the winner of the late match between fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany and Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nShapovalov beat 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round and then knocked off the top-seeded Nadal in a third-set tiebreaker on Thursday in the round of 16.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third Friday only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. The 36-year-old Swiss will next face unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase, a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer has won all seven career matches and taken all 16 sets against the 29-year-old Bautista Agut.\n\nHe is 1-0 against Haase after a straight-sets win in Davis Cup play in 2012.\n\nFederer said he knows Haase well from serving with him on the ATP player council and from practicing together.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to a tough match because he can serve very well and he mixes up his tactics a lot,\" Federer said. \"Sometimes he tends to just roll the ball in and use the big serve, or he uses a slice a lot and comes in.\n\n\"So I don't quite know with Robin what I'm going to get. But, as I have practiced with him quite a bit, maybe I am better prepared than if I would have never hit with him before.\"\n\nFederer broke serve for a 5-4 lead in the first set and broke again for 2-1 in the second en route to the victory in a little more than an hour. Federer was coming off a three-set win over another Spaniard, David Ferrer, against whom he is 17-0.\n\n\"My game plan worked better against Bautista Agut than against Ferrer,\" he said. \"I believe it's because I was more aggressive coming to the net.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, reached his first career Masters Series semifinal. The 30-year-old Haase, back to 52nd in the world after battling injuries for much of his career, improved to 5-0 against 36th-ranked Schwartzman.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially against Dimitrov,\" said Haase. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level.\n\n\"I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:43:00Z", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "source": {"uri": "nationalpost.com", "title": "National Post", "id": "973"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:04:00", "url": "http://nationalpost.com/pmn/sports-pmn/federer-canadian-teen-shapovalov-reach-semis-in-montreal/wcm/ae16c77e-3930-48fd-8332-8583900fe1a5", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8755868", "image": "http://1.gravatar.com/blavatar/bf69214e83fdd5520e4b5d91ba3b7d64?s=200&ts=1502521494", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:43:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

semifinals of the Rogers Cup and was joined later Friday by Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov, who followed his upset of Rafael Nadal with another three-set victory.\n\nThe 18-year-old left-hander from Richmond Hill, Ontario beat France's Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 and will face fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany on Saturday.\n\nShapovalov beat 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round and then knocked off the top-seeded Nadal in a third-set tiebreaker on Thursday in the round of 16.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third set Friday only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\n\"I've been against the wall a couple times this week and I'm very happy I've come out several times just playing really good tennis in those situations,\" Shapovalov said. \"I think it really shows how I've improved mentally, along with just finding my game at the right moments.\"\n\nAfter facing a run of veterans, he will be up against the 20-year-old Zverev, who beat Kevin Anderson of South Africa 7-5, 6-4.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. "score": 4, "id": "1338842", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov Thursday, and then Chung Hyeon or Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\n- Error prone -\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself a set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer leveled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France's Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T06:26:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"uri": "afp.com", "title": "Agence France Presse (AFP)", "id": "2391"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:26:00", "url": "https://www.afp.com/en/news/207/top-seed-nadal-upset-canadian-teen-shapovalov", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8549793", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "06:26:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"id": "405086", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Adrian Mannarino"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Mannarino", "score": 3, "id": "405343", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Uniprix Stadium"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniprix_Stadium", "score": 3, "id": "651038", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Chung Hyeon"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chung_Hyeon", "score": 3, "id": "1338842", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Diego Schwartzman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 1, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jared Donaldson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Donaldson", "score": 1, "id": "1339257", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Even Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov was amazed he had beaten tennis superstar Rafael Nadal.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont. shocked himself, the crowd that roared with every point he scored, and the tennis world with his 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4) victory over top-seeded Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday night at a sold out Uniprix Stadium.\n\nShapovalov dropped to the ground and covered his face in joy and surprise as the cheers reached deafening levels after the match point fell, completing his comeback from a 3-0 deficit in the third-set tiebreaker.\n\n\"It's what I dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa (Nadal), Roger (Federer), Andy (Murray),\" said Shapovalov. \"You know, my dream came true today.\"\n\nThe victory put him into a quarter-final Friday against France's Adrian Mannarino, who beat Hyeon Chung 6-3,6-3.\n\nIt was one of the biggest wins in Canadian tennis history and it came at the tournament that some still call the Canadian Open.\n\nShapovalov became the youngest player to reach the tournament's quarter-finals since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nHe also became the youngest quarter-finalist at a Masters Series tournament ever and is the youngest to beat a player ranked in the top two in the world since Nadal beat Federer in 2004 in Miami.\n\nShapovalov will reach his goal of moving into the top 100 in the world in a week that saw him save four match points in a first round win over Rogerio Dutra Silva, then beat 2009 U.S. Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round before toppling Nadal.\n\n\"I'm very thankful that I'm in this position,\" said Shapovalov, who had hockey great Wayne Gretzky and Olympic swimming star Penny Oleksiak cheering for him from the seats. \"If I didn't save those four match points in the first round, there wouldn't even be a chance to play Juan Martin or Rafa.\n\n\"It's difficult to say how I was feeling during the match. It was extremely hard physically and mentally. Rafa is such a warrior. I'm just so happy to come out with the win.\"\n\nNadal, who could have claimed the No. 1 ranking if he had reached the semifinals this week, said it was the worst match he played all year, but he had kind words for Shapovalov.\n\n\"He played well,\" the 31-year-old said. \"He has a great potential.\n\n\"I wish him the best. He has everything to become a great player. He played with the right determination in the important moments.\"\n\nShapovalov looked unfazed in facing the biggest opponent of his young career. After Nadal cruised through the first set, Shapovalov kept battling, breaking service while taking a 3-0 lead in the second. When Nadal would start taking a control of a game, the younger of the two lefthanders would respond with big serves or impressive forehands down the lines.\n\nNadal fought off two break points to hold serve at 4-2, then earned his own break to win back the momentum from the 2016 Wimbledon junior boys champion, only to see Shapovalov snatch it back and clinch the second set.\n\nThe two held serve through the third. Nadal went up 3-0, but Shapovalov used two aces to fight back and complete the upset victory over the 10-time French Open champion.\n\nSecond-seeded Roger Federer, a 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 winner over Spain's David Ferrer, isn't one to gloat over his stunning record against Spaniard, who was ranked third in the world in 2013.\n\nWithout playing especially well, the 19-time Grand Slam champion from Switzerland stretched his career record against the Ferrer to 17-0. It started with a win in Vienna in 2003.\n\n\"Maybe in the beginning he was not as good as he is now,\" Federer said of Ferrer. \"Maybe I won five times because I'm better than he was.\n\n\"I was No. 1 in the world. I played him on hard courts also. I didn't play him often on clay. Also, there were many tight matches, so maybe it became a mental thing for him. I have a lot of respect for David. As a person, he's very nice. He's a great fighter on the court. So this type of head-to-head is a bit strange.\"\n\nIn Friday's quarter-finals, second-seeded Federer will face 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain, against whom he is 6-0. Bautista Agut outlasted Frenchman Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (2) in a two hours 56 minutes battle.\n\nUnseeded Argentine Diego Schwartzman posted a strange win over American Jared Donaldson 0-6, 7-5, 7-5 to advance to a quarter-final meeting with Robin Haase, the 52nd-ranked Dutchman who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov of Bulgaria 7-6 (3), 4-6, 6-1.\n\nKevin Anderson of South Africa downed American Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-1 and will next play fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev, who ousted 16th seeded Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3.\n\nFederer, who breezed past Canadian Peter Polansky in the second round on Wednesday, looked lost in the opening set, spraying balls long, wide or into the net, but gradually rediscovered at least some of the form that has seen the 36-year-old Swiss put back the clock with two grand slam wins this year.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-10T23:55:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"uri": "tsn.ca", "title": "TSN", "id": "12443"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:53:00", "url": "http://www.tsn.ca/shapovalov-stuns-nadal-in-thriller-to-advance-to-montreal-quarters-1.827145", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8553825", "image": "http://www.tsn.ca/polopoly_fs/1.827520!/fileimage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_620/denis-shapovalov.jpg", "date": "2017-08-10", "time": "23:55:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

3, "id": "405343", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Alex De Minaur"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_De_Minaur", "score": 2, "id": "1338639", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Just three weeks ago, Shapovalov, ranked 143rd on the ATP Tour, was playing in tournaments on the Challenger and Futures level in rural Quebec, in places like Drummondville, Gatineau and Sherbrooke. On Thursday night, he prevailed on Center Court at Canada's biggest tennis tournament.\n\n\"I couldn't believe it actually happened,\" Shapovalov said. \"It's tough to explain the emotions that were going through my head at that moment. But it was just pure happiness.\"\n\nMen's tennis this season has been dominated by Nadal, 31, and Roger Federer, who turned 36 on Tuesday. Shapovalov, however, proved capable of handling himself on the big stage. His relentlessness and power were on display throughout the evening. Shapovalov fired nine aces compared to Nadal's two. Several of his serves topped 124 miles per hour. He hit 49 winners, more than double Nadal's 18.\n\nNadal praised Shapovalov's energy after the match.\n\n\"He played with the right determination in the important moments,\" Nadal said.\n\nNadal called it a win-win match for Shapovalov, who had beaten another Grand Slam champion, Juan Mart\u00edn del Potro of Argentina, on Wednesday.\n\nShapovalov plays Adrian Mannarino in the quarterfinals on Friday night.\n\nShapovalov, who was born in Tel Aviv but moved to Canada as an infant, started playing tennis when he was 5 at the club where his mother, Tessa Shapovalova, worked.\n\nA former professional player herself, Shapovalov's mother later opened her own tennis academy in Vaughan, Ontario, outside Toronto. It served as a base for Shapovalov, who resisted the pressure to move to the National Training Center in Montreal. His mother is still one of his coaches.\n\nAfter winning junior tournaments in Ontario, he experienced similar successes at International Tennis Federation junior events around the world. In October 2015, when he was 16, Shapovalov helped Canada secure its first Junior Davis Cup title. Seven months later, he advanced to the semifinals at the French Open junior tournament. Then at Wimbledon, he became the third Canadian to win a junior Grand Slam title, when he defeated Alex De Minaur of Australia in three sets.\n\nThis season, Shapovalov has played ATP Tour events big and small. In March he lost in the final of the Jalisco Open in Guadalajara, Mexico. He was then eliminated either in the first round or in qualifying of his next five consecutive tournaments, including the French Open. Before the Rogers Cup, Shapovalov reached the final in both of the Challenger tournaments he played, winning the title in Gatineau.\n\nNadal, similarly, reached the semifinals in boys singles at Wimbledon when he was 16. He also helped Spain to win a Junior Davis Cup title. And as a teenager Nadal also beat a top-ranked player, stunning Roger Federer in the third round of the Miami Open in 2004.\n\nAfter Thursday's match, Shapovalov tipped his cap to Nadal, now the veteran.\n\n\"He's such a warrior out there,\" said Shapovalov, who, like Nadal, plays left-handed. \"So it's honestly like a dream come true for me to beat a player like that.\"\n\nNadal, who could have returned to the No. 1 ranking by reaching the semifinals here, was asked if Shapovalov reminded him of his own journey through pro tennis.\n\n\"In my opinion it is much more easy when you are 18 than when you are 30,\" Nadal said. \"He has nothing to lose.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2015-10-", "textEnd": 1824, "textStart": 1812}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {"liCnt": 6}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:00:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "title": "The New York Times", "id": "91"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:00:00", "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/11/sports/denis-shapovalov-rafael-nadal-rogers-cup.html", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8692687", "image": "https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/08/12/sports/tennis/12TENNISweb/12TENNISweb-videoSixteenByNineJumbo1600.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:00:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nMONTREAL (AP) -- Roger Federer advanced to the semifinals of the Rogers Cup and was joined later Friday by Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov, who followed his upset of Rafael Nadal with another three-set victory.\n\nThe 18-year-old left-hander from Richmond Hill, Ontario beat France's Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 and awaits the winner of the late match between fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany and Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nShapovalov beat 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round and then knocked off the top-seeded Nadal in a third-set tiebreaker on Thursday in the round of 16.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third Friday only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. The 36-year-old Swiss will next face unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase, a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer has won all seven career matches and taken all 16 sets against the 29-year-old Bautista Agut.\n\nHe is 1-0 against Haase after a straight-sets win in Davis Cup play in 2012.\n\nFederer said he knows Haase well from serving with him on the ATP player council and from practicing together.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to a tough match because he can serve very well and he mixes up his tactics a lot,\" Federer said. \"Sometimes he tends to just roll the ball in and use the big serve, or he uses a slice a lot and comes in.\n\n\"So I don't quite know with Robin what I'm going to get. But, as I have practiced with him quite a bit, maybe I am better prepared than if I would have never hit with him before.\"\n\nFederer broke serve for a 5-4 lead in the first set and broke again for 2-1 in the second en route to the victory in a little more than an hour. Federer was coming off a three-set win over another Spaniard, David Ferrer, against whom he is 17-0.\n\n\"My game plan worked better against Bautista Agut than against Ferrer,\" he said. \"I believe it's because I was more aggressive coming to the net.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, reached his first career Masters Series semifinal. The 30-year-old Haase, back to 52nd in the world after battling injuries for much of his career, improved to 5-0 against 36th-ranked Schwartzman.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially against Dimitrov,\" said Haase. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level.\n\n\"I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting.\"\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. the Spaniard's chances of returning to World No 1.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\nNadal would have returned to No 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov on Thursday, and then Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nRafael Nadal congratulates Denis Shapovalov on his 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4) win at Montreal Masters. AP\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nError prone\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself a set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer leveled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. "MONTREAL (AP) -- Roger Federer advanced to the semifinals of the Rogers Cup and was joined later Friday by Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov, who followed his upset of Rafael Nadal with another three-set victory.\n\nThe 18-year-old left-hander from Richmond Hill, Ontario beat France's Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 and awaits the winner of the late match between fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany and Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nShapovalov beat 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round and then knocked off the top-seeded Nadal in a third-set tiebreaker on Thursday in the round of 16.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third Friday only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\nDownload our free ebook to find out how agency CIOs and CHCOs implementing the president's reorganization executive order.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. The 36-year-old Swiss will next face unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase, a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer has won all seven career matches and taken all 16 sets against the 29-year-old Bautista Agut.\n\nHe is 1-0 against Haase after a straight-sets win in Davis Cup play in 2012.\n\nFederer said he knows Haase well from serving with him on the ATP player council and from practicing together.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to a tough match because he can serve very well and he mixes up his tactics a lot,\" Federer said. \"Sometimes he tends to just roll the ball in and use the big serve, or he uses a slice a lot and comes in.\n\n\"So I don't quite know with Robin what I'm going to get. But, as I have practiced with him quite a bit, maybe I am better prepared than if I would have never hit with him before.\"\n\nSEC warns TSP participants of new scam\n\nFederer broke serve for a 5-4 lead in the first set and broke again for 2-1 in the second en route to the victory in a little more than an hour. Federer was coming off a three-set win over another Spaniard, David Ferrer, against whom he is 17-0.\n\n\"My game plan worked better against Bautista Agut than against Ferrer,\" he said. \"I believe it's because I was more aggressive coming to the net.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, reached his first career Masters Series semifinal. The 30-year-old Haase, back to 52nd in the world after battling injuries for much of his career, improved to 5-0 against 36th-ranked Schwartzman.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially against Dimitrov,\" said Haase. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level.\n\n\"I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:56:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"uri": "federalnewsradio.com", "title": "Federal News Radio", "id": "9518"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:56:00", "url": "https://federalnewsradio.com/sports-news/2017/08/federer-canadian-teen-shapovalov-reach-semis-in-montreal/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8731709", "image": "https://federalnewsradio.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/APTOPIX_Montreal_Tennis_32318.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:56:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

(Paul Chiasson/The Canadian Press via AP)\n\nAlmost a decade before 18-year-old Denis Shapovalov became one of the brightest young stars on the men's professional tennis tour, he was a tiny kid with long blonde hair posing for photos with Rafael Nadal and Igor Andreev ahead of their match at the 2008 Rogers Cup in Toronto.\n\nShapovalov, who was born in Israel but moved with his family to Canada at an early age, was at Rogers Cup as a player mascot for his hometown tournament. He escorted Andreev onto center court, helped with the coin toss, shook hands with the players and posed for photos before the start of the match, which Nadal would win en route to claiming the event's title that year.\n\nBack to the future: that time @denis_shapo was a mascot for Rafael Nadal in 2008...#CoupeRogers pic.twitter.com/Tl4toivrGh\n\n-- Tennis TV (@TennisTV) August 11, 2017\n\nFast forward nine years and Shapovalov, now a fast-rising tennis sensation ranked No. 143 in the world, was back on the court with Nadal. Only this time, Shapovalov was Nadal's opponent. In front of a roaring hometown crowd that included Wayne Gretzky cheering him on, Shapovalov stunned top-seeded Nadal, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7-4), to advance to the quarterfinals.\n\n\"It's what I dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa, Roger [Federer], Andy [Murray],\" Shapovalov said after the match. \"You know, my dream came true today.\"\n\n2008 - 2017. #Nadal vs. #Shapovalov, neuf ans plus tard. #CoupeRogers #RogersCup pic.twitter.com/S0E8DlhKm2\n\n-- Tennis Legend (@TennisLegende) August 11, 2017\n\nShapovalov has given Canadian tennis fans plenty to cheer about. He defeated 2009 U.S. Open champion and former top 5 player Juan Martin del Potro in the previous round and swung freely against the 15-time Grand Slam winner Nadal -- a player who Shapovalov said he \"grew up watching.\"\n\n\"I've seen [Nadal] win so many Slams,\" he said after his victory over del Potro. \"Every time I look at him, I think what a ridiculous athlete and what a ridiculous player he is. It's unbelievable to watch.\"\n\nAfter the match, a frustrated Nadal lamented his loss, saying it was \"probably the worst match of the year for me\" because of the missed opportunity to regain the world No. 1 ranking. But still the 31-year-old Spaniard had praise for his much younger opponent.\n\n\"He played well,\" Nadal said. \"He has great potential. I wish him the best. He has everything to become a great player. He played with the right determination in the important moments.\"\n\nShapovalov is among the wave of talented young players 21-and-under that the tour has promoted as the Next Gen. Two of those players -- Shapovalov and 16-year-old Felix Auger-Aliassime -- are from Canada.\n\n\"We've got so many players coming up. Not [just] me,\" Shapovalov said during last year's Rogers Cup. \"So of course it's exciting for Canadian tennis. We are very happy to be a part of it.\"\n\nRead more:\n\nTen years and the threat of a body check later, this fan-turned-NHL player got Ovechkin's autograph\n\nAlexander Zverev might be tennis's heir to the Big Four. Montreal Masters quarters.(AFP)\n\nRoger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters on Thursday after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard, while Rafael Nadal suffered a shock defeat at the hands of Denis Shapovalov.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nREAD | Venus Williams battles into Toronto last 16, Garbine Muguruza through\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nREAD | Vishnu Vardhan reaches doubles semis with N Sriram Balaji in Jinan Challenger\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France's Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.\n\nNadal stunned\n\nRafael Nadal won the first set 6-3 against Denis Shapovalov, but the Canadian teenager fought back brilliantly to win the second set 6-4.\n\nThe match headed into a deciding tie-breaker, and unfazed by the pressure, Shapovalov won it 7-4 to win the match 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4).", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T06:05:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "title": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/", "id": "294"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:05:00", "url": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/tennis/roger-federer-into-montreal-masters-quarters-rafael-nadal-knocked-out/story-OgwlLtWqTtFAAoDNKLr78I.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8546932", "image": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/rf/image_size_960x540/HT/p2/2017/08/11/Pictures/rogers-cup-presented-by-national-bank-day_e410dd9e-7e45-11e7-ba32-a280bea68af6.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "06:05:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

{"eng": "Backhand"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backhand", "score": 3, "id": "374056", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Forehand"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forehand", "score": 3, "id": "420299", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 3, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "It's a fallacy that young professional tennis talents struggle with pressure and nerves more than experienced players. Most of the gifted teens have mental advantages. They have skills and power, and know that they no one expects them to beat high-ranked players in top tournaments. Rather than worry about anything, a teenager can swing freely and apply pressure -- and on their best days, win historic upsets.\n\nOn Thursday evening in Montreal, 18-year-old Denis Shapovalov beat Rafael Nadal 3-6, 6-4, 7-6(4) for the biggest victory of his young career. He's left-handed with a strong serve, a one-handed backhand, and a forehand that he hits hard and deep. And no matter the score against Nadal, Shapovalov played aggressive. He even trailed 3-0 in the third set tiebreaker, before pummeling Nadal 7-points-to-1 the rest of the way.\n\nShapovalov, who will play in the quarterfinals Friday evening, is the youngest quarterfinalist in an ATP Masters 1000 tournament since these events began in 1990. He's also the youngest player in a Rogers Cup quarterfinal since Bjorn Borg, who was 18 when he made it here in 1974.\n\n\"I played really well in the big moments,\" Shapovalov said after the match. \"I'm not sure why. I just played really free in the tiebreaker.\"\n\nNadal knows why: It's good being young and extremely talented. Nadal was once like this. He won the French Open at age 19, the first time he entered the tournament. On a hard court as a 17-year-old, Nadal crushed Roger Federer in a Miami event for top players. Now, at the age of 30, he knows how much tennis changes in your mind as your career builds.\n\n\"In my opinion, is much more easy when you have 18 [years] than when you have 30. [Shapovalov] has nothing to lose,\" Nadal said. \"If he loses in straight sets, already he played a good tournament. If he wins, he's amazing. He won. Is amazing for him.\"\n\nNadal said the match wasn't so thrilling for him. \"Probably the worst match of the year for me,\" he said. \"When you play bad, you have to win these matches. I didn't today.\"\n\nShapovalov was born in Tel Aviv, Israel, but only lived there for nine months, when his parents -- Viktor and Tessa -- moved the family to Canada. He started playing at age 5 with his mother, who is a tennis coach. Clearly she teaches beautiful strokes and Shapovalov listened.\n\nShapovalov seems to have all the tools a player needs to succeed, but give him time -- a lot of time. Like Nadal said, playing as an up-and-coming star is easy against top-ranked players. Shapovalov is currently ranked #143 and was given a wildcard into the event.\n\nPlenty of other young players over the last generation have looked just as gifted as Shapovalov, but so far they haven't won majors and displaced the sport's five top stars: Federer, Nadal, Andy Murray, Novak Djokovic, and Stan Wawrinka. That will change one day; Father Time remains undefeated in the long run.\n\nIt's nice, though, to see an upcoming young player win against the best in the sport. If anything, it shows that tennis can still grow in terms of strategy and ability -- and that even the best can be beaten.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:37:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"uri": "weeklystandard.com", "title": "Weekly Standard", "id": "9952"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:37:00", "url": "http://www.weeklystandard.com/denis-shapovalov-the-next-tennis-great/article/2009259", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8689683", "image": "http://www.weeklystandard.com/s3/tws15/images/twitter/tws-twitter_1024x512.png", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:37:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday. Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov Thursday, and then Chung Hyeon or Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot. Shapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands. Shapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T05:15:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:15:00", "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tennis/top-stories/top-seed-nadal-upset-by-canadian-teen-shapovalov/articleshow/60014936.cms", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8541441", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-60014971/60014971.jpg?68277", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "05:15:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Juan Martin Del Potro. He also halted Nadal's bid to regain the No. 1 ranking, which the Spaniard could have achieved by reaching the semifinals.\n\nREAD | Roger Federer into Montreal Masters quarters, Rafael Nadal knocked out\n\nShapovalov battled back after Nadal cruised through the first set, then erased a 3-0 deficit in the tiebreaker for the biggest victory of his career.\n\nShapovalov became the youngest player to reach the tournament's quarterfinals since Bjorn Borg in 1974. With hockey great Wayne Gretzky and Olympic swimming star Penny Oleksiak cheering for him from the seats, he also became the youngest quarterfinalist at a Masters Series tournament ever and is the youngest to beat a player ranked in the top two in the world since Nadal beat Federer in 2004 in Miami.\n\n\"He played well,\" Nadal said. \"He has a great potential.\n\n\"I wish him the best.
