(Source: Reuters) Top-seeded Rafael Nadal goes down at Rogers Cup, Roger Federer advancesRafael Nadal opens Rogers Cup with easy winRogers Cup: Roger Federer cruises in first match since Wimbledon win\n\nRoger Federer reached the Rogers Cup semi-finals on Friday after coming to the net early and often in a straight sets victory over Roberto Bautista Agut on a windy day in Montreal.\n\nWorld number three Federer, who faces Dutchman Robin Haase in the last four, was never seriously pushed by Spain's Bautista Agut, who is winless in seven matches against the Swiss maestro.\n\n\"I think it pays off playing aggressive here in Montreal,\" Federer said in a courtside interview after his 6-4 6-4 win over the 12th seed.\n\n\"Plus I feel comfortable at the net so why not spend some time up there instead of slugging it out from the baseline?\"\n\nFederer opened the second set with a break and cruised through the rest of the match, which lasted just over an hour.\n\nWith world number two Rafael Nadal eliminated on Thursday by 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov and world number one Andy Murray sidelined by a rib injury, Federer has an opportunity to regain his world number one ranking.\n\nHe would need to win the Rogers Cup and have an equal or better finish than Nadal at the Western & Southern Open in Cincinnati next week to become the world number one on Aug. 21.\n\n\"Now that Rafa is out I know I can make big strides, especially if I was to go further than the semis here. But it's all connected to great play,\" said the Australian Open and Wimbledon champion.\n\nIn the other quarter-finals, Shapovalov came from a set down to beat Adrian Mannarino of France 2-6 6-3 6-4, and Germany's Alexander Zverev dismissed South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets, 7-5 6-4.\n\nEarlier, Haase recovered to defeat Argentine Diego Schwartzman 4-6 6-3 6-3 in their quarter-final.\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Roger Federer", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 50, "textStart": 35}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-21", "textEnd": 1458, "textStart": 1451}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T09:48:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:48:00", "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/tennis/aggressive-roger-federer-cruises-to-semi-finals-in-montreal-4793432/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8773426", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/08/federer-reuters-m.jpg?w=759", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "09:48:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 3, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL: Swiss star Roger Federer outclassed Roberto Bautista Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarter-finals of the Montreal Masters on Friday. Federer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points. \"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said. \"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\" Federer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day. Bautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points. \"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\" Federer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017. He will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two. The pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4. Federer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4. Mannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian. Shapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round. Shapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game. \"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman. Haase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place. \"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said. \"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better. \"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\" Fourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov. Zverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov is the youngest since 1990 to reach a Masters 1000 quarter-final.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T20:52:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"uri": "dailytimes.com.pk", "title": "dailytimes.com.pk", "id": "1244"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:52:00", "url": "http://dailytimes.com.pk/sports/13-Aug-17/federer-punches-ticket-to-montreal-semis", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8842729", "image": "http://dailytimes.com.pk/static/uploads/original/070141de69237eab442c8d76e7ede6fa.jpg ", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "20:52:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL: Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, temporarily spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to stun Nadal in three sets 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\n\"I was just swinging for the fences,\" said Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament.\n\nThe 31-year-old Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had reached the semi-finals.\n\nBut Nadal struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand and didn't have an answer for the Canadian's blistering forehand winners.\n\nNadal described it as the worst loss of the season for him for a number of reasons.\n\n\"Worst loss of the year because I lost against a player with a lower ranking,\" Nadal said. \"At the same time because of the opportunity I had to get back to Number One.\"\n\nShapovalov's biggest win of his young career against the 15-time Grand Slam winner came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov fell behind 3-0 before winning seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker. He closed out the match with a forehand winner down the line and celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nNadal easily won the first set but couldn't put the free-swinging Canadian away with a second set victory.\n\nThe third game of the second set lasted 14 minutes with Shapovalov finally holding serve when Nadal's volley sailed into the net. Shapovalov managed to win the game despite double faulting three times.\n\n\"It is incredible. I can't even talk right now. I grew up watching Rafa so just to be able to compete with him is one thing but to come out winning is a dream come true for me,\" he said. -- AFP", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T04:24:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"uri": "thenews.com.pk", "title": "The News International", "id": "460"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:24:00", "url": "https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/223082-Nadals-pursuit-of-No-1-derailed-by-Canadian-teen", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8742678", "image": "https://www.thenews.com.pk/assets/uploads/akhbar/2017-08-12/l_223082_042559_print.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "04:24:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

{"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Forget all the talk about Denis Shapovalov being the future of Canadian tennis.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill., Ont., has already arrived.\n\nShapovalov reached the quarter-finals of the $4.9-million Rogers Cup Canadian Open men's tennis championships Thursday, going toe-to-toe with top-seeded Rafael Nadal and emerging with a 4-6, 6-3, 7-6 (4) victory. The two lefthanders battled for two hours and 46 minutes.\n\nShapovalov, the youngest player in the top 200, has been making his mark on the second tier Challenger circuit, but his performance this week showed he has no respect for his elders. He reached the third round with wins over Rogerio Dutra Silva and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro. With the win, Shapovalov should crack the top 100 in the rankings for the first time next week.\n\nA single service break provided Nadal with the first set, but the young Canadian was just getting warmed up.\n\nOn two occasions in the second set, Shapovalov fell behind 0-30 on his serve, but he responded by winning four consecutive points. At 4-4, he pulled even with two aces, one of them clocked at 133 miles an hour. He failed to come back in the seventh game, but Shapovalov broke Nadal's serve again at 4-5 to secure the second set.\n\nShapovalov's serve let him down at 1-1 in the third set when he double-faulted three times and faced three break points. But he persevered to win a game that went to deuce 10 times. But the players held serve throughout the set.\n\nNadal had a mini-break on the first point of the tiebreaker, but gave it back with a double-fault for 3-3 and Shapovalov had his first match point when Nadal netted a backhand to fall behind at 4-6. Shapovalov won it with a forehand winner on the next point.\n\nphickey@postmedia.com", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {"liCnt": 6}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T03:53:00Z", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "source": {"uri": "montrealgazette.com", "title": "Montreal Gazette", "id": "2649"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:53:00", "url": "http://montrealgazette.com/sports/rogers-cup-denis-shapovalov-18-stuns-top-seed-rafael-nadal", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8531737", "image": "http://wpmedia.montrealgazette.com/2017/08/0811-spt-rogerscup4-8884.jpg?w=640", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "03:53:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarterfinals of the Montreal Masters Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute center court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said.\n\n\"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer advances to the semifinals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old left-handed Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him, I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said.\n\nFourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov became the youngest since 1990 when he reached the quarterfinals of the Masters 1000 event. -- AFP", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T03:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"uri": "saudigazette.com.sa", "title": "Saudi Gazette", "id": "5204"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:38:00", "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/514994/Sports/Roger-Federer", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8868246", "image": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/uploads/images/2017/08/12/461907.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "03:38:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"420299", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "2015 Rogers Cup"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Rogers_Cup", "score": 4, "id": "1437917", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL: Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters on Thursday after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set -- ending Federer's 32-set streak -- the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer levelled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France's Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T03:26:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"uri": "newindianexpress.com", "title": "The New Indian Express", "id": "934"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:26:00", "url": "http://www.newindianexpress.com/sport/tennis/2017/aug/11/roger-federer-into-montreal-quarters-as-david-ferrer-downed-again-1641599.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8528931", "image": "http://images.newindianexpress.com/uploads/user/imagelibrary/2017/8/11/w600X390/Montreal_Tennis_R.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "03:26:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Montreal,\" Federer said. \"Plus I feel comfortable at the net so why not spend some time up there instead of slugging it out from the baseline?\"\n\nFederer opened the second set with a break and cruised through the rest of the match, which lasted just over an hour.\n\nWith world No.2 Rafael Nadal eliminated on Thursday by 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov and world No.1 Andy Murray sidelined by a rib injury, Federer has an opportunity to regain the top spot.\n\nHe would need to win the Rogers Cup and have an equal or better finish than Nadal at the Western & Southern Open in Cincinnati next week to become the world No.1 on August 21.\n\n\"Now that Rafa is out I know I can make big strides, especially if I was to go further than the semis here,\" Federer said. \"But it's all connected to great play.\"\n\nFederer, who leads the ATP this season with five titles - including two grand slams - improved his 2017 record to 34-2 as he bids for a 94th career trophy. Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters on Thursday after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament. But while Ferrer managed to take the opening set - ending Federer's 32-set streak - the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set. Nowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4. But Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4. Federer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set. The set went with serve as Federer levelled. An early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response. The decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match. Federer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match\n\nSwiss star Roger Federer outclassed Roberto Bautista Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarterfinals of the Montreal Masters on Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 per cent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said.\n\n\"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer advances to the semifinals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him, I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said.\n\n\"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\"\n\nFourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov became the youngest since 1990 when he reached the quarter-finals of the Masters 1000 event.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T17:44:00Z", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "source": {"uri": "khaleejtimes.com", "title": "khaleejtimes.com", "id": "17167"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:44:00", "url": "http://www.khaleejtimes.com/sport/federer-flies-into-montreal-semis", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8824521", "image": "http://www.khaleejtimes.com/storyimage/KT/20170812/ARTICLE/170819711/AR/0/AR-170819711.jpg&NCS_modified=  &imageversion=1by1&exif=.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "17:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

teenager Denis Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world number one.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov, who needed a wildcard to get into the tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday.\n\nNadal would have returned to No 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov on Thursday, and then Chung Hyeon or Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tie-breaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute centre court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set - ending Federer's 32-set streak - the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself a set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer leveled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France's Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.\n\nResults on Thursday in the ATP Montreal Masters (x-denotes seeded player):\n\nThird round\n\nDenis Shapovalov (CAN) bt Rafael Nadal (ESP x1) 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4)\n\nRoger Federer (SUI x2) bt David Ferrer (ESP) 4-6, 6-4, 6-2\n\nRobin Haase (NED) bt Grigor Dimitrov (BUL x7) 7-6 (7/3), 4-6, 6-1\n\nDiego Schwartzman (ARG) bt Jared Donaldson (USA) 0-6, 7-5, 7-5\n\nRoberto Bautista (ESP) bt Gael Monfils (FRA) 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2)\n\nAdrian Mannarino (FRA) bt Hyeon Chung (KOR) 6-3, 6-3\n\nAlexander Zverev (GER x4) bt Nick Kyrgios (AUS x16) 6-4, 6-3\n\nKevin Anderson (RSA) bt Sam Querrey (USA) 6-4, 6-1", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T04:57:00Z", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "source": {"uri": "sport24.co.za", "title": "SPORT24", "id": "976"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:57:00", "url": "http://www.sport24.co.za/Tennis/ATPTour/nadal-stunned-by-canadian-teenager-20170811", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8539568", "image": "http://cdn.24.co.za/files/Cms/General/d/1340/7a6a6cd93621425d9397f0adf319b281.gif", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "04:57:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nTitle for Federer, tears for Cilic in one-sided Wimbledon final\n\nFederer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65% of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMontreal Masters: Nadal stunned by teenager Shapovalov\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him, I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T13:42:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "title": "The Express Tribune", "id": "1929"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:42:00", "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/1480047/montreal-masters-dominant-federer-fires-semis/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8798946", "image": "https://c.tribune.com.pk/2017/08/1480047-federer-1502545119-314-640x480.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "13:42:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"body": "The 18-year-old left-hander from Richmond Hill, Ontario beat France's Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 and will face fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany on Saturday.\n\nShapovalov beat 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round and then knocked off the top-seeded Nadal in a third-set tiebreaker on Thursday in the round of 16.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third set Friday only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\n\"I've been against the wall a couple times this week and I'm very happy I've come out several times just playing really good tennis in those situations,\" Shapovalov said. \"I think it really shows how I've improved mentally, along with just finding my game at the right moments.\"\n\nAfter facing a run of veterans, he will be up against the 20-year-old Zverev, who beat Kevin Anderson of South Africa 7-5, 6-4.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. The 36-year-old Swiss will next face unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase, a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer has won all seven career matches and taken all 16 sets against the 29-year-old Bautista Agut.\n\nHe is 1-0 against Haase after a straight-sets win in Davis Cup play in 2012.\n\nFederer said he knows Haase well from serving with him on the ATP player council and from practicing together.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to a tough match because he can serve very well and he mixes up his tactics a lot,\" Federer said. \"Sometimes he tends to just roll the ball in and use the big serve, or he uses a slice a lot and comes in.\n\n\"So I don't quite know with Robin what I'm going to get. But, as I have practiced with him quite a bit, maybe I am better prepared than if I would have never hit with him before.\"\n\nFederer broke serve for a 5-4 lead in the first set and broke again for 2-1 in the second en route to the victory in a little more than an hour. Federer was coming off a three-set win over another Spaniard, David Ferrer, against whom he is 17-0.\n\n\"My game plan worked better against Bautista Agut than against Ferrer,\" he said. \"I believe it's because I was more aggressive coming to the net.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, reached his first career Masters Series semifinal. The 30-year-old Haase, back to 52nd in the world after battling injuries for much of his career, improved to 5-0 against 36th-ranked Schwartzman.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially against Dimitrov,\" said Haase. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level.\n\n\"I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T09:40:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "sports.abs-cbn.com", "title": "ABS-CBN SPORTS", "id": "6300"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:40:00", "url": "http://sports.abs-cbn.com/tennis/news/2017/08/12/federer-canadian-teen-shapovalov-reach-semis-montreal-29649", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8772426", "image": "http://data-sports.abs-cbn.com/dev/articles/1502528373_photo-250x250-federer-ao-nishikori.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "09:40:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Montreal Masters on Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 or 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said. \"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nREAD | Denis Shapovalov's dream comes true after shock win vs Rafael Nadal in Montreal\n\nBautista Agut struggled mightily on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and boosted his season record to 34-2. He has a Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nREAD | Karolina Pliskova into Rogers Cup quarterfinals, Venus Williams bows out\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title of the season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his dream run in the tournament with a 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 win over Adrian Mannarino.\n\nThe other quarter-final saw Germany's Alexander Zverev beat Kevin Anderson of South Africa 7-5, 6-4.\n\nREAD | Andy Murray ruled out of Cincinnati Masters with hip injury\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said. \"I was not as fast. Roger Federer says, 'he had a good start, I had a better finish.' Photo by Glyn Kirk/AFP\n\nMONTREAL, Canada - Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarterfinals of the ATP Montreal Masters on Thursday, August 10 (Friday, August 11, Manila time), after a 3-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set - ending Federer's 32-set streak - the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start; I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the 7th game, when he squandered 3 break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer levelled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the 7th game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarterfinals. final.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will clash on Sunday with German Alexander Zverev who ended the Cinderella run of 18-year old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 win in the other semi-final.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 3, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Roberto Bautista Agut, left, and Roger Federer shake hands after their Rogers Cup quarter-final at the Uniprix Stadium in Montreal, Quebec, on Friday.\n\nSwiss star Roger Federer outclassed Roberto Bautista Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup on Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first-serve points in the 68-minute center court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said. \"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer faces Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his Cinderella run on Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4. Mannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. He served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him, I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career, but said he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said. \"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\"\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years,\" he said. \"I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\"\n\nFourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov became the youngest since 1990 when he reached the quarter-finals of the Masters 1000 event.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T17:08:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"uri": "taipeitimes.com", "title": "Taipei Times", "id": "3289"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:08:00", "url": "http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/sport/archives/2017/08/13/2003676435", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8821041", "image": "http://www.taipeitimes.com/images/2017/08/13/thumbs/P11-170813-315.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "17:08:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"Passing shot"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passing_shot", "score": 3, "id": "1341894", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Watch as Denis Shapovalov wins the tie break to beat world number-one Rafael Nadal and move on at the Rogers Cup.\n\nDenis Shapovalov came into the Rogers Cup as the 143rd-ranked player in the world, and with his 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4) win against one of the all-time greats in Rafael Nadal moved up to No. 100.\n\nThe Richmond Hill, Ont., native did it in front of 11,000 screaming fans, who packed Stade Uniprix to the brim and rose to their feet with every passing shot he managed.\n\nTo know that Shapovalov dictated play for the majority of the two hours and 46 minutes he was on centre court for, notching 49 winners to Nadal's 18, is to know that this 18-year-old kid is more than just a flash in the pan.\n\nOn Wednesday, Roger Federer, the most dominant athlete tennis has ever seen, shared his thoughts on what it takes for a young up-and-comer to become a champion.\n\n\"You have to like being at the centre of attention,\" the world No. 3 and owner of 19 Grand Slams said in French. \"You have to think it's not a bad thing to have people talking about you. You have to welcome being on centre court, to play against the best players and prove yourself. You can't be scared of those moments.\"\n\nIt was clear right from the start of Thursday's match that Shapovalov was anything but overwhelmed by the situation. He wasn't just there to participate against one of his childhood idols. He was there to win.\n\nShapovalov stood toe-to-toe with one of tennis' biggest sluggers, absorbed every blow, and he kept moving forward.\n\nWhen he was asked how he felt after the match, he smiled and said, \"I feel tired. I want to go to sleep.\"\n\nConsider it rest well-earned.\n\nShapovalov established himself early on in the match, opening up the court with his crossing backhand, finishing off points with forehands down the line. There was no sign of intimidation; no doubt he could handle this situation.\n\nBut his serve, which zinged in regularly at over 200 km/h, was broken in the fifth game of the match, and his spirit could've easily followed when the first set went to Nadal.\n\nBut in the 38th minute of play, Shapovalov stepped to the baseline and started the comeback that could very well change the trajectory of his career. He held serve easily and wound up a windmill fist pump after breaking Nadal to go up 2-0, en route to taking the second set in roughly 40 minutes.\n\nWhat followed in the third-and-deciding set was one of the greatest displays of will a Canadian has ever shown at this event.\n\nServing at 1-1, Shapovalov fought through 10 deuce points, saved four consecutive break points, and prevailed in a 26-point, 14-and-a-half-minute marathon of a game.\n\nAt 2-2 he saved another three break points and held on to take the lead.\n\nService holds were exchanged until Shapovalov kicked off the first point of the tiebreak.\n\nNadal took the first three points. A nervous hush filled the stadium.\n\nBut Shapovalov battled back to 3-3, and at 4-4 the blond-haired, blue-eyed wonder smashed a serve 216 km/h down the centre line and picked up his ninth ace of the match.\n\nTwo points later he became the lowest-ranked player to beat the Spaniard since Nick Kyrgios (ranked 144th at the time) took him at Wimbledon in 2014.\n\n\"I'm not happy to be part of this story,\" said Nadal, just minutes after leaving the court. \"Probably the worst loss of the year, without a doubt, for me.\"\n\nThe 31-year-old was two wins away from recapturing No. 1 in the world -- a ranking he's owned on three separate occasions, but one he hasn't had since 2014. It was unimaginable he'd be stopped in his tracks by a player who had just 10 matches of experience on the ATP World Tour prior to this tournament.\n\n\"It's what I dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa, Roger, Andy [Murray],\" said Shapovalov. \"My dream came true today.\"\n\nA new pursuit begins Friday, when Shapovalov faces France's Andrian Mannarino in the quarter-final.\n\nRegardless of how he fares, his arrival on tennis' biggest stage has been noted.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T05:15:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"uri": "sportsnet.ca", "title": "Sportsnet", "id": "1184"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:15:00", "url": "http://www.sportsnet.ca/tennis/atp/shapovalov-shoots-star-status-win-time-great-nadal/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8541382", "image": "http://assets1.sportsnet.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Denis_Shapovalov3.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "05:15:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

turned in a precision performance on Saturday (Sunday in Manila) at the ATP Montreal tennis, using thundering serves and clever backhands to defeat unseeded Robin Haase for a spot in the final.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will clash on Sunday with German Alexander Zverev who ended the Cinderella run of 18-year old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 win in the other semi-final.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nThe 19-time Grand Slam winner Federer is seeking his 27th Masters 1000 title and his third Canadian Masters crown after wins in 2004 and 2006.\n\nHaase, who hit 17 winners, made a late charge and forced a second-set tiebreak before Federer stymied the challenge to win the match.\n\nZverev, 20, will have a much tougher time against the skilled veteran Federer than he did in beating Shapovalov.\n\nAFP", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T11:10:00Z", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "title": "Manila Times", "id": "1062"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:10:00", "url": "http://www.manilatimes.net/resurgent-federer-advances-montreal-final/344226/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8906402", "image": "http://14255-presscdn-0-60.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/federer20170814-300x200.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "11:10:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"Diego Schwartzman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 2, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Canada's Denis Shapovalov advanced to the Rogers Cup semifinals with a 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 victory over France's Adrian Mannarino on Friday night.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont., was coming off a second-round win over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro and a thrilling three-set upset of top-seeded tennis legend Rafael Nadal in the Round of 16.\n\nShapovalov will next meet the winner of a match later Friday between fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany and Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nThe 29-year-old Mannarino had knocked out Canada's top player, Milos Raonic, in the second round, although the big-server from Thornhill, Ont., played with a swollen wrist.\n\nShapovalov started out looking low on energy despite the encouragement of the packed centre court crowd.\n\nHe double-faulted on break point in the opening game en route to a quick first-set loss.\n\nThe two lefthanders were on serve in the second when play halted 20 minutes for a light rain but the crowd sprang to life, chanting 'let's go Denis' on the changeovers as he broke serve and then served out the set.\n\nAs it was against Nadal, Shapovalov spent much of the match alternating between errors and impressive winners, consistently fighting off break points on his serve. He had nine aces and seven double faults.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\nSecond-seeded Roger Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. The 36-year-old Swiss will next face unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase, a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer has won all seven career matches and taken all 16 sets against the 29-year-old Bautista Agut.\n\nHe is 1-0 against Haase -- a straight-sets win in Davis Cup play in 2012.\n\nFederer said he knows Haase well from serving with him on the ATP player council and from practising together.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to a tough match because he can serve very well and he mixes up his tactics a lot,\" said Federer. \"Sometimes he tends to just roll the ball in and use the big serve, or he uses a slice a lot and comes in.\n\n\"So I don't quite know with Robin what I'm going to get. But, as I have practised with him quite a bit, maybe I am better prepared than if I would have never hit with him before.\"\n\nFederer broke serve for a 5-4 lead in the first set and broke again for 2-1 in the second en route to a one hour eight minute win over Bautista Agut. Federer was coming off a three-set win over another Spaniard, David Ferrer, against whom he is 17-0.\n\n\"My game plan worked better against Bautista Agut than against Ferrer,\" he said. \"I believe it's because I was more aggressive coming to the net.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, reached his first career Masters Series semifinal. The 30-year-old Haase, back to 52nd in the world after battling injuries for much of his career, improved to 5-0 against 36th-ranked Schwartzman.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially against Dimitrov,\" said Haase. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level.\n\n\"I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:05:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "nationalpost.com", "title": "National Post", "id": "973"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:30:00", "url": "http://nationalpost.com/pmn/sports-pmn/dutchman-haase-tops-schwartzman-to-reach-rogers-cup-semifinals/wcm/df3f3c6b-3f4f-4097-acae-bf948dd8ac93", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8729826", "image": "http://1.gravatar.com/blavatar/bf69214e83fdd5520e4b5d91ba3b7d64?s=200&ts=1502501447", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:05:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Major_League_Baseball_single-game_grand_slam_leaders", "score": 2, "id": "1358229", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Roger Federer has reached the Rogers Cup semi-finals after coming to the net early and often in a straight-sets victory over Roberto Bautista Agut on a windy day in Montreal.\n\nWorld No.3 Federer, who faces Dutchman Robin Haase in the last four, was never seriously pushed in the 6-4 6-4 win against his Spanish opponent, who is winless in seven matches against the Swiss maestro.\n\n\"I think it pays off playing aggressive here in Montreal,\" Federer said.\n\n\"Plus I feel comfortable at the net so why not spend some time up there instead of slugging it out from the baseline?\"\n\nFederer opened the second set with a break and cruised through the rest of the match, which lasted just over an hour.\n\nWith world No.2 Rafael Nadal eliminated on Thursday by 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov and world No.1 Andy Murray sidelined by a rib injury, Federer has an opportunity to regain the top spot.\n\nHe would need to win the Rogers Cup and have an equal or better finish than Nadal at the Western & Southern Open in Cincinnati next week to become the world No.1 on August 21.\n\n\"Now that Rafa is out I know I can make big strides, especially if I was to go further than the semis here,\" Federer said.\n\n\"But it's all connected to great play.\"\n\nFederer, who leads the ATP this season with five titles - including two grand slams - improved his 2017 record to 34-2 as he bids for a 94th career "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 2, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canada's Denis Shapovalov advanced to the Rogers Cup semifinals with a 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 victory over France's Adrian Mannarino on Friday night.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont., was coming off a second-round win over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro and a thrilling three-set upset of top-seeded tennis legend Rafael Nadal in the Round of 16.\n\nShapovalov will next meet the winner of a match later Friday between fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany and Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nThe 29-year-old Mannarino had knocked out Canada's top player, Milos Raonic, in the second round, although the big-server from Thornhill, Ont., played with a swollen wrist.\n\nShapovalov started out looking low on energy despite the encouragement of the packed centre court crowd.\n\nHe double-faulted on break point in the opening game en route to a quick first-set loss.\n\nThe two lefthanders were on serve in the second when play halted 20 minutes for a light rain but the crowd sprang to life, chanting 'let's go Denis' on the changeovers as he broke serve and then served out the set.\n\nAs it was against Nadal, Shapovalov spent much of the match alternating between errors and impressive winners, consistently fighting off break points on his serve. He had nine aces and seven double faults.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\nSecond-seeded Roger Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. The 36-year-old Swiss will next face unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase, a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer has won all seven career matches and taken all 16 sets against the 29-year-old Bautista Agut.\n\nHe is 1-0 against Haase - a straight-sets win in Davis Cup play in 2012.\n\nFederer said he knows Haase well from serving with him on the ATP player council and from practising together.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to a tough match because he can serve very well and he mixes up his tactics a lot,\" said Federer. \"Sometimes he tends to just roll the ball in and use the big serve, or he uses a slice a lot and comes in.\n\n\"So I don't quite know with Robin what I'm going to get. But, as I have practised with him quite a bit, maybe I am better prepared than if I would have never hit with him before.\"\n\nFederer broke serve for a 5-4 lead in the first set and broke again for 2-1 in the second en route to a one hour eight minute win over Bautista Agut. Federer was coming off a three-set win over another Spaniard, David Ferrer, against whom he is 17-0.\n\n\"My game plan worked better against Bautista Agut than against Ferrer,\" he said. \"I believe it's because I was more aggressive coming to the net.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, reached his first career Masters Series semifinal. The 30-year-old Haase, back to 52nd in the world after battling injuries for much of his career, improved to 5-0 against 36th-ranked Schwartzman.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially against Dimitrov,\" said Haase. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level.\n\n\"I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {"liCnt": 5}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:46:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "id": "1409"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:46:00", "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/tennis/shapovalovs-magic-run-continues-as-canadian-teen-reaches-rogers-cup-semifinals/article35976057/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8730865", "image": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/41e/sports/tennis/article35976056.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/web-sp-te-men-0811.JPG", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

to defeat unseeded Robin Haase for a spot in the final.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\nA RIDICULOUS running backhand pass from @rogerfederer \u1f44c\u1f525\n\nWatch LIVE \u1f4fa: https://t.co/kRsZ9udpkC pic.twitter.com/DlkJUtDs39\n\n-- Tennis TV (@TennisTV) August 12, 2017\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will clash on Sunday with German Alexander Zverev who ended the Cinderella run of 18-year old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 win in the other semi-final.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nThe 19-time Grand Slam winner Federer is seeking his 27th Masters 1000 title and his third Canadian Masters crown after wins in 2004 and 2006.\n\nHaase, who hit 17 winners, made a late charge and forced a second-set tiebreak before Federer stymied the challenge to win the match.\n\nZverev, 20, will have a much tougher time against the skilled veteran Federer than he did in beating Shapovalov.\n\nZverev came into Montreal with four titles this season while Shapovalov had just three career match victories. Shapovalov leaves Montreal with seven career wins, including a shocking upset of 10-time French Open champion Rafael Nadal.\n\n\"It is a completely life-changing week,\" said Shapovalov, whose dream run this week also included a win over former US Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro.\n\nThe fourth seeded Zverev broke Shapovalov at 4-4 in the first set then served for the set to silence the partisan crowd.\n\nUltimately, Zverev played better in the key moments, finishing with two aces, winning 81 percent of his first-serve points and breaking the Canadian three times.\n\nShapovalov finished with three aces, six double faults and won 64 percent of his first-serve points in the one-hour, 43-minute match.\n\nAFP\n\nLike us on Facebook\n\nFollow us on Twitter", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 1078, "textStart": 1063}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T08:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "iol.co.za", "title": "IOL", "id": "1546"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:17:00", "url": "https://www.iol.co.za/sport/tennis/resurgent-federer-advances-to-montreal-final-10769225", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8889307", "image": "https://image.iol.co.za/image/1/process/620x349?source=http://ana-baobab-prod-eu-west-2.s3.amazonaws.com/public/ana/media/media/2017/08/12/1502571892599.jpg&operation=CROP&offset=0x39&resize=4329x2424", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "08:17:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Roger Federer turned in a precision performance Saturday at the ATP Montreal tennis, using thundering serves and clever backhands to defeat unseeded Robin Haase for a spot in the final.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will clash on Sunday with German Alexander Zverev who ended the Cinderella run of 18-year old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 win in the other semi-final.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nThe 19-time Grand Slam winner Federer is seeking his 27th Masters 1000 title and his third Canadian Masters crown after wins in 2004 and 2006.\n\nHaase, who hit 17 winners, made a late charge and forced a second-set tiebreak before Federer stymied the challenge to win the match.\n\nZverev, 20, will have a much tougher time against the skilled veteran Federer than he did in beating Shapovalov.\n\n'Life-changing week'\n\nZverev came into Montreal with four titles this season while Shapovalov had just three career match victories. Shapovalov leaves Montreal with seven career wins, including a shocking upset of 10-time French Open champion Rafael Nadal.\n\n\"It is a completely life-changing week,\" said Shapovalov, whose dream run this week also included a win over former US Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro.\n\nThe fourth seeded Zverev broke Shapovalov at 4-4 in the first set then served for the set to silence the partisan crowd.\n\nUltimately, Zverev played better in the key moments, finishing with two aces, winning 81 percent of his first-serve points and breaking the Canadian three times.\n\nShapovalov finished with three aces, six double faults and won 64 percent of his first-serve points in the one-hour, 43-minute match.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T06:47:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "sports.inquirer.net", "title": "sports.inquirer.net", "id": "3860"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:47:00", "url": "http://sports.inquirer.net/260332/roger-federer-tennis-atp-can-montreal-alexander-zverev-canada-robin-haase", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8881387", "image": "http://sports.inquirer.net/wp-content/blogs.dir/2/files/2017/08/063_830818086.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "06:47:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said. \"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. "uri": "706433653", "lang": "eng", "title": "Canadian Denis Shapovalov's potential front and centre at Rogers Cup - Sportsnet.ca", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "Brazil"}, "type": "loc", "score": 4, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Brazil"}, "type": "country"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazil", "id": "30"}, {"label": {"eng": "Canada"}, "type": "loc", "score": 4, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Canada"}, "type": "country"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada", "id": "37"}, {"label": {"eng": "Montreal"}, "type": "loc", "score": 5, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Montreal"},
