"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_(biology)", "score": 4, "id": "303765", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rog\u00e9rio Dutra Silva"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rog\u00e9rio_Dutra_Silva", "score": 4, "id": "310210", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "National Hockey League"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League", "score": 2, "id": "315690", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Glossary of tennis terms"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_tennis_terms", "score": 2, "id": "323035", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Wayne Gretzky"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayne_Gretzky", "score": 5, "id": "351623", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sportsnet"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sportsnet", "score": 3, "id": "377839", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL - It's not a matter of \"if,\" it's more a matter of \"when\" everything is going to come together for Canada's Denis Shapovalov.\n\nIf Tuesday's win over Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva is any indication, that time could arrive much sooner than anyone could've predicted.\n\nNot that a 4-6, 7-6, 6-4 win over the 64th best player in the world in his opening-round match at the Rogers Cup was a guarantee Shapovalov is ready to prevail over anyone and everyone on tennis' top circuit. It's going to take time - and much more experience - for the youngest player ranked in the top 150 in the world to climb his way up to the pinnacle of the sport.\n\nBut the will the 18-year-old displayed - saving four match points in the second set before earning a service break at 3-3 in the third and putting his foot on the gas pedal to close out the match - is a sign he has what it takes to one day become a champion.\n\nWayne Gretzky is a believer.\n\nOne of the greatest hockey players of all time brought his family to Montreal to spend some time with Shapovalov, and he stuck around to cheer him on in Tuesday's match.\n\n\"I think he has ice in his veins,\" Gretzky told the Sportsnet on-site panel. \"I think he's one of those guys who's going to love the pressure and take on that responsibility.\"\n\nOn centre court, in front of family, friends, the Gretzkys and a stadium full of Canadian tennis fans, Shapovalov showed it.\n\n\"It's great to have guys like this around my matches watching me, keeping an eye out for me\" he said.\n\nShapovalov took to the surface wearing a red shirt, blue shorts and white sneakers with blue laces, and it wasn't long before he was striping the lines yellow with serves north of 200 km/h, top-spinning forehands and thunderous one-handed backhands.\n\nIf there was one thing the lefty made clear with his performance, it's that he oozes talent. His 12 aces and 38 winners in Tuesday's two-hour, 26-minute session were a testament to the fact.\n\nHowever there were moments when Shapovalov's inexperience got the better of him. For example, he broke Dutra Silva early in the first set but then he gifted the break right back in the very next game - at love, no less - with some curiously aggressive shots that found their way outside the lines.\n\nLater on he had the advantage of serving to open the second-set tiebreak and blew the first point with a loose shot that landed beyond the opposing baseline. It was one of 47 unforced errors he made.\n\nHe then deepened the hole by netting two forehands to give Dutra Silva his first two match points.\n\nBut he contrasted those undisciplined moments with a confidence that bordered on arrogance, stepping into the court on nearly every shot and upping the pace on his groundstrokes in moments that might have summoned conservatism from someone else.\n\n\"I play as aggressive as possible,\" Shapovalov said.\n\nGretzky outlined what's behind that style of play.\n\n\"I think the biggest thing of all is, first of all, you have to have the confidence in yourself and I think you have to believe in yourself that you can be successful,\" said the NHL's all-time leading goal-scorer and point-getter.\n\nNone of that was lacking on Shapovalov's side of the court, in spite of the fact that he served at 50 per cent for the match and admittedly struggled to find his best game throughout.\n\n\"I thought I could win the whole time,\" he said. \"I mean, I never lost faith.\"\n\nThe Richmond Hill, Ont., native knows he'll have to bring that confidence to the court on Wednesday, with a 2:30pm start scheduled against the world's No. 31 player in Argentina's Juan Martin Del Potro.\n\n\"I have to play really well,\" said Shapovalov. \"It's going to be an extremely tough match. But I live for these moments. I live to be in these matches.\"\n\nThere's reason to believe it won't be long before this kid is on the winning side of most of those matches.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-09T00:37:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "sportsnet.ca", "title": "Sportsnet", "id": "1184"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:37:00", "url": "http://www.sportsnet.ca/tennis/canadian-denis-shapovalovs-potential-front-centre-rogers-cup/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8087566", "image": "http://assets3.sportsnet.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/shapovalov_denis1280.jpg", "date": "2017-08-09", "time": "00:37:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-09"}

Roberto Bautista Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarter-finals of the Montreal Masters on Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said.\n\nRoger Federer celebrates his victory over Roberto Bautista Agut during quarterfinal. AP\n\n\"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by World No 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said. \"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\"\n\nFourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov is the youngest since 1990 to reach a Masters 1000 quarter-final.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 12, 2017 10:00 am | Updated Date: Aug 12, 2017 10:00 am\n\nTags :#Adrian mannarino#Alexander zverev#Atp masters#Denis shapovalov#Masters 1000#Rafael nadal#Roberto bautista-agut#Robin haase#Roger federer#Sportstracker#Tennis", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 3563, "textStart": 3551, "freq": 2}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T04:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "title": "Firstpost", "id": "2530"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:38:00", "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/sports/montreal-masters-roger-federer-sets-up-semi-final-against-robin-haase-denis-shapovalov-continues-dream-run-3921489.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8743964", "image": "http://s2.firstpost.in/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Roger-Federer-1024.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "04:38:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

career meeting between the two.\n\nSwiss star Roger Federer outclassed Roberto Bautista Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarter-finals of the Montreal Masters on Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said.\n\n\"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said. \"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\"\n\nFourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov is the youngest since 1990 to reach a Masters 1000 quarter-final.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T04:12:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "title": "The Hindu", "id": "241"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:12:00", "url": "http://www.thehindu.com/sport/tennis/montreal-atp-masters-cup-tennis-tournament-federer-punches-ticket-to-montreal-semis/article19479250.ece", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8741741", "image": "http://www.thehindu.com/sport/tennis/article19479249.ece/ALTERNATES/LANDSCAPE_615/Roger%20Federer", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "04:12:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Donaldson", "score": 1, "id": "1339257", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov delighted his home fans when he battled from a set down to record a stunning upset victory over top seed Rafael Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday.\n\nThe lanky wild card kissed the Montreal court after completing a rousing 3-6 6-4 7-6(4) triumph as the 18-year-old became the youngest player to ever reach the quarter-finals of an ATP Masters 1000 event.\n\nThe early exit also denied world number two Nadal a chance to take over from the absent Andy Murray at the top of the rankings, a position the Spaniard would have regained for the first time since 2014 had he advanced to the semi-finals.\n\nShapovalov showed no sign of nerves in their first ever meeting, the left-hander playing the more aggressive tennis by utilising his huge forehand on roundhouse swings and frequently attacking the net.\n\nThe teenager's quixotic bid looked doomed in the third set tiebreaker when he fell 3-0 behind but the world number 143 refused to buckle and only coughed up one more point in the decider.\n\nAs a reward for his unlikely victory, the 2016 Wimbledon junior champion will next face 29-year-old Frenchman Adrian Mannarino in the quarter-finals on Friday.\n\nREAD: Nadal, Federer win opening matches at Rogers Cup\n\nElsewhere, world number three Roger Federer dropped his first set since June but the Swiss recovered to dispatch Spaniard David Ferrer 4-6 6-4 6-2 in their last 16 meeting.\n\nFederer was sloppy from the outset on centre court, sending routine forehands wide and providing the underdog Ferrer with early break opportunities in the Montreal encounter.\n\nFerrer capitalised by winning the opener to end Federer's streak of 32 consecutive sets won, a record that dates back to his defeat to Tommy Haas at the Stuttgart Open on June 14.\n\n\"He had a good start, I had a better finish,\" Federer told reporters after the match.\n\nFrustration boiled over for the Australian Open and Wimbledon champion in the second set after he misfired with an overhead smash.\n\nFederer, who turned 36 this week, responded by hitting a ball into the stands, earning a reprimand but no official ball abuse call from the umpire.\n\nThe outburst appeared to steady the Swiss, whose serve and overall accuracy improved as the two-hour match progressed.\n\nFerrer has now lost all of his 17 contests against Federer, who is also vying to take the world number one spot from the injured Murray.\n\nNext up for Federer is a quarter-final against 12th-seeded Spaniard Roberto Bautista Agut, who defeated Frenchman Gael Monfils 4-6 7-6(5) 7-6(2) in a marathon tussle.\n\nIn other tournament action, American Jared Donaldson lost to Diego Schwartzman 0-6 7-5 7-5, while his countryman Sam Querrey was thrashed 6-4 6-1 by Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nAustralian Nick Kyrgios fell 6-4 6-3 to fourth seed Alexander Zverev as the German finally claimed victory over his opponent in their third meeting of the season.\n\n(Reporting by Rory Carroll in Los Angeles; Editing by John O'Brien)\n\nFor more sports coverage, visit He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two. The pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nDream run\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night. Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. He also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said, adding, \"When I broke him I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again\".\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" he said. \"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better. I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will clash on Sunday with German Alexander Zverev who ended the Cinderella run of 18-year old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 win in the other semi-final.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. Shapovalov leaves Montreal with seven career wins, including a shocking upset of 10-time French Open champion Rafael Nadal.\n\n\"It is a completely life-changing week,\" said Shapovalov, whose dream run this week also included a win over former US Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro.\n\nThe fourth seeded Zverev broke Shapovalov at 4-4 in the first set then served for the set to silence the partisan crowd.\n\nUltimately, Zverev played better in the key moments, finishing with two aces, winning 81 percent of his first-serve points and breaking the Canadian three times.\n\nShapovalov finished with three aces, six double faults and won 64 percent of his first-serve points in the one-hour, 43-minute match.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T06:22:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"uri": "digitaljournal.com", "title": "digitaljournal.com", "id": "556"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:22:00", "url": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/tennis-resurgent-federer-advances-to-montreal-final/article/499877", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8879216", "image": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/img/1/0/4/8/0/9/3/i/3/5/2/p-large/cd9e7b0b64058de58f543f7d45066018bd48398f.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "06:22:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

everything went Rafael Nadal's way. Not only did he win, but all of the accomplished players in his section of the draw went out to less-accomplished ones. On Thursday something like that happened on the other half of the draw. The result is that #Roger Federer has now picked up what should be a routine draw to the 2017 Rogers Cup final in Montreal.\n\nFirstly, Federer did his part on Thursday as he defeated David Ferrer. The line score in that match was 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 with the Spaniard at least getting Federer's attention in the match. Ferrer had won Bastad on clay a little while ago so there may be something in his game right now that has been absent for a couple of years.\n\nBut Federer improved to 17-0 against the Spaniard in booking a quarter-final spot in Montreal with ambitions of winning the title this weekend.\n\n\"I already beat other players 17 times,\" said Federer after the match. \"Sometimes I played them maybe 30 or 40 times. They ended up beating me at a certain stage, like Roddick, Gonzalez, and Soderling. Sometimes I beat them ten times in a row. In the end, they always ended up beating me. That's why I have a lot of respect for this match today. I know it can't continue that way. 17 is a lot\" (qtd. at the ATP's website).\n\nGael Monfils went out in Federer's half, meaning that the Swiss Maestro will next face Roberto Bautista-Agut. That's another Spaniard that just hasn't been able to solve Federer in the past. In six previous matches not only is Bautista-Agut 0-6, but he is winless in all sets played (14 sets to love).\n\nBautista-Agut's last match against Federer was not one sided as he took Federer to two tiebreakers back in Miami. He'll be looking to make things competitive again as he looks like the last player that might keep Federer from the final.\n\nShould Federer advance to the semifinals, then he would face either Diego Schwartzman or Robin Haase. The former took out third-seeded Dominic Thiem earlier this week. Meanwhile the latter upset Grigor Dimitrov on Thursday. Neither Schwartzman nor Haase has ever beaten Federer in four compiled matches. That means that the players remaining in Federer's path to the final are 0-10 against the Swiss.\n\nThey are also 1-24 in sets played against him, an egregious compiled record between them. The three of them combined have played 25 sets against Federer with just Schwartzman managing to win a set against the current World No. 3. The two tiebreakers that Bautista-Agut forced earlier this year, both won by Federer, are the only ones to be played in the 25 sets. tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set - ending Federer 32-set streak - the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away early breaks to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to hold to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake with his second set point, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer however responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the break opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer levelled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand return to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarterfinals. "MONTREAL - Canada's Denis Shapovalov advanced to the Rogers Cup semifinals with a 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 victory over France's Adrian Mannarino on Friday night.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont., was coming off a second-round win over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro and a thrilling three-set upset of top-seeded tennis legend Rafael Nadal in the Round of 16.\n\nShapovalov will next meet the winner of a match later Friday between fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany and Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nStory continues below\n\nThe 29-year-old Mannarino had knocked out Canada's top player, Milos Raonic, in the second round, although the big-server from Thornhill, Ont., played with a swollen wrist.\n\nREAD MORE: Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov upsets Rafael Nadal at Rogers Cup\n\nShapovalov started out looking low on energy despite the encouragement of the packed centre court crowd.\n\nHe double-faulted on break point in the opening game en route to a quick first-set loss.\n\nThe two lefthanders were on serve in the second when play halted 20 minutes for a light rain but the crowd sprang to life, chanting 'let's go Denis' on the changeovers as he broke serve and then served out the set.\n\nAs it was against Nadal, Shapovalov spent much of the match alternating between errors and impressive winners, consistently fighting off break points on his serve. He had nine aces and seven double faults.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\nWATCH ABOVE: Canadian teen Denis Shapovalov stuns Rafael Nadal at Rogers Cup\n\nSecond-seeded Roger Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. The 36-year-old Swiss will next face unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase, a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer has won all seven career matches and taken all 16 sets against the 29-year-old Bautista Agut.\n\nHe is 1-0 against Haase -- a straight-sets win in Davis Cup play in 2012.\n\nFederer said he knows Haase well from serving with him on the ATP player council and from practising together.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to a tough match because he can serve very well and he mixes up his tactics a lot,\" said Federer. \"Sometimes he tends to just roll the ball in and use the big serve, or he uses a slice a lot and comes in.\n\n\"So I don't quite know with Robin what I'm going to get. But, as I have practiced with him quite a bit, maybe I am better prepared than if I would have never hit with him before.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Shapovalov downs Del Potro at Rogers Cup\n\nFederer broke serve for a 5-4 lead in the first set and broke again for 2-1 in the second en route to a one hour eight minute win over Bautista Agut. Federer was coming off a three-set win over another Spaniard, David Ferrer, against whom he is 17-0.\n\n\"My game plan worked better against Bautista Agut than against Ferrer,\" he said. \"I believe it's because I was more aggressive coming to the net.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, reached his first career Masters Series semifinal. The 30-year-old Haase, back to 52nd in the world after battling injuries for much of his career, improved to 5-0 against 36th-ranked Schwartzman.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially against Dimitrov,\" said Haase. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level.\n\n\"I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"uri": "globalnews.ca", "title": "Global News", "id": "501"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:50:00", "url": "http://globalnews.ca/news/3664934/canadas-denis-shapovalov-advances-to-semifinals-after-downing-mannarino/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8731183", "image": "https://shawglobalnews.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/pch138420042_high.jpg?quality=70&strip=all&w=650&h=414&crop=1", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:50:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada", "id": "37"}, {"label": {"eng": "Spain"}, "type": "loc", "score": 3, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Spain"}, "type": "country"}, "uri": "Juan Mart\u00edn del Potro"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart\u00edn_del_Potro", "score": 3, "id": "305581", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rog\u00e9rio Dutra Silva"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rog\u00e9rio_Dutra_Silva", "score": 3, "id": "310210", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Roger Federer"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer", "score": 3, "id": "311098", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "ATP World Tour Masters 1000"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Masters_1000", "score": 1, "id": "337716", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Backhand"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backhand", "score": 2, "id": "374056", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Canadian Open (tennis)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Open_(tennis)", "score": 3, "id": "379384", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Adrian Mannarino"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Mannarino", "score": 1, "id": "405343", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Forehand"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forehand", "score": 2, "id": "420299", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Lleyton Hewitt"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt", "score": 3, "id": "518403", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Denis Shapovalov didn't appear to run from one corner of the court to the other so much as fling himself there. He broke many of the cardinal rules of execution against No. 2 seed Rafael Nadal, including hitting off his back foot and unloading while falling backward. Nevertheless, the rockets he fired kept flying true and landing for glowing winners. Individual beads of perspiration dripped from strands of long white-blond hair streaming from the back of his cap, which of course was worn backward.\n\nAn homage to Lleyton Hewitt, whom he resembles in so many ways? Not really. Shapovalov is 18 years old, and the unwritten rule is that you have to wear the hat that way until at least 21.\n\nThe Canadian pulled off an upset for the ages on a sultry Thursday night at the Rogers Cup in Montreal. He knocked out Nadal in every sense of the term, halting the reconstructed Spaniard's drive to reclaim the No. 1 ranking. It was an utterly unexpected result, and Shapovalov reacted exactly the same way all kids his age do after accomplishing something of that magnitude. He said he grew up dreaming of playing the likes of Nadal and Roger Federer, and announced, \"You know, my dream came true today.\"\n\nWas this a preview of Shapovalov's future, or a one-off event that will make good fodder for the grandchildren?\n\nTrue, the Russian-born teenager (he was a one when his family moved to Canada) was lucky to escape four match points in his first-round contest against Rogerio Dutra Silva. But he backed up that escape with an upset of former Grand Slam champion Juan Martin del Potro. The way he mastered Nadal suggests that Shapovalov isn't likely to pinch himself on Friday and discover that he really had been dreaming all along.\n\nShapovalov cracked 49 winners in the see-sawing, two-hour and 45 minute match that ended in a tiebreaker (3-6, 6-4, 7-6 [4]). His lefty serve was effective against his fellow southpaw, brutally so at times. He kept Nadal off balance with his serve selection and hit nine aces to Nadal's two.\n\nShapovalov's shot selection and execution was bold and unrestrained throughout. He knew he needed to take big cuts at every ball that afforded the opportunity. That's an easy task to set, but a difficult one to execute. But Shapovalov trusted his game (including his sizzling one-handed backhand), even on those occasions when he found himself dangling precariously on the brink of the abyss. Instead of waiting to be rescued, he pulled himself out hand-over-hand.\n\n\"It's so tough [to play Nadal],\" Shapovalov told reporters after the match. \"A lot of the times he just hits a shot that's way too good. I was managing to get a lot back when I could. But you could tell why he has won so many Grand Slams. His ball was just so heavy. He's such a warrior out there.\"\n\nBut Nadal was no more a warrior than his Canadian opponent, who was down 0-3 in the decisive tiebreaker. Shapovalov reeled off seven of the next eight points and fittingly ended the match with a forehand blast that Nadal couldn't even lunge for.\n\n\"I wish him the best,\" Nadal told reporters after the match. \"He has everything to become a great player. He played with the right determination in the important moments.\"\n\nAt 18 and three months, Shapovalov became the youngest-ever quarterfinalist in a top-tier ATP Masters 1000 event. Ranked No. 143 at the start of the event, he is projected to crack the top 100 and could jump into the mid 60s if he wins his next match against No. 42 ranked Frenchman Adrian Mannarino. It's an easily conceivable scenario.\n\nShapovalov's win adds to the proliferating number of signs that suggest a fleet of young players (collectively known as the #NextgenATP) is ready to push out the old guard.\n\nEverywhere you turn these days, a 21-and-under player seems to be counting coup on a respected veteran. At this tournament alone, seeds David Goffin, Richard Gasquet, and Lucas Pouille were taken out by Shapovalov's peers.\n\nThe current transition might even be over before Shapovalov tries wearing his ball cap bill forward.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T16:26:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "title": "ESPN.com", "id": "4"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:26:00", "url": "http://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/20312787", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8660099", "image": "http://a4.espncdn.com/combiner/i?img=%2Fphoto%2F2017%2F0811%2Fr242725_1296x729_16%2D9.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "16:26:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Donaldson", "score": 1, "id": "1339257", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov delighted his home fans when he battled from a set down to record a stunning upset victory over top seed Rafael Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday.\n\nThe lanky wild card kissed the Montreal court after completing a rousing 3-6 6-4 7-6(4) triumph as the 18-year-old became the youngest player to ever reach the quarter-finals of an ATP Masters 1000 event.\n\nThe early exit also denied world number two Nadal a chance to take over from the absent Andy Murray at the top of the rankings, a position the Spaniard would have regained for the first time since 2014 had he advanced to the semi-finals.\n\nShapovalov showed no sign of nerves in their first ever meeting, the left-hander playing the more aggressive tennis by utilising his huge forehand on roundhouse swings and frequently attacking the net.\n\nThe teenager's quixotic bid looked doomed in the third set tiebreaker when he fell 3-0 behind but the world number 143 refused to buckle and only coughed up one more point in the decider.\n\nAs a reward for his unlikely victory, the 2016 Wimbledon junior champion will next face 29-year-old Frenchman Adrian Mannarino in the quarter-finals on Friday.\n\nElsewhere, world number three Roger Federer dropped his first set since June but the Swiss recovered to dispatch Spaniard David Ferrer 4-6 6-4 6-2 in their last 16 meeting.\n\nFederer was sloppy from the outset on centre court, sending routine forehands wide and providing the underdog Ferrer with early break opportunities in the Montreal encounter.\n\nFerrer capitalised by winning the opener to end Federer's streak of 32 consecutive sets won, a record that dates back to his defeat to Tommy Haas at the Stuttgart Open on June 14.\n\n\"He had a good start, I had a better finish,\" Federer told reporters after the match.\n\nFrustration boiled over for the Australian Open and Wimbledon champion in the second set after he misfired with an overhead smash.\n\nFederer, who turned 36 this week, responded by hitting a ball into the stands, earning a reprimand but no official ball abuse call from the umpire.\n\nThe outburst appeared to steady the Swiss, whose serve and overall accuracy improved as the two-hour match progressed.\n\nFerrer has now lost all of his 17 contests against Federer, who is also vying to take the world number one spot from the injured Murray.\n\nNext up for Federer is a quarter-final against 12th-seeded Spaniard Roberto Bautista Agut, who defeated Frenchman Gael Monfils 4-6 7-6(5) 7-6(2) in a marathon tussle.\n\nIn other tournament action, American Jared Donaldson lost to Diego Schwartzman 0-6 7-5 7-5, while his countryman Sam Querrey was thrashed 6-4 6-1 by Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nAustralian Nick Kyrgios fell 6-4 6-3 to fourth seed Alexander Zverev as the German finally claimed victory over his opponent in their third inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarter-finals of the Montreal Masters. Federer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points. \"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said.\n\n\"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\" Federer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day. Bautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points. \"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017. He will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two. The pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4. Federer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4. Mannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian. Shapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game. \"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman. Haase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place. \"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said. \"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\" Fourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov. He's the youngest player to reach the third round of this event since Mats Wilander in 1982.\n\nSwiss tennis maestro Roger Federer in action at the Rogers Cup in Montreal. Photo: The Canadian Press via APDenis Shapovalov returns to Rafael Nadal at the Rogers Cup. Photo: The Canadian Press via AP\n\nCanadian teenager Denis Shapovalov delighted his home fans when he battled from a set down to record a stunning upset victory over top seed Rafael Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday.\n\nThe lanky wild card kissed the Montreal court after completing a rousing 3-6 6-4 7-6(4) triumph as the 18-year-old became the youngest player to ever reach the quarter-finals of an ATP Masters 1000 event.\n\nThe early exit also denied world number two Nadal a chance to take over from the absent Andy Murray at the top of the rankings, a position the Spaniard would have regained for the first time since 2014 had he advanced to the semi-finals.\n\nShapovalov showed no sign of nerves in their first ever meeting, the left-hander playing the more aggressive tennis by utilising his huge forehand on roundhouse swings and frequently attacking the net.\n\nThe teenager's quixotic bid looked doomed in the third set tiebreaker when he fell 3-0 behind, but the world number 143 refused to buckle and only coughed up one more point in the decider.\n\nAs a reward for his unlikely victory, the 2016 Wimbledon junior champion will next face 29-year-old Frenchman Adrian Mannarino in the quarter-finals on Friday.\n\nElsewhere, world number three Roger Federer dropped his first set since June, but the Swiss recovered to dispatch Spaniard David Ferrer 4-6 6-4 6-2 in their last 16 meeting.\n\nFederer was sloppy from the outset on centre court, sending routine forehands wide and providing the underdog Ferrer with early break opportunities in the Montreal encounter.\n\nFerrer capitalised by winning the opener to end Federer's streak of 32 consecutive sets won, a record that dates back to his defeat to Tommy Haas at the Stuttgart Open on June 14.\n\n\"He had a good start, I had a better finish,\" Federer told reporters after the match.\n\nFrustration boiled over for the Australian Open and Wimbledon champion in the second set after he misfired with an overhead smash. Federer, who turned 36 this week, responded by hitting a ball into the stands, earning a reprimand, but no official ball abuse call from the umpire.\n\nThe outburst appeared to steady the Swiss, whose serve and overall accuracy improved as the two-hour match progressed.\n\nFerrer has now lost all of his 17 contests against Federer, who is also vying to take the world number one spot from the injured Murray.\n\nNext up for Federer is a quarter-final against 12th-seeded Spaniard Roberto Bautista Agut, who defeated Frenchman Gael Monfils 4-6 7-6(5) 7-6(2) in a marathon tussle.\n\nIn other tournament action, American Jared Donaldson lost to Diego Schwartzman 0-6 7-5 7-5, while his countryman Sam Querrey was thrashed 6-4 6-1 by Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nAustralian Nick Kyrgios fell 6-4 6-3 to fourth seed Alexander Zverev as the German finally claimed victory over his opponent in their third meeting of the season.\n\nAnderson will now face Zverev in the quarter-finals.\n\nReuters", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-06-14", "textEnd": 1921, "textStart": 1914}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T13:07:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"uri": "iol.co.za", "title": "IOL", "id": "1546"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:07:00", "url": "https://www.iol.co.za/sport/tennis/canadian-teen-stuns-nadal-sas-anderson-marches-on-10743973", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8619989", "image": "https://image.iol.co.za/image/1/process/620x349?source=http://ana-baobab-prod-eu-west-2.s3.amazonaws.com/public/ana/media/media/2017/08/11/1502415387792.jpg&operation=CROP&offset=0x0&resize=4429x2480", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "13:07:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"Swiss star Roger Federer outclassed Roberto Bautista Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarter- finals of the Montreal Masters.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said.\n\n\"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\" Federer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\" Haase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said.\n\n\"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\" Fourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov is the youngest since 1990 to reach a Masters 1000 quarter-final.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T04:50:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"uri": "dnaindia.com", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "id": "492"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:50:00", "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-federer-punches-ticket-to-montreal-semis-2527551", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8744875", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "04:50:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

World number three Federer, who faces Dutchman Robin Haase in the last four, was never seriously pushed by Spain's Bautista Agut, who is winless in seven matches against the Swiss maestro.\n\n\"I think it pays off playing aggressive here in Montreal,\" Federer said in a courtside interview after his 6-4 6-4 win over the 12th seed. \"Plus I feel comfortable at the net so why not spend some time up there instead of slugging it out from the baseline?\"\n\nFederer opened the second set with a break and cruised through the rest of the match, which lasted just over an hour. With world number two Rafael Nadal eliminated on Thursday by 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov and world number one Andy Murray sidelined by a rib injury, Federer has an opportunity to regain his world number one ranking.\n\nHe would need to win the Rogers Cup and have an equal or better finish than Nadal at the Western & Southern Open in Cincinnati next week to become the world number one on Aug. 21.\n\n\"Now that Rafa is out I know I can make big strides, especially if I was to go further than the semis here. "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Diego Schwartzman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 3, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL - Swiss star Roger Federer outclassed Roberto Bautista Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4 6-4 win in the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup on Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said.\n\n\"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6 6-3 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has an ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two. The pair met in a Davis Cup World Group playoff in 2012, with Federer winning 6-1 6-4 6-4.\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world number 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run on Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6 6-3 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old left-handed Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. He also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin del Potro in the second round.\n\nThe Canadian teenager started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, he broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. He served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"When I broke him, I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nFourth-seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world, and Shapovalov became the youngest since 1990 when he reached the quarter-finals of the Masters 1000 event.\n\nSealed with an ace! \u1f4aa\n\nMake it 8 straight wins for Alexander Zverev and he's into the #CoupeRogers SF. pic.twitter.com/4F5Lo7XhpU\n\n-- Tennis TV (@TennisTV) August 12, 2017\n\nAFP", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 3089, "textStart": 3074}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T07:46:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"uri": "iol.co.za", "title": "IOL", "id": "1546"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:46:00", "url": "https://www.iol.co.za/sport/tennis/federer-storms-into-semis-but-anderson-goes-down-in-montreal-10755957", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8760350", "image": "https://image.iol.co.za/image/1/process/620x349?source=http://ana-baobab-prod-eu-west-2.s3.amazonaws.com/public/ana/media/media/2017/08/11/1502485416787.jpg&operation=CROP&offset=0x0&resize=4353x2437", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "07:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Rogers Cup semi-final victory over Robin Haase of Netherlands, at Uniprix Stadium in Montreal, Quebec, on August 12, 2017 \u00a9 GETTY/AFP / Minas Panagiotakis\n\nMONTREAL, Canada, Aug 13 - Swiss superstar Roger Federer turned in a precision performance on Saturday at the ATP Montreal tennis, using thundering serves and clever backhands to defeat unseeded Robin Haase for a spot in the final.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\nRobin Haase of Netherlands reacts after losing a point against Roger Federer of Switzerland during their ATP Rogers Cup semi-final match, at Uniprix Stadium in Montreal, Quebec, on August 12, 2017 \u00a9 GETTY/AFP / Minas Panagiotakis\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will meet either German Alexander Zverev or young Canadian Denis Shapovalov in Sunday's final where he will be seeking his sixth title of 2017.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nThe 19-time Grand Slam winner Federer is seeking his 27th Masters 1000 title and his third Canadian Masters crown after wins in 2004 and 2006.\n\nHaase, who hit 17 winners, made a late charge and forced a second-set tiebreak before Federer stymied the challenge to win the match.\n\nShares", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 186, "textStart": 171, "freq": 2}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 246, "textStart": 240}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T10:56:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"uri": "capitalfm.co.ke", "title": "Capital News", "id": "333"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:29:00", "url": "http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/13/resurgent-federer-advances-atp-montreal-masters-final/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8908348", "image": "http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/files/2017/08/85abce68a2f4c18c91b5b0f6aaab9fa99e76e07e.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "10:56:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Montreal tennis, using thundering serves and clever backhands to defeat unseeded Robin Haase for a spot in the final.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\nRoger Federer reacts after winning the first set against Robin Haase in their semi-final. AP\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will meet either German Alexander Zverev in Sunday's final where he will be seeking his sixth title of 2017.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nThe 19-time Grand Slam winner Federer is seeking his 27th Masters 1000 title and his third Canadian Masters crown after wins in 2004 and 2006.\n\nHaase, who hit 17 winners, made a late charge and forced a second-set tiebreak before Federer stymied the challenge to win the match.\n\nFourth seed Zverev advanced to the final with a 6-4, 7-5 win over Canada's Denis Shapovalov.\n\nFederer owns a 2-1 edge against Zverev in head-to-head meetings, most recently a 6-1 6-3 win at Halle in June.\n\nZverev ended Shapovalov's magical week on his third match point when the 18-year-old, who had been the story of the tournament after a stunning run that included an upset win over world number two Rafael Nadal, sent a backhand wide.\n\nShapovalov, who was born in Israel and moved to Canada before his first birthday, had a great chance at 4-3 in the second set but failed to convert on his three break points.\n\n\"I wasn't too sharp on the big points,\" said Shapovalov, who made headlines in February for inadvertently blasting a ball into an umpire's face in a fit of rage during a Davis Cup quarter-final.\n\n\"I had a couple looks at some second serves and I missed some returns. But at the end of the day he did a good job to make me play those points.\"\n\nWith inputs from agencies\n\nPublished Date: Aug 13, 2017 10:15 am | Updated Date: Aug 13, 2017 10:24 am\n\nTags :#Alexander zverev#Atp#Denis shapovalov#Final#Montreal masters#Robin haase#Roger cup#Roger federer#Semi-finals#Sportstracker#Tennis", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 3220, "textStart": 3208, "freq": 2}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T05:02:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "title": "Firstpost", "id": "2530"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:02:00", "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/sports/montreal-masters-roger-federer-advances-to-final-alexander-zverev-ends-denis-shapovalovs-run-3924815.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8873898", "image": "http://s2.firstpost.in/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Rogers-Cup-Roger-Federer-firstpump-AP1.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "05:02:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Roger Federer outclassed Roberto Bautista Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarter-finals of the Montreal Masters on Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81 percent of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said.\n\n\"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nFederer advances to the semi-finals where he will face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nRobin Haase of the Netherlands chases the ball during his ATP Rogers Cup quarter-final match against Diego Schwartzman of Argentina, at Uniprix Stadium in Montreal, Canada, on August 11, 2017 \u00a9 GETTY/AFP / Minas Panagiotakis\n\nBautista Agut struggled on his serve as he was broken three times and won just 65 percent of his first serve points.\n\n\"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well,\" he said. \"Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\"\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nHe will face Dutchman Haas in just the second career meeting between the two.\n\nThe pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nDenis Shapovalov of Canada celebrates after scoring a point against Adrian Mannarino of France during their ATP Rogers Cup quarter-final match, at Uniprix Stadium in Montreal, on August 11, 2017 \u00a9 GETTY/AFP / Minas Panagiotakis\n\nFederer's chances of winning another title this season were given a boost when top seed Rafael Nadal was upset by world No. 143 Denis Shapovalov of Canada on Thursday night.\n\nShapovalov, who needed a wild card to gain entry into the tournament, continued his cinderella run Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old lefthanded Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n- Shapovalov rolls on -\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him, I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said.\n\n\"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\"\n\nFourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov became the youngest since 1990 when he reached the quarter-finals of the Masters 1000 event.\n\nShares", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 184, "textStart": 169, "freq": 4}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T08:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"uri": "capitalfm.co.ke", "title": "Capital News", "id": "333"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:59:00", "url": "http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/12/federer-punches-ticket-atp-montreal-masters-semis/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8768266", "image": "http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/files/2017/08/e04d9d2728dcda8734f2f7ac250e0aa55a3be5cb.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "08:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

to the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters on Thursday after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set, the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nA strangely error-prone Federer was unable to generate his usual fluency early on, and quickly found himself giving away an early break to trail 4-1 in the first set.\n\nNowhere was Federer's wayward performance better illustrated than in the seventh game, when he squandered three break points at 0-40 to allow Ferrer to take a 5-2 lead.\n\nFederer held for 5-3 and looked to have clawed his way back into the set with a break of Ferrer's serve in the next game to make it 5-4.\n\nBut Federer was struggling again as he served to level the set, finding himself set point down. He saved the first with an ace but Ferrer made no mistake later in the game, converting to take the opener 6-4.\n\nFederer responded quickly in the second set, going a break up to lead 3-2 before holding for a 4-2 lead.\n\nWith Federer slowly improving his first serve, Ferrer was unable to carve out the opportunities he had found in the first set.\n\nThe set went with serve as Federer levelled.\n\nAn early break in the decider put him in control as a weary Ferrer began to tire.\n\nSome vintage play at the net helped put Federer 4-2 up with Ferrer seemingly unable to summon a response.\n\nThe decisive break came in the seventh game, with Ferrer netting a forehand to leave Federer 5-2 up and serving for the match.\n\nFederer promptly went in for the kill, attacking the net and opening up the court to clinch victory with a deft volley.\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. record a stunning upset victory over top seed Rafael Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday.\n\nThe lanky wild card kissed the Montreal court after completing a rousing 3-6 6-4 7-6(4) triumph as the 18-year-old became the youngest player to ever reach the quarterfinals of an ATP Masters 1000 event.\n\nThe early exit also denied world number two Nadal a chance to take over from the absent Andy Murray at the top of the rankings, a position the Spaniard would have regained for the first time since 2014 had he advanced to the semifinals.\n\nShapovalov showed no sign of nerves in their first ever meeting, the left-hander playing the more aggressive tennis by utilising his huge forehand on roundhouse swings and frequently attacking the net.\n\nThe teenager's quixotic bid looked doomed in the third set tiebreaker when he fell 3-0 behind but the world number 143 refused to buckle and only coughed up one more point in the decider.\n\nAs a reward for his unlikely victory, the 2016 Wimbledon junior champion will next face 29-year-old Frenchman Adrian Mannarino in the quarterfinals on Friday.\n\nElsewhere, world number three Roger Federer dropped his first set since June but the Swiss recovered to dispatch Spaniard David Ferrer 4-6 6-4 6-2 in their last 16 meeting.\n\nFederer was sloppy from the outset on centre court, sending routine forehands wide and providing the underdog Ferrer with early break opportunities in the Montreal encounter.\n\nFerrer capitalised by winning the opener to end Federer's streak of 32 consecutive sets won, a record that dates back to his defeat to Tommy Haas at the Stuttgart Open on June 14.\n\n\"He had a good start, I had a better finish,\" Federer told reporters after the match.\n\nFrustration boiled over for the Australian Open and Wimbledon champion in the second set after he misfired with an overhead smash.\n\nFederer, who turned 36 this week, responded by hitting a ball into the stands, earning a reprimand but no official ball abuse call from the umpire.\n\nThe outburst appeared to steady the Swiss, whose serve and overall accuracy improved as the two-hour match progressed.\n\nFerrer has now lost all of his 17 contests against Federer, who is also vying to take the world number one spot from the injured Murray.\n\nNext up for Federer is a quarterfinal against 12th-seeded Spaniard Roberto Bautista Agut, who defeated Frenchman Gael Monfils 4-6 7-6(5) 7-6(2) in a marathon tussle.\n\nIn other tournament action, American Jared Donaldson lost to Diego Schwartzman 0-6 7-5 7-5, while his countryman Sam Querrey was thrashed 6-4 6-1 by Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nAustralian Nick Kyrgios fell 6-4 6-3 to fourth seed Alexander Zverev as the German finally claimed victory over his opponent in their third Rogers Cup title after triumphs in Toronto in 2004 and 2006.\n\nRoger Federer used a dominant service game to beat Dutchman Robin Haase 6-3 7-6(5) in Montreal on Saturday, setting up a Rogers Cup final against German Alexander Zverev.\n\nHaase, playing in his first ATP World Tour Masters 1000 semi-final, did well to force a second-set tiebreak but Federer proved too much to handle as the Swiss fired down nine aces and dropped only nine points on serve.\n\nFederer, whose five titles this year include the Australian Open and Wimbledon, credited a positive mindset for helping him extend his winning streak to 16 matches.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said the 19-times grand slam champion.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nNext up for the Swiss right-hander, who is seeking his third Rogers Cup title after triumphs in Toronto in 2004 and 2006, is Zverev after the fourth seed advanced with a 6-4 7-5 win over Canada's Denis Shapovalov.\n\nFederer owns a 2-1 edge against Zverev in head-to-head meetings, most recently a 6-1 6-3 win at Halle in June.\n\nZverev ended Shapovalov's magical week on his third match point when the 18-year-old, who had been the story of the tournament after a stunning run that included an upset win over world number two Rafael Nadal, sent a backhand wide.\n\nShapovalov, who was born in Israel and moved to Canada before his first birthday, had a great chance at 4-3 in the second set but failed to convert on his three break points.\n\n\"I wasn't too sharp on the big points,\" said Shapovalov, who made headlines in February for inadvertently blasting a ball into an umpire's face in a fit of rage during a Davis Cup quarter-final.\n\n\"I had a couple looks at some second serves and I missed some returns. Shapovalov shocked top seeded Rafael Nadal to reach the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters tournament, spoiling the Spaniard's chances of returning to world No 1. The 18-year-old Shapovalov, who needed a wild card to get into the tournament, continued his giant killing form at the hardcourt tournament by rallying to beat Nadal in three sets, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) on Thursday. Nadal would have returned to No. 1 in the world if he had defeated Shapovalov Thursday, and then Chung Hyeon or Adrian Mannarino on Friday.\n\nShapovalov's stunning upset against the reigning French Open champion came as a result of some inspired tennis in front of a boisterous home crowd who cheered his every shot.\n\nShapovalov had just three wins this season coming into the tournament. He quickly got on a roll in Montreal beating Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva in the opening round 4-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-4. He defeated former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round in straight sets 6-3 7-6 (7/4) to set up the showdown with Nadal.\n\nShapovalov won seven of the final eight points of the third set tiebreaker before closing out the match with a forehand winner down the line. He celebrated by falling onto his back then covering his face with his hands.\n\nShapovalov blasted a total of nine aces, including ones on his second serve that handcuffed Nadal. He also had seven double faults and won 67 percent of his first serve points.\n\nNadal won 77 percent of his first serve points but had just two aces and six double faults in the two hour, 45 minute center court match.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Roger Federer maintained his career-long winning streak over David Ferrer to advance to the quarter-finals after a three-set battle with the veteran Spaniard.\n\nFederer, 36, had never lost in 16 previous meetings with the 35-year-old Ferrer, whom he first defeated 14 years ago at the Vienna Indoor tournament.\n\nBut while Ferrer managed to take the opening set - ending Federer's 32-set streak - the Swiss ace raised his game to win 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David can play a lot better, too,\" Federer said. \"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. You know, he had a good start, I had a better finish.\"\n\nFederer will now play another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the quarter-finals. Bautista Agut defeated France's Gael Monfils in a gruelling slugfest, winning 4-6, 7-6 (7/5), 7-6 (7/2).\n\n\"I hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David,\" Federer said.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T03:20:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"uri": "sports.ndtv.com", "title": "NDTVSports.com", "id": "3506"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:19:00", "url": "https://sports.ndtv.com/tennis/top-seed-rafael-nadal-shocked-by-canadian-teen-denis-shapovalov-in-montreal-1736311", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8548891", "image": "https://i.ndtvimg.com/i/2017-08/rafael-nadal-montreal-masters-afp_806x605_41502428666.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "03:20:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}
