attacking the net.\n\nThe teenager's quixotic bid looked doomed in the third set tiebreaker when he fell 3-0 behind but the world number 143 refused to buckle and only coughed up one more point in the decider.\n\nAs a reward for his unlikely victory, the 2016 Wimbledon junior champion will next face 29-year-old Frenchman Adrian Mannarino in the quarter-finals on Friday.\n\nElsewhere, world number three Roger Federer dropped his first set since June but the Swiss recovered to dispatch Spaniard David Ferrer 4-6 6-4 6-2 in their last 16 meeting.\n\nFederer was sloppy from the outset on centre court, sending routine forehands wide and providing the underdog Ferrer with early break opportunities in the Montreal encounter.\n\nFerrer capitalised by winning the opener to end Federer's streak of 32 consecutive sets won, a record that dates back to his defeat to Tommy Haas at the Stuttgart Open on June 14.\n\n\"He had a good start, I had a better finish,\" Federer told reporters after the match.\n\nFrustration boiled over for the Australian Open and Wimbledon champion in the second set after he misfired with an overhead smash.\n\nFederer, who turned 36 this week, responded by hitting a ball into the stands, earning a reprimand but no official ball abuse call from the umpire.\n\nThe outburst appeared to steady the Swiss, whose serve and overall accuracy improved as the two-hour match progressed.\n\nFerrer has now lost all of his 17 contests against Federer, who is also vying to take the world number one spot from the injured Murray.\n\nNext up for Federer is a quarter-final against 12th-seeded Spaniard Roberto Bautista Agut, who defeated Frenchman Gael Monfils 4-6 7-6(5) 7-6(2) in a marathon tussle.\n\nIn other tournament action, American Jared Donaldson lost to Diego Schwartzman 0-6 7-5 7-5, while his countryman Sam Querrey was thrashed 6-4 6-1 by Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nAustralian Nick Kyrgios fell 6-4 6-3 to fourth seed Alexander Zverev as the German just 68 minutes on Friday to advance to the semifinals of the Rogers Cup at Montreal.\n\nFederer rolled to a 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Spaniard to move closer to winning his sixth ATP title of the season.\n\nFederer, who is 34-2 this year, will meet Dutchman Robin Haase in the semis. Haase outlasted Argentina's Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 in his quarterfinal match.\n\nFederer controlled the action at the net, winning 21 of 25 points, while cruising past Bautista Agut.\n\n\"It pays off playing aggressively here in Montreal, plus I feel comfortable at net, so why not spend some time there instead of slugging it out from the baseline,\" Federer said in a post-match television interview. \"I think I did a good job again, even though it was tough to control the ball. I got some decent rhythm going.\"\n\nBautista Agut battled Federer closely in the first set before the Swiss picked up at the pace to win it. Federer held the edge in the second set but Bautista Agut was able to hold his head high despite the outcome.\n\n\"I wanted to play a great tournament, and I think I did have a good week,\" Bautista Agut told reporters. \"Today, I felt that I didn't get into the rhythm of the match and I didn't feel the ball well. Roger plays very fast and he didn't want to rally with me, so he went for his shots.\n\n\"To be in the quarterfinals here in Montreal is a very good result for me, also getting hard-court matches under my belt.\"\n\nFederer will be facing Haase for the first time since a 2012 Davis Cup match.\n\nHaase improved to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman with his comeback after losing the opening set.\n\nHe also reminisced on his career, saying he finally is back in his comfort zone after being mentally drained by injuries that derailed his career.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said. \"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better, but actually your own body is not letting you. That took me, honestly, a couple of years to get more calm in my head, that I have to deal with it.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better. Then I started this year winning back-to-back matches against really good players. Then you're thinking, 'OK, it might happen again.' That it happens, it's just awesome.\"\n\nSchwartzman was dejected after being outplayed in the final two sets.\n\n\"The week for me was very good, but I am now disappointed as I don't think I played well in the second and third sets,\" Schwartzman said afterward. \"I didn't play too well from the baseline, but Haase served better to get back into the match.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:51:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"uri": "upi.com", "title": "UPI", "id": "149"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:51:00", "url": "https://www.upi.com/Sports_News/Tennis/2017/08/11/Rogers-Cup-Roger-Federer-cruises-into-semifinals/4871502502331/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8731272", "image": "https://cdnph.upi.com/ph/st/th/4871502502331/2017/upi/0396268fedc81dcbc49280f517a1b68f/v2.1/Rogers-Cup-Roger-Federer-cruises-into-semifinals.jpg?lg=4", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:51:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"Roger Federer of Switzerland celebrates his 6-3, 7-6 victory over Robin Haase of Netherlands during day nine of the Rogers Cup on August 12, 2017 in Montreal. -- AFP picMONTREAL, Aug 13 -- Swiss superstar Roger Federer turned in a precision performance yesterday at the ATP Montreal tennis, using thundering serves and clever backhands to defeat unseeded Robin Haase for a spot in the final.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will meet either German Alexander Zverev or young Canadian Denis Shapovalov in Sunday's final where he will be seeking his sixth title of 2017.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nThe 19-time Grand Slam winner Federer is seeking his 27th Masters 1000 title and his third Canadian Masters crown after wins in 2004 and 2006.\n\nHaase, who hit 17 winners, made a late charge and forced a second-set tiebreak before Federer stymied the challenge to win the match. -- AFP", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 145, "textStart": 130}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 185, "textStart": 179}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T04:22:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"uri": "themalaymailonline.com", "title": "themalaymailonline.com", "id": "661"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:22:00", "url": "http://www.themalaymailonline.com/sports/article/resurgent-federer-advances-to-montreal-final", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8871477", "image": "http://www.themalaymailonline.com/uploads/articles/2017/2017-08/federer_montreal_20170812AFP.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "04:22:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Reuters | Montreal | Published:August 13, 2017 9:20 am Roger Federer credited a positive mindset for helping him extend his winning streak to 16 matches. (Source: USA Today Sports) Aggressive Roger Federer cruises to semi-finals in MontrealTop-seeded Rafael Nadal goes down at Rogers Cup, Roger Federer advancesRafael Nadal opens Rogers Cup with easy win\n\nRoger Federer used a dominant service game to beat Dutchman Robin Haase 6-3 7-6(5) in Montreal on Saturday, setting up a Rogers Cup final against German Alexander Zverev.\n\nHaase, playing in his first ATP World Tour Masters 1000 semi-final, did well to force a second-set tiebreak but Federer proved too much to handle as the Swiss fired down nine aces and dropped only nine points on serve.\n\nFederer, whose five titles this year include the Australian Open and Wimbledon, credited a positive mindset for helping him extend his winning streak to 16 matches.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said the 19-times grand slam champion.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nNext up for the Swiss right-hander, who is seeking his third Rogers Cup title after triumphs in Toronto in 2004 and 2006, is Zverev after the fourth seed advanced with a 6-4 7-5 win over Canada's Denis Shapovalov.\n\nFederer owns a 2-1 edge against Zverev in head-to-head meetings, most recently a 6-1 6-3 win at Halle in June.\n\nZverev ended Shapovalov's magical week on his third match point when the 18-year-old, who had been the story of the tournament after a stunning run that included an upset win over world number two Rafael Nadal, sent a backhand wide.\n\nShapovalov, who was born in Israel and moved to Canada before his first birthday, had a great chance at 4-3 in the second set but failed to convert on his three break points.\n\n\"I wasn't too sharp on the big points,\" said Shapovalov, who made headlines in February for inadvertently blasting a ball into an umpire's face in a fit of rage during a Davis Cup quarter-final.\n\n\"I had a couple looks at some second serves and I missed some returns. But at the end of the day he did a good job to make me play those points.\"\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Roger Federer", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 50, "textStart": 35}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T04:01:00Z", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:01:00", "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/tennis/roger-federer-beats-robin-haase-meets-alexander-zverev-in-montreal-final-4794497/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8869862", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/08/federer-reuters-m1.jpg?w=759", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "04:01:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nShapovalov started slowly by dropping the first set before settling into the match in the second. After a rain delay, Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 4-2 lead in the second set. Her served out the set in the ninth game.\n\n\"It's tough to come out and serve after a 12-minute rain delay. I knew that was a very big turning point,\" Shapovalov said. \"When I broke him, I got that little bit of confidence, and I started believing in my shots again.\"\n\nHaase rallied after losing the opening set to improve to 5-0 all-time against Schwartzman.\n\nHaase has had to overcome several injuries in his career but says he is finally in a good place.\n\n\"I wasn't the player I was before my injury,\" Haase said.\n\n\"I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after. Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally. It drains you because you know you can do better.\n\n\"I've been working on it a lot in the past few years. I started to believe more and more again. My game is better.\"\n\nFourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov became the youngest since 1990 when he reached the quarterfinals of the Masters 1000 event.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T08:55:00Z", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "source": {"uri": "supersport.com", "title": "SuperSport official website", "id": "1756"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:55:00", "url": "https://www.supersport.com//tennis/article.aspx?Id=4097414", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8767785", "image": "https://images.supersport.com/2017/8/Roger-Federer-170809-ReturnBall-G-300.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "08:55:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

He has everything to become a great player.\"\n\nIt will be interesting to see how Shapovalov progesses. lose.\n\nThe list of legitimate challengers to Federer was reduced by one Thursday night when top-seeded Rafael Nadal was upset by 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov.\n\nWhen play started Friday, the second-seeded Federer had lost to only one of the surviving quarterfinalists -- Alexander Zverev. The fourth-seeded German has one win in three matches against the Swiss star.\n\nFederer eased into the semifinals of the $4.9-million Canadian Open men's tennis championships on Friday with a workmanlike 6-4, 6-4 win over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista-Agut of Spain.\n\nNext up is unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who said he was lucky to come back for a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 win over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer, who is playing his first tournament since winning his eighth Wimbledon title, struggled a bit at the beginning of his Thursday match against Spanish veteran David Ferrer and was forced to play three sets. But he seemed more composed Friday.\n\n\"I believe I served better earlier in the match, but I don't think Bautista-Agut returned as well as Ferrer,\" Federer said. \"Both things combined, two major factors in a beginning of a match, I was able to get into the match better. Of course, it was tough until 4-all. But my game plan worked better against Bautista-Agut than against Ferrer. I believe it's because today I was more aggressive coming to the net. It was more possible today. I was aggressive yesterday, but I couldn't carry it out because Ferrer had better momentum from the baseline. It made things more complicated for me.\"\n\nHaase and Schwartzman were both looking to reach their first semifinal in an ATP Masters 1000 event. Haase said it was difficult for both players after playing tough three-set matches against seeded players earlier in the week.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially yesterday against (seventh-seeded Grigor) Dimitrov,\" Haase said. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level. I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting. You could see that we were both mentally (tired). It took a lot out of us. We beat good guys. We've been playing really well. Then to do it on this stage again for your first semis, it's not easy.\"\n\nThe 30-year-old Haase said he always believed he could be competitive at this level, but he had to overcome a serious knee injury early in his career.\n\n\"I didn't even know if I could ever play tennis again,\" Haase said. \"After one-and-a-half years, I got back. I came back really fast, from zero to 60 in eight months. However, from that moment, I wasn't the player I was before my injury. I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after.\n\n\"Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally,\" he said. \"It drains you because you know you can do better, but actually your own body is not letting you. That took me, honestly, a couple of years to get more calm in my head, that I have to deal with it. \"\n\nphickey@postmedia.com\n\ntwitter.com/zababes1", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T22:19:00Z", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "source": {"uri": "montrealgazette.com", "title": "Montreal Gazette", "id": "2649"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:19:00", "url": "http://montrealgazette.com/sports/tennis/roger-federer-cruises-into-the-rogers-cup-semifinals", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8711365", "image": "http://wpmedia.montrealgazette.com/2017/08/830447654.jpg?w=640", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "22:19:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL: Swiss superstar Roger Federer turned in a precision performance Saturday at the ATP Montreal tennis, using thundering serves and clever backhands to defeat unseeded Robin Haase for a spot in the final.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer blasted nine aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he extended his match win streak to 16 -- his longest win streak in five years.\n\nHe raised his game to another level when it mattered most, beating Netherlands Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (7/5) in just 75 minutes.\n\n\"I'm very excited to be back in the finals,\" Federer said. \"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will meet either German Alexander Zverev or young Canadian Denis Shapovalov in Sunday's final where he will be seeking his sixth title of 2017.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. Cup.\n\nSugita, winner of the Antalya Open in July and currently ranked 46th in the world, managed to take the first set off the world No. 13 in the hard-court event at the Aviva Center, but made costly technical mistakes in the next two sets.\n\nSugita was unable to convert a single break point in the second set, when the best he could do was win the sixth game, while Goffin fired nine aces and capitalized on six of his 13 break-point chances in the 1 hour, 44 minute match.\n\n\"There was a big difference in the way we played in key situations,\" said Sugita.\n\n\"When I tried to be aggressive I made mistakes. "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Roger Federer continued his longest winning streak in five years by reaching the Rogers Cup final.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer used a 6-3, 7-6 (5) victory over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands yesterday to reach his sixth final of the year and win his 16th consecutive match.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me. If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away.\n\nSometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nFederer is looking for a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open beginning Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer has his longest winning streak since 2012. Next up is 20-year-old Alexander Zverev, who stopped Denis Shapovalov's impressive run with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the second semifinal.\n\nFederer has won of their three meetings, including a victory over the German on grass in June.\n\nShapovalov's tournament included consecutive wins over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro and top-seeded Spanish star Rafael Nadal. The victories, and the shaggy- haired youngster's style and skill on the court, announced his presence not only to Canadian fans but to the tennis world.\n\n\"My whole life has changed in the past five days,\" he said. \"It's crazy how it is.\n\n\"I mean, I go from being not known to being so known in the tennis world, in Canada in general. It's going to be a little bit of a change to me. I'm going to have to adapt. But that doesn't change things. I still have to work really hard every day.\"\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic, but Zverev was too strong, winning 81 percent of the points off his serve compared to 64 percent for Shapovalov.\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 1341, "textStart": 1334}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T07:02:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"uri": "business-standard.com", "title": "Business Standard", "id": "405"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:02:00", "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/federer-reaches-rogers-cup-final-117081300172_1.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8882624", "image": "http://bsmedia.business-standard.com/_media/bs/img/common/no_preview.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "07:02:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Le gamin avec la casquette rouge (Denis Shapovalov) a battu Nadal hier, 9 ans apr\u00e8s cette photo pic.twitter.com/pLxNLDqaOY --\n\n@PhotosHistos\n\nAfter Shapovalov, now 18, beat Adrian Mannarino of France in quarter-final action Friday night, he was asked about the photo.\n\nHe claims he didn't remember taking it until it began circulating on social media in the hours after his big win, but he remembers the day vividly.\n\nAs a young up-and-coming Canadian tennis player, he was supposed to play for five minutes before Nadal took the court, but the match before took so long there wasn't time.\n\n\"I was little bit bummed out because I thought Rafa was going to watch me play, you know, before his match,\" he said, laughing and eliciting chuckles from the reporters in the room.\n\nHe got his photo though, so it wasn't all bad.\n\nHe said he stuck around to watch the match and remembers how Igor Andreev, Nadal's opponent, rolled his ankle but still tried to battle it out, not unlike how Shapovalov himself has been powering through adversity this week. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 3, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "After knocking off world No. 2 Rafael Nadal at the Rogers Cup on Thursday night, all eyes are on the teenage tennis phenom from Richmond Hill\n\nThe \"burden of Canada\" that Eugenie Bouchard spoke of earlier in the week at the Rogers Cup has been placed squarely on the shoulders of Denis Shapovalov. The teenage tennis phenom seems to be handling the load just fine.\n\nWhile Bouchard was speaking of up-and-comers on the women's side of the draw, there is no question Shapovalov is this week carrying the torch for all Canadian tennis players - male and female - after his upset of world No. 2 Rafael Nadal in Thursday's round of 16 in Montreal. With Bouchard and leading Canadian men's player, Milos Raonic, both eliminated, it is safe to say all eyes are on Shapovalov.\n\nThe win Thursday makes the teenager from Richmond Hill, Ont., the youngest Masters series quarter-finalist of all time, and the youngest Rogers Cup quarter-finalist since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nAfter dropping the opening set to Nadal, who, with Andy Murray's withdrawal from the W&S Open next week could soon become world. No. 1, Shapovalov stormed back to win the second and third sets 6-4, 7-6 (4).\n\nIt was his second upset in as many days. On Wednesday, the 18-year-old knocked off former top-5 and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro. He'll face the Frenchman Adrian Mannarino, world No. 42, in Friday evening's contest. Mannarino defeated Raonic earlier in the tournament.\n\nAmong Shapovalov's supporters this week has been hockey great Wayne Gretzky and Canadian Olympic swimmer Penny Oleksiak. Gretzky has been courtside for all of Shapovalov's matches, and said he believes the Canadian left-hander has what it takes to be a superstar athlete.\n\n\"The great athletes want to be at centre stage. They want to play out here and be under that microscope,\" Gretzky said during a television broadcast. \"I think he has ice in his veins and I think he's one of those guys who's going to love the pressure and take on that responsibility.\"\n\nWho is Denis Shapovalov?Who is Denis Shapovalov?\n\nFor a thorough explanation, read Rachel Brady's profile from last summer. In a nutshell, he's Canada's next big thing. Last year he won the junior Wimbledon title before making a name for himself by offing the 11th-ranked, Australian Nick Kyrgios, in the round of 64 at last year's Rogers Cup.\n\nHe is the son of Tessa and Viktor Shapovalov, who moved to Canada from Tel Aviv the same year Denis was born.\n\nTessa runs an academy in Richmond Hill, which opened in 2012. It's where Shapovalov refined his skills after he making his way onto the Tennis Canada radar at age 9. By 13, it was clear he'd need a team around him to make it to the next level.\n\nIn 2015, he was Canada's U18 national outdoor champion, and by this time last year, he'd won three Futures titles.\n\nHe popped up on the radar again in for less desirable reasons in February, when he was fined $7, 000 for smashing a ball into the eye of umpire Arnaud Gabas during a decisive Davis Cup match, ultimately costing Canada a shot at victory over Great Britain.\n\nICYMI, Denis Shapovalov hits a ball out of anger that accidentally hits the chair umpire in the eye during @daviscup pic.twitter.com/ZBadhJmnww -- Tennis Channel (@TennisChannel)\n\nFebruary 7, 2017\n\nWhat are his chances?\n\nConsidering the kind of season Nadal is having (which, going by total points, is better than anyone's, even Roger Federer), then anything is possible.\n\nIn Mannarino, Shapovalov is facing a 29-year-old left-hander whose 2017 record is 17-18. Mannarino plays his best tennis on a grass surface, where he boasts a .567 win percentage. On hard courts, he's 7-9 on the season and 75-99 for his career.\n\nShapolvalov's ATP sample size is too small to be a barometer, he has posted a 27-5 record on hard surfaces between his appearances on the Futures and Challenge tours.\n\nPrior to Nadal, he had never faced another lefty at the ATP level. Mannarino's career record against southpaws, meanwhile, is 17-17.\n\nMORE FROM THE GLOBE AND MAIL", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-02-07", "textEnd": 3286, "textStart": 3270}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T14:29:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "id": "1409"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:48:00", "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/tennis/denis-shapovalov-rogers-cup/article35959187/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8640514", "image": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/381/sports/article35959235.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/Shapovalov7.JPG", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "14:29:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 5, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Denis Shapovalov pulled out another win and the crowd went nuts watching the Canadian sensation beat Adrian Mannarino.\n\nAt 18 years old, Denis Shapovalov has become one of the youngest players to ever reach the semifinals of a Masters 1000 event. And when you consider how that came to be, you have to think some higher power is in his corner.\n\nOn Tuesday, the youngest player in the draw at the Rogers Cup staved off four match points and pushed himself into the second round with a resilient win over Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva. On Wednesday, he was on the court asking to be pinched by TVA's Frederique Guay after beating one of his childhood idols, Juan Martin Del Potro, in straight sets. On Thursday, he was the author of one of the most iconic moments in Canadian tennis history, beating one of the best players of all time and world No. 2 Rafael Nadal.\n\nBut what Shapovalov did on Friday night, under the lights at Stade Uniprix, beating France's Andrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, was enough to make you believe in fate.\n\nIt looked like a train wreck out of the gate for the Richmond Hill, Ont., native. He was broken in both of his first two service games, he flubbed seven of eight volleys, and he airmailed more than his share of forehands into the crowd, en route to dropping the first set.\n\nMomentum was firmly on Mannarino's side when the skies opened up and light rain fell at centre court, causing a near 13-minute delay.\n\nCall it luck, or divine intervention, but that pause, at 2-2 in the second set, changed the complexion of the match entirely.\n\n\"I kind of told myself, 'This could be a really good turning point. It's giving him a little bit of time to think about his game.' He got a little bit cold. It's always tough to come out and serve after having 11, 12 minutes off,\" Shapovalov said afterwards.\n\nThe blustery wind that had, at least in part, caused Shapovalov to commit 16 unforced errors in the first set had all but died out when play resumed. His nerves calmed, his timing came together, and his opponent -- who had appeared unflappable to that point of the match -- booted his service game to give Shapovalov the lead and the momentum he wouldn't surrender until his hands were in the air in celebration of the win.\n\nIn reality -- though Shapovalov had shown his resilience in each of the previous rounds leading up to Friday's quarter-final -- the odds were stacked against him from the start.\n\nHe was the one who began the tournament as the 143rd-ranked player in the world, and beating anyone here -- including Mannarino (ranked 42) -- was going to be a crapshoot.\n\nAnd yet Shapovalov had come into the end-of-week session with external expectations heaped upon him for the first time all week. Within the span of 15 minutes, as Shapovalov fell down 4-0, the free-swinging, nothing-to-lose approach that had propelled him to orchestrate the two biggest upsets of his career had seemingly abandoned him upon the pre-match realization that this was his to win.\n\nShapovalov's coach, Martin Laurendeau, could see it coming. He attempted to ease the pressure on his player when he met with the media on Friday morning.\n\n\"Mannarino has been at this level for a number of years now, so it's going to be difficult for Denis,\" he said. \"You have to be aware that he's only 18 years old, and it's difficult mentally and physically to stay at that level.\"\n\nAnd it proved to be particularly difficult for Shapovalov against Mannarino, who tossed him a changeup after he had smashed fastballs from Del Potro and Nadal out of the ballpark.\n\nThe kid struggled against the Frenchman's counterpunching style. Seemingly every ball he striped found its way back to him, forcing him to push the envelope to win points. Impatience -- and his imprecision -- got the best of him. It looked like it was going to put his run in Montreal to an end.\n\nBut once again Shapovalov summoned something magical to dig his way out of the hole.\n\nIn the third and deciding set, after Mannarino held easily to start things off, Shapovalov had to stave off three break points to tie things up.\n\nMore adversity came when he surrendered a break directly after breaking Mannarino for a 3-2 lead.\n\nBut at 4-4, with Mannarino serving, Shapovalov returned to the well, won some gruellingly long rallies with the groundstrokes that have carried him to this point, earned two break points, and never looked back.\n\nHe served out the match with ease.\n\nNo matter what Shapovalov does on Saturday, this has already been the most successful week of his professional tennis career.\n\nBut if destiny has something to say about it, the kid who's moved up to No. 66 in the ATP rankings will have his crack at becoming the first Canadian champion at this event since 1958.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T04:02:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"uri": "sportsnet.ca", "title": "Sportsnet", "id": "1184"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:02:00", "url": "http://www.sportsnet.ca/tennis/victory-mannarino-latest-example-shapovalovs-destiny/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8740816", "image": "http://assets1.sportsnet.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Denis_ShapovalovQF.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "04:02:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

not spend some time up there instead of slugging it out from the baseline?\"\n\nFederer opened the second set with a break and cruised through the reest of the match, which lasted just over an hour.\n\nWith world number two Rafael Nadal eliminated on Thursday by 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov and world number one Andy Murray sidelined by a rib injury, Federer has an opportunity to regain his world number one ranking.\n\nHe would need to win the Rogers Cup and have an equal or better finish than Nadal at the Western &amp; Southern Open in Cincinnati next week to become the world number one on Aug. 21.\n\n\"Now that Rafa is out I know I can make big strides, especially if I was to go further than the semis here. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Kyrgios", "score": 4, "id": "350450", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Martin Laurendeau"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Laurendeau", "score": 4, "id": "1048441", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Denis Shapovalov's coach wasn't surprised that the teenager was able to keep his head while upsetting a tennis legend on centre court at the Rogers Cup.\n\nMartin Laurendeau said Friday that he saw it a year ago when Shapovalov beat Australian star Nick Kyrgios in the Rogers Cup first round in Toronto and the 18-year-old's cool head was evident again this week with wins over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro and former world No.1 Rafael Nadal.\n\n\"All the guys he's played up to, he takes it to them,\" said Laurendeau, who coaches Shapovalov and serves as Canada's Davis Cup captain. \"He revels in that kind of atmosphere.\n\n\"He's like a fish in water when you put him on a big court against a big player. I don't know if you can teach that, but he has that and he's making the most of it.\"\n\nShapovalov, of Richmond Hill, Ont., posted one of the biggest wins in Canadian tennis history when he battled Nadal for two hours 45 minutes on Thursday night and pulled out the victory in a third-set tiebreaker. It was a back-and-forth match, with several break points saved on both sides. Shapovalov fell behind 3-0 in the tiebreaker, but a Nadal double fault and two aces gave the youngster the match.\n\nAt no time did the left-hander show any sign of cracking under the pressure. Instead, he fed off the deafening sound from the sellout crowd of 11,000 that cheered every point he won.\n\n\"It's a bit surreal to be able to, start to finish, last that long, produce quality tennis and go toe-to-toe with a legend like that,\" said Laurendeau. \"It's just remarkable.\n\n\"I'm glad I was there to witness it. I'll remember it for a long time. It will certainly be a reference for him because he still has a lot of steps to go through. That's always going to be there for him, what he's able to do. Just continue to work towards his goal, which is being top 100, top 50, top 10 and, one day, contend for a Grand Slam.\"\n\nEven 19-time grand slam winner Roger Federer of Switzerland was impressed watching Shapovalov on television at his hotel.\n\n\"I thought it was a fantastic match,\" said Federer. \"It was exhilarating for the crowd, for the fans watching on TV, for Canadian tennis.\n\n\"I didn't expect it to be this way. I thought that Rafa was going to win in straights. Denis did a great job. I'm really happy for him. Rafa was all class. He was great. It was a good night for tennis in some ways.\"\n\nIt helped that Shapovalov had nothing to lose and could try risky shots, but so far, that seems to be part of the youngster's success. Federer first noticed it while watching the Canadian win the junior Wimbledon title in 2016.\n\n\"He was in all sorts of trouble,\" said Federer. \"He kept going for the biggest shots: forehands, backhands and serves.\n\n\"I couldn't believe what he was doing. I guess for him it's somewhat normal to do that. Obviously it's risky and doesn't always play off. Doing that on Court 4 against a journeyman is a different story than doing it on center court, but not everybody can go up to that level. It seems that Denis has an extra gear.\n\n\"I think he's going to be a wonderful player.\"\n\nLaurendeau said Shapovalov is still developing the physical and mental sides of the game. A major test came in February at a Davis Cup World Group series against Britain in Ottawa.\n\nIn a fit of anger, Shapovalov tried to smash a ball into the crowd, but instead struck chair umpire Arnaud Gabas in the face. Gabas needed surgery to repair a broken bone under his left eye. Shapovalov defaulted the match, which cost Canada the series, and was fined US$7,000 by the International Tennis Federation.\n\n\"How he's handled the February incident from the beginning was very impressive from anybody, even a veteran and a mature man, to face the consequences of what happened,\" said Laurendeau. \"I think even more so for a teenager.\n\n\"He's never shied away. The first thing on his mind was to apologize to everybody. He understood the consequences. He manned up. The biggest progress to me is that aspect -- the mental, psychological aspect of his game. I mean, tactically, technically, physically he's improved. His biggest improvement to me has been how he's competing, how he's channelling and managing his emotions.\"\n\nOnly three weeks ago, Shapovalov was winning a Challenger event -- one step below the ATP Tour -- in Gatineau, Que.\n\nHe started the week ranked 143rd in the world, but the first three wins alone put him into the top 100.\n\nShapovalov will not be an ATP regular quite yet. He is not eligible to enter next week's event in Cincinnati and will instead play a Challenger tournament in Vancouver.\n\nAfter that, he will try to qualify for the U.S. Open in New York.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:34:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"uri": "tsn.ca", "title": "TSN", "id": "12443"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:46:00", "url": "http://www.tsn.ca/shapovalov-s-coach-not-surprised-by-teen-s-poise-1.828081", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8720612", "image": "http://www.tsn.ca/polopoly_fs/1.828085!/fileimage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_620/denis-shapovalov.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:34:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

\"A bit surprising, to be quite honest, because I hadn't practiced much.\"\n\nFederer has taken more time off this year than usual. He skipped the clay-court season from April to mid-June.\n\n\"I came from vacation, did some fitness, saw how I was feeling and said, 'You know what, I practiced so much the last year, let's go play some matches.'\n\n\"It's a big bonus right now and I hope I can play as free as I have so far in the finals tomorrow.\"\n\nSecond seeded Federer will meet either German Alexander Zverev or young Canadian Denis Shapovalov in Sunday's final where he will be seeking his sixth title of 2017.\n\nFederer is undergoing a resurgence this season after it appeared to many he might be slowing down as he transitions through his mid-30s.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said Federer, who would earn the second seed at the upcoming US Open if he wins in Montreal.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Roger Federer continued his longest winning streak in five years by reaching the Rogers Cup final.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer used a 6-3, 7-6 (5) victory over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands yesterday to reach his sixth final of the year and win his 16th consecutive match.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me. If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away.\n\nSometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel.\n\nI'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nFederer is looking for a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open beginning Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer has his longest winning streak since 2012. Next up is 20-year-old Alexander Zverev, who stopped Denis Shapovalov's impressive run with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the second semifinal.\n\nFederer has won of their three meetings, including a victory over the German on grass in June.\n\nShapovalov's tournament included consecutive wins over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro and top-seeded Spanish star Rafael Nadal. The victories, and the shaggy- haired youngster's style and skill on the court, announced his presence not only to Canadian fans but to the tennis world.\n\n\"My whole life has changed in the past five days,\" he said. \"It's crazy how it is.\n\n\"I mean, I go from being not known to being so known in the tennis world, in Canada in general. It's going to be a little bit of a change to me. I'm going to have to adapt. But that doesn't change things. I still have to work really hard every day.\"\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic, but Zverev was too strong, winning 81 percent of the points off his serve compared to 64 percent for Shapovalov.\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\" AP AH AH\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 1342, "textStart": 1335}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T06:52:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"uri": "dnaindia.com", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "id": "492"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:52:00", "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-federer-reaches-rogers-cup-final-2528454", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8881795", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "06:52:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

(Getty Images) Roger Federer used a dominant service game to beat Dutchman Robin Haase 6-3 7-6(5) in Montreal on Saturday, setting up a Rogers Cup final against German Alexander Zverev.\n\nHaase, playing in his first ATP World Tour Masters 1000 semi-final, did well to force a second-set tiebreak but Federer proved too much to handle as the Swiss fired down nine aces and dropped only nine points on serve.\n\nFederer, whose five titles this year include the Australian Open and Wimbledon, credited a positive mindset for helping him extend his winning streak to 16 matches.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said the 19-times grand slam champion.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sascha_Zverev", "score": 2, "id": "1278336", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 2, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Roger Federer continued his longest winning streak in five years by reaching the Rogers Cup final.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer used a 6-3, 7-6 (5) victory over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands on Saturday to reach his sixth final of the year and win his 16th consecutive match.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me. If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nFederer is looking for a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open beginning Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer has his longest winning streak since 2012. Next up is 20-year-old Alexander Zverev, who stopped Denis Shapovalov's impressive run with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the second semifinal.\n\nFederer has won of their three meetings, including a victory over the German on grass in June.\n\nShapovalov's tournament included consecutive wins over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro and top-seeded Spanish star Rafael Nadal. The victories, and the shaggy-haired youngster's style and skill on the court, announced his presence not only to Canadian fans but to the tennis world.\n\n\"My whole life has changed in the past five days,\" he said. \"It's crazy how it is.\n\n\"I mean, I go from being not known to being so known in the tennis world, in Canada in general. It's going to be a little bit of a change to me. I'm going to have to adapt. But that doesn't change things. I still have to work really hard every day.\"\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic, but Zverev was too strong, winning 81 percent of the points off his serve compared to 64 percent for Shapovalov.\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 1342, "textStart": 1335}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T04:51:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"uri": "kansascity.com", "title": "The Kansas City Star", "id": "577"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:51:00", "url": "http://www.kansascity.com/sports/article166939022.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8873180", "image": "http://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/s2yzk1/picture166939002/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/Rogers_Cup_Tennis_52620.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "04:51:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

final preview: Roger Federer v Alexander Zverev George BellshawSunday 13 Aug 2017 10:56 am Share this article with Facebook Share this article with Twitter Share this article with Google Plus Share this article with Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nRoger Federer will go toe-to-toe with 20-year-old hotshot Alexander Zverev in the 2017 final of the Rogers Cup in Montreal, with the Swiss looking to add a sixth title to his collection in a stunning comeback year.\n\nRafael Nadal bemoans 'worst defeat of year' as wildcard stuns world No 2\n\nAfter spending six months on the sidelines in the second half of last season, the world No. 3 has returned to his very best to take the tennis world by storm once more.\n\nHis opponent is enjoying a fine year of his own, with four titles already to his name, and he will be looking to match Federer's haul of five successes to become the joint-most trophy-laden star on the ATP Tour thus far in 2017.\n\nHere we take a look at the contest and offer a prediction as to who will come out on top...\n\nWhat's on the line?\n\nFederer is defending a simply stunning record in Masters 1000 and Grand Slam events in 2017, having played 29 matches and won them all.\n\nHowever, he has never won the Rogers Cup when it's based in Montreal, although he has won the event twice in Toronto.\n\nThe Swiss is also on a 16-match winning streak and should he extend that to 17 he will be in control of his own destiny to replace Andy Murray as world No. 1 at the Cincinnati Masters.\n\nFederer & Zverev in 2017 Current ranking\n\nFederer - 3\n\nZverev - 8\n\nTitles\n\nFederer - 5\n\nZverev - 4\n\nWin/loss ratio\n\nFederer - 35/2\n\nZverev - 45/13\n\nFourth seed Zverev is on a nine-match win streak of his own, having won the Citi Open in Washington last week and has secured qualification for the Next Gen Finals in Milan.\n\nThe German is up to third in the Race to London and looking to defend his 100% record in Masters 1000 finals, having beaten Novak Djokovic in Rome earlier this year.\n\nHow have they reached this stage?\n\nThings haven't all gone Federer's way during his time in Canada, with David Ferrer taking a set off him and Robin Haase causing him problems in the semi-finals, but the 36-year-old has still looked relatively assured in reaching the final.\n\nZverev, meanwhile, has taken out a host of well-known stars on his route to the brink of glory, beating Richard Gasquet in a tight opening match, in which he saved a match point after a 49-shot rally.\n\nSince then, he's not dropped a set during a run that saw him beat Nick Kyrgios, Kevin Anderson and 18-year-old Canadian sensation Denis Shapovalov.\n\nRoutes to Rogers Cup final\n\nFederer\n\nR1: Bye\n\nR2: 6-2 6-1 Polansky\n\nR3: 4-6 6-4 6-2 Ferrer\n\nQF: 6-4 6-4 Bautista Agut\n\nSF: 6-3 7-6 Haase\n\nZverev\n\nR1: Bye\n\nR2: 6-3 4-6 7-6 (7-3) Gasquet\n\nR3: 6-4 6-3 Kyrgios\n\nQF: 7-5 6-4 Anderson\n\nSF: 6-4 7-5 Shapovalov\n\nWhat's their head-to-head like?\n\nThe second seed leads the head-to-head 2-1 in official ATP Tour matches, although Zverev did enjoy a win in the Hopman Cup at the start of the year.\n\nFederer won their only previous meeting in a Masters 1000 match (Rome, 2016), while he also beat the German in the only time they've met in a Tour-level final (Halle, 2017).\n\nHowever, this is the first time the pair will meet on a hard court.\n\nFederer v Zverev head-to-head\n\nHead-to-head\n\nFederer 2-1 Zverev\n\nMasters 1000 head-to-head\n\nFederer 1-0 Zverev\n\nLast meeting\n\nFederer 6-1 6-3 Zverev, Halle final (2017)\n\nWho is the favourite?\n\nZverev is the youngest Coupe Rogers finalist since Djokovic lifted the title in 2007 but he is not fancied to deny Federer a 94th career ATP crown.\n\nThe Swiss will match Ivan Lendl's total in second place of trophies won in the Open Era - ranking just behind Jimmy Connors (109) - with a victory in what is his 45th Masters 1000 final.\n\nFederer is the clear favourite to win the title at 1/3, while Zverev's price is out at 5/2.\n\nRogers Cup final odds 1/3 - Federer to win\n\n5/2 - Zverev to win\n\n5/6 - Federer in 2\n\n5/1 - Zverev in 2\n\n11/4 - Federer in 3\n\n11/2 - Zverev in 3 What have they said?\n\nZverev: 'I think he's definitely the favourite. He's been playing amazing tennis. He pretty much won every single big tournament he played this year. But, you know, I played in five finals this year. I won four. The one that I lost was against Roger. There's a reason for it. I'm happy to be in the final. I'll try to enjoy as much as I can.'\n\nFederer: 'I'm happy - most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.'\n\nPrediction?\n\nZverev has enjoyed a great year so far but no man has looked more comfortable at the top of tennis than Federer.\n\nThe fear factor surrounding the Swiss is close to an all-time high and it's virtually impossible to back against right now.\n\nHopefully the German can put in a better showing than his one-sided defeat to the 19-time Grand Slam champion in Halle earlier this season but it remains likely he'll end up on the losing side here.\n\nPrediction: Federer in 2\n\nMORE: Roger Federer has named his eighth Wimbledon trophy Arthur - and the reason is perfect", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 97, "textStart": 86}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T09:58:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"uri": "metro.co.uk", "title": "Metro.co.uk", "id": "218"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:58:00", "url": "http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/13/rogers-cup-2017-final-preview-roger-federer-v-alexander-zverev-6848877/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8898968", "image": "https://metrouk2.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/800797464.jpg?quality=80&strip=all", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "09:58:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 2, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Montreal, Aug 12 (IANS) Second-seeded Swiss Roger Federer coasted into the semi-finals of the Rogers Cup in Montreal with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over Spain's Roberto Bautista-Agut here.\n\nAlthough the 12th-seeded Spaniard managed to make the score of both sets respectable, Federer was much sharper than in his Thursday round-of-16 match against Spain's David Ferrer and never appeared threatened throughout the one-hour, eight-minute contest on Friday, reports Efe.\n\nThe 36-year-old, whose titles at the Australian Open and Wimbledon -- the 18th and 19th of his legendary career -- have made him the story of the 2017 tennis season, squandered a service-break lead early in the second set when he was broken for the lone time in the match.\n\nBut he broke Bautista-Agut's serve in the ensuing game and never looked back.\n\n\"I struggled against Ferrer early on, so today was better. I was more committed and a step further in, adjusting my position slightly realizing the ball does fly a lot,\" Federer was quoted as saying on the ATP World Tour's Web site.\n\nNext up for Federer on Saturday will be surprise semi-finalist Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who rallied to defeat diminutive Argentine Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 in a battle of unseeded players.\n\nIn another round-of-16 action, 18-year-old Canadian rising star Denis Shapovalov stunned world No. 2 Rafael Nadal 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7-4) and stymied the Spaniard's hopes of regaining the No.1 ranking this week.\n\nEither Nadal or the third-ranked Federer will take over the top spot in the rankings from Scotland's Andy Murray on August 21, following the conclusion of next week's hard-court event in Cincinnati.\n\nMurray has withdrawn from Cincinnati with a lingering hip injury.\n\nBoth the Rogers Cup and the Western and Southern Open in Cincinnati are tune-up events for the final Grand Slam tournament on the tennis calendar, the US Open, which gets under way on August 28.\n\n--IANS\n\ntri/vm\n\nSEARCH", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 16, "textStart": 10}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-21", "textEnd": 1588, "textStart": 1579}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 1923, "textStart": 1914}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T07:36:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"uri": "sify.com", "title": "Sify", "id": "186"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:36:00", "url": "http://www.sify.com/news/federer-eases-into-rogers-cup-semis-news-others-rimmEbcgeeead.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8759335", "image": "http://static.sify.com/cms/commons/widget/images/featured-thumbs-default-img.gif", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "07:36:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Cantillon\n\nLast Updated: 11/08/17 10:34pm\n\nRoger Federer will face Dutchman Robin Haase in the semi-finals of the Montreal Masters after the pair beat Roberto Bautista Agut and Diego Schwartzman, respectively.\n\nFriday night saw three of the Montreal Masters semi-finals. Here's what went on....\n\nRoger Federer v Roberto Bautista Agut\n\nRoger Federer booked his place in the semi-finals of the Montreal Masters with a dominant and routine 6-4 6-4 victory over Spain's Bautista Agut on Friday.\n\nFederer had beaten another Spaniard, David Ferrer, 4-6 6-4 6-2 to book his place in the quarter-finals, while Bautista Agut had got past Frenchman Gael Monfils 4-6 7-6 7-6.\n\nA tight start to the match went to serve for the first eight games leaving it 4-4, but Federer picked up the first break in the ninth game, repeatedly attacking Bautista Agut's second serves to the point at which the Spaniard double faulted to hand the Swiss the break.\n\nFederer took the opening with both hands as he ruthlessly served out the set in the next game with ease, clinching it 6-4.\n\nThe 36-year-old began the second set in confident form, with Bautista Agut struggling to handle Federer's returns and giving away far too many unforced errors.\n\nFederer duly went a break up in the very first game, clinching it by lashing a trademark backhand across the court which Bautista Agut couldn't deal with.\n\nBautista Agut showed great character to break straight back as Federer made just one first serve in the second game, but that was as good as it got for the Spaniard for the rest of the set.\n\nFederer proceeded to force the third break of serve in a row, stepping up and into Bautista Agut's shots and finishing them with lethal power to move 2-1 ahead.\n\nThe next game saw Federer serve out four straight points, with Bautista Agut on the backfoot on each occasion, but the 29-year-old recovered to hold in the next game to leave the scores 3-2.\n\nAfter two key unforced errors, Federer survived two break points to recover to deuce, and then served out two more points to go 4-2 ahead.\n\nBautista Agut twice held serve but crucially could not fire a shot on Federer's service game, who calmly dispatched the Spaniard on each occasion to seal the victory.\n\nRobin Haase v Diego Schwartzman\n\nEarlier in the night, Haase booked his passage through to the first Masters 1000 event semi-final in his career after defeating Argentine Diego Schwartzman 4-6 6-3 6-2.\n\nThe 30-year-old Dutchman had seen off seventh seed Grigor Dimitrov 7-6 4-6 6-1 in the last round, while Schwartzman had also won in three sets against 20-year-old American Jared Donaldson 0-6 7-5 7-5.\n\nThe tension was palpable as both players sought to make a bit of history in their careers, and it looked as if Schwartzman would make a slow start again as he did against Donaldson.\n\nThe 24-year-old saved a couple of break points to eventually serve out the opening game, however, before the pair traded breaks over the next couple of games.\n\nWith little to choose between the payers, it was to be Hasse who would blink first in the opening set, and in the most crucial of games at 5-4 down.\n\nHaving adopted a distinctly defensive approach, the Dutchman appeared to panic when Schwartzman applied pressure to get on top of him in the 10th game.\n\nHaase saved one set point with an ace, but had no reply to Schwartzman's lethal and aggressive service return thereafter, clinching the first set 6-4.\n\nIn the second set, Schwartzman was the first to drop a game, and it was one he never should have.\n\nAt 1-1 and cruising 40-15 in the third game, the diminutive Argentine made four inexplicable unforced errors which gifted Haase the break of serve.\n\nAfter Haase held his next serve, it was a similar story in the fifth game as Schwartzman allowed the Dutchman to take command of the second set at 4-1 through his mistakes.\n\nThe spirited Argentine broke back immediately though, with Haase complaining about a disturbance in the stands, and then came the game which would decide the second set.\n\nIt last over 13 minutes long as both players passed up numerous points to win the game, which kept reverting to deuce. Haase passed up five break points, while Schwartzman missed six points to win the game before finally clinching it.\n\nAt 4-3, Schwartzman passed up a break point, allowing Haase to go 5-3 ahead, and the Dutchman closed the set out in the very next game to win it 6-3, and take the clash to a decider.\n\nHaase began the third set powerfully, racing into a 2-0 lead, after a terrific top spin lob shot clinched the break of serve in the second game.\n\nThe pair held serve in the next two games, before Schwartzmann broke Haase to get the match back to 3-2.\n\nHaase won the next two games to go 5-2 ahead however, and the next time he was serving he confirmed the set 6-2 and clinched the victory.\n\nDenis Shapovalov v Adrian Mannarino (11.30pm start)\n\nReport to follow...\n\nAlso See: Murray prospers as Nadal exits Konta slips up in Toronto ATP schedule Tennis on Sky", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:43:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"uri": "skysports.com", "title": "Sky Sports", "id": "709"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:43:00", "url": "http://www.skysports.com/tennis/news/12110/10983974/montreal-masters-round-up-roger-federer-to-face-robin-haase-in-semi-final", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8706625", "image": "http://e1.365dm.com/17/08/150x150/skysports-roger-federer-tennis_4071490.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:43:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"ATP Challenger Tour"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Challenger_Tour", "score": 1, "id": "359693", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "2009 U.S. Open (golf)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_U.S._Open_(golf)", "score": 3, "id": "569995", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Martin Laurendeau"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Laurendeau", "score": 4, "id": "1048441", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canadian teenager stuns top-seeded Rafael Nadal at Rogers Cup\n\nDenis Shapovalov's coach wasn't surprised that the teenager was able to keep his head while upsetting a tennis legend on centre court at the Rogers Cup.\n\nMartin Laurendeau said Friday that he saw it a year ago when Shapovalov beat Australian star Nick Kyrgios in the Rogers Cup first round in Toronto and the 18-year-old's cool head was evident again this week with wins over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro and former world No.1 Rafael Nadal.\n\n\"All the guys he's played up to, he takes it to them,\" said Laurendeau, who coaches Shapovalov and serves as Canada's Davis Cup captain. \"He revels in that kind of atmosphere.\n\n\"He's like a fish in water when you put him on a big court against a big player. I don't know if you can teach that, but he has that and he's making the most of it.\"\n\nShapovalov, of Richmond Hill, Ont., posted one of the biggest wins in Canadian tennis history when he battled Nadal for two hours 45 minutes on Thursday night and pulled out the victory in a third-set tiebreaker. It was a back-and-forth match, with several break points saved on both sides. Shapovalov fell behind 3-0 in the tiebreaker, but a Nadal double fault and two aces gave the youngster the match.\n\nAt no time did the left-hander show any sign of cracking under the pressure. Instead, he fed off the deafening sound from the sellout crowd of 11,000 that cheered every point he won.\n\n\"It's a bit surreal to be able to, start to finish, last that long, produce quality tennis and go toe-to-toe with a legend like that,\" said Laurendeau. \"It's just remarkable.\n\n\"I'm glad I was there to witness it. I'll remember it for a long time. It will certainly be a reference for him because he still has a lot of steps to go through. That's always going to be there for him, what he's able to do. Just continue to work towards his goal, which is being top 100, top 50, top 10 and, one day, contend for a Grand Slam.\"\n\nHe said Shapovalov is still developing the physical and mental sides of the game. A major test came in February at a Davis Cup World Group series against Britain in Ottawa.\n\nIn a fit of anger, Shapovalov tried to smash a ball into the crowd, but instead struck chair umpire Arnaud Gabas in the face. Gabas needed surgery to repair a broken bone under his left eye. Shapovalov defaulted the match, which cost Canada the series, and was fined US$7,000 by the International Tennis Federation.\n\n\"How he's handled the February incident from the beginning was very impressive from anybody, even a veteran and a mature man, to face the consequences of what happened,\" said Laurendeau. \"I think even more so for a teenager.\n\n\"He's never shied away. The first thing on his mind was to apologize to everybody. He understood the consequences. He manned up. The biggest progress to me is that aspect -- the mental, psychological aspect of his game. I mean, tactically, technically, physically he's improved. His biggest improvement to me has been how he's competing, how he's channelling and managing his emotions.\"\n\nOnly three weeks ago, Shapovalov was winning a Challenger event -- one step below the ATP Tour -- in Gatineau, Que.\n\nHe started the week ranked 143rd in the world, but the first three wins alone put him into the top 100.\n\nBut he will not be an ATP regular quite yet. He is not eligible to enter next week's event in Cincinnati and will instead play a Challenger tournament in Vancouver.\n\nAfter that, he will try to qualify for the U.S. Open in New York.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:17:00Z", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "title": "CBC News", "id": "668"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:33:00", "url": "http://www.cbc.ca/sports/tennis/denis-shapovalov-coach-laurendeau-not-surprised-success-big-stage-1.4244264", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8696966", "image": "https://i.cbc.ca/1.4244289.1502481965!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_1180/97006690.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:17:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

sharper than in his Thursday round-of-16 match against Spain's David Ferrer and never appeared threatened throughout the one-hour, eight-minute contest.\n\nThe 36-year-old, whose titles at the Australian Open and Wimbledon - the 18th and 19th of his legendary career - have made him the story of the 2017 tennis season, squandered a service-break lead early in the second set when he was broken for the lone time in the match.\n\nBut he broke Bautista-Agut's serve in the ensuing game and never looked back.\n\n\"I struggled against Ferrer early on, so today was better. "score": 3, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Nadal goes down to Shapovalov in Montreal, Federer scrapes past Ferrer\n\nThere will be no new world No. 1 at the end of the Rogers Cup. Rafael Nadal, who would have regained the top ranking if he had reached the semifinals, lost to Denis Shapovalov 3-6, 6-4, 7-6(4) during third-round action on Thursday night. In front of a home Canadian crowd, Shapovalov pulled off the biggest win of his career after two hours and 45 minutes.\n\nAfter the 18-year-old broke Nadal's serve to end the second set, a wild third ensued. Shapovalov saved six break points to stay on level terms early before a stretch of routine holds led to a tiebreaker. Nadal led 3-0 but won only a single point the rest of the way and watched Shapovalov blast a forehand winner at 6-4 to wrap it up in style.\n\nShapovalov admitted afterward that he woke up in the morning in Felix Auger Aliassime's basement and the first thing he saw was a poster of Rafael Nadal on the wall. He told his friend to take it down. A little more than 12 hours later, Shapovalov took down the real Nadal.\n\nThe second-ranked Spaniard called it his worst loss of the year.\n\nIf Nadal hasn't done much losing this year, Roger Federer has done next to none. In fact, the 36-year-old Swiss has fallen only twice. Federer actually lost a set on Thursday, but he refused to go down to David Ferrer and instead prevailed 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 in one hour and 56 minutes.\n\n\"For me it was more of a struggle,\" Montreal's No. 2 seed commented. \"As you know, you don't always feel the same and each opponent is a different problem. He started very well, especially on the return on my second serve. I was not able to serve my first serve where I wanted to, and he hurt me on the second serve.\"\n\nWith the win, Federer improved to 17-0 lifetime against Ferrer.\n\n\"I already beat other players 17 times,\" Federer noted. \"Sometimes I played them maybe 30 or 40 times. They ended up beating me at a certain stages, like (Andy) Roddick, (Fernando) Gonzalez, and (Robin) Soderling. Sometimes I beat them 10 times in a row. At the end they always ended up beating me. That's why I have a lot of respect for this match today. I know it can't continue that way. Seventeen is a lot.\n\n\"The last match we played were three tight sets in Toronto, then three sets Cincinnati, and again today. So these statistics are a bit ridiculous, because I have a lot of respect for David. As a person, he's very nice. He's a great fighter on the court. So this type of head-to-head is a bit strange.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T04:24:00Z", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "source": {"uri": "10sballs.com", "title": "10sballs.com", "id": "4235"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:24:00", "url": "http://www.10sballs.com/2017/08/10/rafael-nadal-goes-down-to-denis-shapovalov-in-montreal-roger-federer-beats-david-ferrer/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8535786", "image": "http://www.10sballs.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/53698402-150x150.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "04:24:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filip_Peliwo", "score": 3, "id": "548377", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Martin Laurendeau"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Laurendeau", "score": 2, "id": "1048441", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 5, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Denis Shapovalov reacts to his upset win over Rafael Nadal at the 2017 Rogers Cup. (Paul Chiasson/CP)\n\nCanadian teen tennis sensation Denis Shapovalov had the biggest win of his young career on Thursday night when he upset top-seeded Spaniard Rafael Nadal in the round of 16 at the Rogers Cup.\n\nWhile the 18-year-old Richmond Hill, Ont., native's profile -- not to mention his world ranking of 143 -- is sure to climb thanks to his success in Montreal, he's still a relatively new face on the ATP Tour.\n\nHere are five things to help Canadian tennis fans get to know the budding star:\n\nHE'S MADE HISTORY ... A FEW TIMES: The win over Nadal put Shapovalov into the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup, making him the youngest player to advance to the tournament's final eight since Bjorn Borg in 1974. He's also the youngest quarter-finalist ever at an ATP Masters event, the highest level on the pro tour. In 2016, he became just the second Canadian to win the Wimbledon boys singles title. Filip Peliwo in 2012 was the first.\n\n--\n\nHE'S A LEFTY: Like tennis greats John McEnroe, Martina Navratilova, Jimmy Connors and Nadal, Shapovalov is left-handed. But being a southpaw may not give him the same advantage it gave some of his predecessors. Technical advances in rackets and court surfaces as well as a changes in game strategy and the rise of the two-handed backhand have levelled the playing field in recent years.\n\n--\n\nHE'S BEEN COMPARED TO ROGER FEDERER: Tennis analyst Craig O'Shannessy once described the young Canadian as \"a left-handed version of Federer, with that one-handed backhand,\" according to the Telegraph in Britain. O'Shannessy also said there is \"no ceiling\" for Shapovalov, and praised his \"great energy and rapport with the crowd.\" He's certainly made an impression this week in Montreal, with Wayne Gretzky and star swimmer Penny Oleksiak among his boosters in the stands.\n\n--\n\nHE RECENTLY CHANGED COACHES: Before the start of the season, his first full campaign as a pro, Shapovalov split with his coach Adriano Fuorivia, who he had worked with for more than four years. Canadian Davis Cup captain Martin Laurendeau was hired as his replacement. Shapovalov said earlier this year that he and Fuorivia are on good terms despite parting ways. \"Adriano thought that someone with more experience like Marty would be a good benefit to my team,\" he said. \"It was nothing that happened between us, it was just more of a decision that we made together.\"\n\n--\n\nHE'S STILL A KID: Shapovalov showed a flash of immaturity when a ball he carelessly hit in frustration during a Davis Cup match in February struck a chair umpire in the eye. He dealt with the fallout like a man however, making no excuses for the incident, saying he lost control of his emotions and behaved unprofessionally. While he apologized to the umpire, his teammates and tennis fans, the International Tennis Federation didn't let him off the hook.
