"Forehand"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forehand", "score": 3, "id": "420299", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Filip Peliwo"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filip_Peliwo", "score": 3, "id": "548377", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Uniprix Stadium"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniprix_Stadium", "score": 4, "id": "651038", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "That's what we call a conversation changer.\n\nThe moment Denis Shapovalov ripped his final forehand winner past a helpless Rafael Nadal to defeat the Spaniard on Thursday night at Uniprix Stadium in one of Canada's most significant tennis achievements ever, it altered many of the important discussion points on the sport in this country.\n\nWith the constantly-injured Milos Raonic seemingly stalled (albeit in the ATP's top 10) and Eugenie Bouchard both plummeting in world rankings even further and complaining about the responsibilities of representing the Great White North, it was just about the perfect time for a new Canadian star to, in the immortal words of Ebby Calvin (Nuke) LaLoosh, announce his presence with authority.\n\nShapovalov did that at the Rogers Cup, blocking Nadal from returning to No. 1 in the world in a match that the Toronto native admitted he felt he had no chance of winning before it started.\n\nHe clinched the unthinkable come-from-behind victory by dramatically winning seven of the final eight points in the third set tiebreak, making himself the new focus of Canadian tennis at the tender age of 18. Raonic, now entering his prime at age 26, was never able to register a victory quite like that while a teenager. His biggest win so far probably came last year in the Wimbledon semifinals over Roger Federer.\n\nBut Raonic just can't stay healthy for more than a few months at a time, and bombed out of this Rogers Cup early with a wrist problem. His health has been a significant part of the reason he's so far not been able to win one of the big tournaments in his sport, either a Grand Slam event or a Masters-level tournament.\n\nHe's still Canada's best player, and still miles ahead of Shapovalov in the world rankings.\n\nBut the teenager is about to enter the top 100 with a bullet, and looks to be the next great thing in Canadian tennis. Vasek Pospisil has done great things at Davis Cup, won a Wimbledon doubles crown, at one point worked himself inside the top 30 and even played Raonic in the Rogers Cup semis four years ago, but he is no longer viewed as a anything but an occasional threat to the best singles players in the world.\n\nRead more:\n\nDenis Shapovalov upsets top seed Rafael Nadal at Rogers Cup\n\nEugenie Bouchard one and done at Wimbledon: DiManno\n\nMilos Raonic eliminated in opening match at Rogers Cup after playing through wrist injury\n\nFilip Peliwo, who won junior Wimbledon the same year Bouchard did, has been unable to get his career off the ground at all so far.\n\nBut Shapovalov, also a Wimbledon junior champ, surely has, beating Nick Kyrgios last year at the Rogers Cup and both Juan Martin del Potro and Nadal this year. He handled a disgraceful moment earlier this year in Ottawa fairly well -- he struck a chair umpire in the eye with a ball while throwing a tantrum during a Davis Cup match and was disqualified -- and showed up in Montreal with high profile supporters Wayne Gretzky and Penny Oleksiak in his box.\n\nSo Raonic is still our best. But Shapovalov, regardless of the conclusion to his Rogers Cup, is now the one everyone's talking about.\n\nBouchard, meanwhile, really put a dark cloud over the proceedings earlier in the week when, after losing in the first round again, she whined about the \"burden\" of carrying the Canadian flag into competition. It did make you wonder for a moment. Do we put too much pressure on our few tennis stars? Has it really dragged her down, inhibited her selfie-taking?\n\nThen Shapovalov arrived to utterly dismiss that kind of talk. Burden? That kid looked like he could have floated out of the stadium, and other star Canadian athletes surely noticed.\n\nWithout mentioning Bouchard by name, former Canadian national hockey team superstar Hayley Wickenheiser tweeted, \"Great match @denis_shapo!! See, it's not a burden it's a wave of Canadian energy pushing you from behind! Go for it! #rogerscup #Shapovalov\"\n\nSounds like something Gretzky would say. Or tweet, if he was a tweeter.\n\nShapovalov clearly has the fire Bouchard once did back in the days she would put temporary tattoos of Canadian flags on her face when she competed in Fed Cup. To be fair to her, we'll see how he feels about things in another five years. Tennis can be a lonely sport, and she clearly feels very alone these days.\n\nNot Shapovalov. Indeed, while he tries to catch up to Raonic, he's staying in the basement of buddy Felix Auger-Aliassime, a 17-year-old Montrealer who won the junior boys title at the U.S. Open last fall and the doubles, too, with Shapovalov as his partner. Both have come through the Tennis Canada development system, evidence that it is working to produce top talent.\n\nIndeed, there are more than a few who believe Auger-Aliassime might be even better than Shapovalov has already proven to be. We'll see about that.\n\nWhat we do know is Shapovalov looks to have a more complete game than Raonic did at the same age, with a fearsome serve, a massive forehand, a flamboyant one-handed backhand and lots of nimbleness around the court. The volleying needs work, and he's in the process of adding a slice backhand. Being a lefty, meanwhile, still comes with its advantages on tour. Just ask Nadal.\n\nRaonic has been able to rise into the top 10 with his monster serve and by working as hard as anybody in the sport to address his vulnerabilities, both through tireless effort and by assembling a top-notch team around him. And still, the top titles have proven elusive.\n\nSo Shapovalov still has lots and lots of miles to go. But he's flashy and exciting, perhaps the most exciting and outwardly passionate player Canadian tennis has produced. That personality ignited that fiasco in Ottawa earlier this year. The umpire suffered a fractured eye socket, but Shapovalov apologized publicly for his conduct and privately to the umpire, paid his $7,000 fine and has moved on. He needs to make sure that temper stays in check.\n\nThe tennis world in general was watching his win over Nadal, and so was Canada. All eyes are now squarely on Shapovalov as the one to watch.\n\nRaonic still has the ranking and that incredible serve.\n\nBut Shapovalov clearly has our undivided attention.\n\nDamien Cox is the co-host of Prime Time Sports on Sportsnet 590 The FAN. He spent nearly 30 years covering a variety of sports for The Star. Follow him @DamoSpin. His column appears Tuesday and Saturday.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {"liCnt": 3}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:02:00Z", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "title": "theStar.com", "id": "1354"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:53:00", "url": "https://www.thestar.com/sports/tennis/2017/08/11/all-eyes-on-denis-shapovalov-as-the-new-canadian-tennis-star-to-watch-cox.html", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8683569", "image": "https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/sports/tennis/2017/08/11/all-eyes-on-denis-shapovalov-as-the-new-canadian-tennis-star-to-watch-cox/denis-shapovalov.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:02:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

reaching the Rogers Cup final.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer used a 6-3, 7-6 (5) victory over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands on Saturday to reach his sixth final of the year and win his 16th consecutive match.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me. If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nFederer is looking for a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open beginning Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer has his longest winning streak since 2012. Next up is 20-year-old Alexander Zverev, who stopped Denis Shapovalov's impressive run with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the second semifinal.\n\nFederer has won of their three meetings, including a victory over the German on grass in June.\n\nShapovalov's tournament included consecutive wins over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro and top -- seeded Spanish star Rafael Nadal. The victories, and the shaggy -- haired youngster's style and skill on the court, announced his presence not only to Canadian fans but to the tennis world.\n\n\"My whole life has changed in the past five days,\" he said. \"It's crazy how it is.\n\n\"I mean, I go from being not known to being so known in the tennis world, in Canada in general. It's going to be a little bit of a change to me. I'm going to have to adapt. But that doesn't change things. I still have to work really hard every day.\"\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic, but Zverev was too strong, winning 81 percent of the points off his serve compared to 64 percent for Shapovalov.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 1022, "textStart": 1015}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T06:18:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "title": "The Hindu", "id": "241"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:18:00", "url": "http://www.thehindu.com/sport/tennis/federer-reaches-rogers-cup-final/article19485171.ece", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8878886", "image": "http://www.thehindu.com/sport/tennis/article19485170.ece/ALTERNATES/LANDSCAPE_615/ROGERSCUPTENNIS", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "06:18:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Dare to dream big, and big things can happen for you.\n\nJust ask Canadian Denis Shapovalov, who pulled off a shocker by knocking off one of his childhood heroes in Argentina's Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round of the Rogers Cup on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nThe blond-haired, blue-eyed native of Richmond Hill, Ont., took the match 6-3, 7-6 (4) in front of a near-capacity crowd at Stade Uniprix.\n\nHe had entered the tournament as the youngest player in the draw and on Wednesday he became the youngest player to advance to the third round of a Masters 1000 event since Rafael Nadal managed the feat in Miami 13 years ago.\n\nIt was on Tuesday, after Shapovalov debuted with a gutsy 4-6, 7-6, 6-4 win over Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Silva, that the 18-year-old said he'd have to be at his very best to have a chance against the No. 31-ranked player who once ranked as high as fourth in the world.\n\n\"I live for these moments,\" he added. \"I live to be in these matches. I think it's going to be a great battle. Hopefully I can play really well.\"\n\nThere's no doubt Shapovalov delivered, breaking the 2009 U.S. Open champion early in the first set and fighting his way into a tiebreak in the second before smashing his final shot of the match to bring the crowd to its feet.\n\nThey were a boisterous bunch, having been revved up earlier in the day by two-time Rogers Cup champion Roger Federer, who played his first match in Montreal since 2011 and dismantled Canadian Peter Polansky 6-2, 6-1 in just under 53 minutes.\n\n\"Shapo-valov\" [clap, clap, clap clap clap], the fans cheered throughout the match, inspiring him to achieve his best result yet at a Rogers Cup. He reached the second round at last year's tournament in Toronto.\n\n\"Thanks so much,\" Shapovalov said to the crowd after the match. \"You guys are amazing. Honestly, I love you guys so much.\"\n\nConsider this his best experience of the year. He had won two Challenger events and an IT Futures event earlier in the season. A wild card berth at Wimbledon was certainly a highlight. But after dropping four of his first five matches on the ATP World Tour this season before arriving in Montreal, winning two matches on home soil -- one of them against one of the sport's most prolific players -- is a dream come true.\n\n\"It's got to be one of my best wins. Has to be,\" said Shapovalov. \"Like I said yesterday, [Del Potro's] my idol. First of all, just to play against him, it's a huge honour for me. To beat a player of this category, of this talent, it's very inspiring to me. [It's] a huge confidence boost.\"\n\nIt's a necessary one ahead of what's likely to be a third-round meeting with Nadal, who takes to centre court later on Wednesday to face Croatia's Borna Coric.\n\nConsidering the prospect of facing Nadal, who currently ranks No. 2 in the world and has a chance to recapture No. 1 by making the semifinal of this tournament, Shapovalov said he expects a really tough fight.\n\n\"Every time I look at him I think, what a ridiculous athlete and what a ridiculous player he is,\" said Shapovalov. \"I think it's going to be very interesting for me to go up against him, just to see how my game style matches him.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-09T22:59:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"uri": "sportsnet.ca", "title": "Sportsnet", "id": "1184"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:59:00", "url": "http://www.sportsnet.ca/tennis/denis-shapovalov-proving-youth-no-obstacle-rogers-cup/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8286953", "image": "http://assets1.sportsnet.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Denis_Shapovalov.jpg", "date": "2017-08-09", "time": "22:59:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-09"}

"Forehand"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forehand", "score": 2, "id": "420299", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Serve (tennis)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serve_(tennis)", "score": 2, "id": "498181", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "We here at RealSport preview the clash between world number 2 Roger Federer and former top ten stalwart David Ferrer of Spain.\n\nThe Rogers Cup third round has thrown up a clash between long-time rivals Roger Federer, twice a champion in Canada, and one-time world number 3 and French Open finalist David Ferrer. They have had contrasting seasons, with Federer winning five titles, including two Slams, whilst Ferrer has fallen down the rankings. But they have had some terrific clashes down the years, and this could be another one.\n\nRoger Federer and David Ferrer have met 16 times, and Federer has won 16 times. It's a testament to both men's longevity that their first meeting came back in 2003 in Vienna, which was a comfortable victory for Federer 6-2 6-2. In fact, it took until their seventh meeting, in the quarterfinals in Hamburg for Ferrer to win his first set, which he did in a 3-6 6-4 3-6 loss. He has pushed Federer on a couple of occasions, including in their last meeting in the final in Cincinnati in 2014. However, just as in the fifteen meetings prior to that one, Federer ultimately came away with the victory.\n\nNeither man is short of experience. Ferrer has recorded 711 wins so far in his career, and won 27 titles, including one Masters 1000 in Paris in 2012. However, even those hugely impressive numbers pale when compared with Federer's. The great Swiss has notched 1112 wins and won a staggering 93 titles. That includes a record 19 Slams and 26 Masters 1000 titles.\n\nAs the second seed Roger Federer received a bye into the second round. There he faced off against one-time hitting partner Peter Polansky, who had knocked out fellow Canadian Vasek Pospisil in the previous round. However, Polansky could offer little resistance to Federer. In their previous match in 2014, he had suffered a 6-2 6-0 hammering. It went little better for the Canadian in the rematch. Federer swiftly took the first set 6-2 and came within a point of repeating the score line from their 2014 meeting. Polansky managed to avoid that fate, holding serve down 5-0. But it did nothing but delay the inevitable as Federer comfortably served out the match in the next game to record a 6-2 6-1 win.\n\nDavid Ferrer, in contrast, has had to battle hard to reach the third round. Beginning against Kyle Edmund of Great Britain, Ferrer had to rebound from dropping the first set in a tight tiebreak. He managed to do so, pressurising the Yorkshireman's backhand and second serve. Edmund couldn't cope and surrendered the next two sets 6-3 6-4 to send Ferrer into the second round. There he clashed with American number 1 Jack Sock. Again the first set was decided by a tight tiebreak, but this time it was Ferrer who won it, coming through 9-7. Jack Sock took the second set six games to one with a flurry of forehand winners but Ferrer didn't give up the fight. He broke decisively and served out the match for a 7-6 1-6 6-3 to set up the meeting with Federer.\n\nIf there is a shot that can be hit with a tennis racquet, Federer probably can, and has, played it. His variety is rightly legendary, but his game is built around two core strengths all the same. Those are his forehand and serve, which are amongst the best in the world. His serve, though not amongst the most powerful, but its accuracy is unparalleled. Ferrer is blessed with neither Federer's weapons nor his variety. But what he does have is a dogged resilience that is perhaps unmatched by any other, and an ability to stay in rallies few others could.\n\nHis defence will have to be at its legendary best if he is to have a chance against Federer. Furthermore, he will have to keep Federer pinned back at the baseline, or he will have little chance. The one comfort Ferrer can bring into the match is his excellent return, which will allow him to neutralise more of Federer's serves than most players. It is a tactic Novak Djokovic has used with great success against Federer in the past. Unfortunately for Ferrer, he lacks Djokovic's power of the ground.\n\nConsidering Federer has won 16 times in a row against Ferrer, it's hard to go against him in this one. He is playing some of the best tennis of his life, with time seemingly having had no effect on his game. Ferrer, unfortunately, is not the player he once was. Though his will is undiminished, his legs are weaker and slower than they were during the glory years of his career when he reached as high as world number 3. If Federer could beat that Ferrer, he can surely beat this one. Federer in straight sets.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-09T22:00:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"uri": "realsport101.com", "title": "RealSport", "id": "16982"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:20:00", "url": "https://realsport101.com/news/sports/tennis/roger-federer-vs-david-ferrer-rogers-cup-2017-3rd-round-preview-and-prediction/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8548948", "image": "https://realsport101.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Federer-Rogers-Cup-3.jpg", "date": "2017-08-09", "time": "22:00:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

16 at the Rogers Cup Canadian Open men's tennis championships.\n\nShapovalov finished the day as the lone surviving Canadian, as sixth-seeded Milos Raonic of Thornhill, Ont., turned in an uninspired performance in a 6-4, 6-4 loss to Adrian Mannarino of France. After the match, Raonic said he is suffering from a left wrist injury.\n\nShapovalov will be a decided underdog when he meets top-seeded Rafael Nadal, who cruised past Croatian Borna Coric 6-1, 6-2. Even if he loses Thursday evening, Shapovalov will come out of this week with a career-high ranking in the 125 range.\n\n\"Like I said yesterday, he's my idol,\" Shapovalov said after he became the youngest Canadian to reach the third round in this tournament. \"First of all, just to play against him, it's a huge honour for me. But to beat a player of this category, of this talent, it's very inspiring for me, a huge confidence boost.\"\n\nThe win lifted Shapovalov into some rarefied company. He's the youngest player to reach the third round of this event since Mats Wilander in 1982. And he's the youngest player to reach the final 16 of an ATP Masters 1000 event since Rafael Nadal in Miami in 2004.\n\nShapovalov showed poise beyond his years. serve.\n\nFederer, whose five titles this year include the Australian Open and Wimbledon, credited a positive mindset for helping him extend his winning streak to 16 matches.\n\nREAD: Federer reaches Rogers Cup final\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said the 19-times grand slam The two went back and forth as tennis fans, including a front-row Wayne Gretzky, sat on the edge of their seats.\n\nShapovalov was able to overcome a 3-0 deficit in the tiebreaker to take the final set 7-6, while simultaneously thrilling a nation and making some history.\n\nThe teen was 143rd on the ATP ranking heading into the match and is the second-youngest person to defeat Nadal on the Tour -- the youngest being Borna Coric back in 2014 as a 17-year-old.\n\nShapovalov, of Richmond Hill, Ont., is now set to face Adrian Mannarino, fresh off a win over Milos Raonic, in the quarter-finals.\n\nBefore that happens, however, here's a look at some of the best reaction to Shapovalov's stunning upset of Nadal.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T05:23:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"uri": "sportsnet.ca", "title": "Sportsnet", "id": "1184"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:23:00", "url": "http://www.sportsnet.ca/tennis/twitter-reaction-canada-falls-love-denis-shapovalov/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8542032", "image": "http://assets3.sportsnet.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/shapovalov_denis_win.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "05:23:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Shapovalov who had the bullet ", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "Canada"}, "type": "loc", "score": 4, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Canada"}, "type": "country"}, "uri": "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Open_(tennis)", "score": 2, "id": "433950", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tennis Channel"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Channel", "score": 2, "id": "533173", "type": "org"}], "body": "The Canadian teen stunned the 15-time Grand Slam champion in front of his home crowd. (Getty Images)\n\nThere's the big, bending lefty serve; \"swing it like Shapovalov,\" kids may say someday. There's the forehand that he can hit for winners crosscourt, down the line, inside out and inside in, and which never ever looks rushed. There's the one-handed backhand that he rarely gives in and slices, and which he rarely misses when he sees a crosscourt opening. There's the too-large backwards hat and the leaping energy that lets you know that, yes, while his game may look 25, he's still just 18.\n\nBut what has really set Denis Shapavolov apart this week in Montreal is what happens when he gets done leaping and comes back to earth. He slows down, collects himself and finds his best, calmest, most forceful tennis when he needs it. In Shapovalov's matches with Juan Martin del Potro on Wednesday and Rafael Nadal on Thursday, I kept waiting for the veteran Grand Slam champion to assert his authority and run away with the match. Instead, it was Shapovalov, the teenage wild card ranked outside the Top 150, who ran them off the court.\n\nShapovalov, the 2016 Wimbledon boys' champ, followed up the biggest win of his young career, over Del Potro, with a much bigger one, over Nadal, by the suitably dramatic score of 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (4). Over the last two sets, Shapovalov controlled the rallies and pushed Nadal back with his hooking serve and heavy forehand, while at the same time forcing Rafa to scramble far beyond the sidelines with both shots. Shapovalov hit nine aces and 49 winners to just 18 for Nadal; that included a 33 to 14 edge from the forehand side.\n\nBut it wasn't the number of aces or winners he hit; it was when he hit them. Up 4-1 in the second set, Shapovalov let Nadal come back to 4-4 and take a 0-30 lead in that game. The crowd that had been so noisy was quiet now; the end looked near. That is, until Shapovalov uncorked two aces down the T (something he hadn't done much of, if at all, until then), smoothly sent a forehand winner into the corner and finished the game with a nasty, slicing body serve. From there, he broke to win the second set.\n\nAgain, early in the third, it looked as if Nadal would reassert himself. Through a long, multi-deuce third game, Nadal kept forcing break points, only to watch as Shapovalov wiped them away with line-painting serves and forehands. In the stat of the night, Shapovalov saved nine of 11 break points. By the time the match reached its climactic and well-earned third-set tiebreaker, the outcome seemed inevitable -- and not in Nadal's favor.\n\nEven when Rafa went up 3-0 in the breaker, you felt like Shapovalov hadn't fired his last shot just yet. Nadal berated himself when he missed an easy backhand with a chance to go up 4-0; he knew he needed to build his lead while he still had the chance. He was right. Shapovalov, as he had all night, played his best, most settled tennis with the match on the line, hitting two aces and three forehand winners in the last seven points.\n\nFor Nadal, this was another in a long string of close losses and missed opportunities on surfaces other than clay. He spent much of the match 10 feet behind the baseline; from there, he struggled to get the ball to Shapovalov's backhand. And while the 18-year-old rookie was firing aces and winners in the breaker, the 15-time Slam champion double-faulted and smothered a hanging forehand into the net. Nadal can still reach No. 1 next week, but he could use a victory in one of these tightrope-walk matches before he gets to the U.S. Open.\n\n\"No. 1 With a Bullet\" is an old phrase that seemed appropriate again on Thursday: Nadal was going for No. 1, but it was Shapovalov, the youngest of the ATP's young guns, who was carrying the bullets.\n\n-- Citi Open Women's Semis/Final: Catch up on all the action from Citi Open on Tennis Channel Plus.\n\n-- Citi Open Men's Semis/Final: Take a look back at the best matches from the Citi Open with on demand match coverage on Tennis Channel Plus.\n\n-- Azarenka Channel: Enjoy the best moments from Victoria Azarenka on the Azarenka Channel exclusively on Tennis Channel Plus.\n\n-- Sharapova Channel: Gear up for Maria's return to next week's Cincinnati Open with the Sharapova Channel only on Tennis Channel Plus.\n\n-- Get Tennis Channel Plus for 650+ live events all year long.\n\n-- Tennis Channel Plus is available on any streaming device, on mobile, always on the GO (desktop, iOS, Android, Apple TV, Roku and Amazon Fire). "id": "1048441", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 5, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Denis Shapovalov of Canada celebrates winning a point over Rafael Nadal of Spain during round of sixteen play at the Rogers Cup tennis tournament Thursday August 10, 2017 in Montreal. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Paul Chiasson\n\nCanadian teen tennis sensation Denis Shapovalov had the biggest win of his young career on Thursday night when he upset top-seeded Spaniard Rafael Nadal in the round of 16 at the Rogers Cup.\n\nWhile the 18-year-old Richmond Hill, Ont., native's profile -- not to mention his world ranking of 143 -- is sure to climb thanks to his success in Montreal, he's still a relatively new face on the ATP Tour.\n\nHere are five things to help Canadian tennis fans get to know the budding star:\n\nHE'S MADE HISTORY ... A FEW TIMES: The win over Nadal put Shapovalov into the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup, making him the youngest player to advance to the tournament's final eight since Bjorn Borg in 1974. He's also the youngest quarter-finalist ever at an ATP Masters event, the highest level on the pro tour. In 2016, he became just the second Canadian to win the Wimbledon boys singles title. Filip Peliwo in 2012 was the first.\n\n--\n\nHE'S A LEFTY: Like tennis greats John McEnroe, Martina Navratilova, Jimmy Connors and Nadal, Shapovalov is left-handed. But being a southpaw may not give him the same advantage it gave some of his predecessors. Technical advances in rackets and court surfaces as well as a changes in game strategy and the rise of the two-handed backhand have levelled the playing field in recent years.\n\n--\n\nHE'S BEEN COMPARED TO ROGER FEDERER: Tennis analyst Craig O'Shannessy once described the young Canadian as \"a left-handed version of Federer, with that one-handed backhand,\" according to the Telegraph in Britain. O'Shannessy also said there is \"no ceiling\" for Shapovalov, and praised his \"great energy and rapport with the crowd.\" He's certainly made an impression this week in Montreal, with Wayne Gretzky and star swimmer Penny Oleksiak among his boosters in the stands.\n\n--\n\nHE RECENTLY CHANGED COACHES: Before the start of the season, his first full campaign as a pro, Shapovalov split with his coach Adriano Fuorivia, who he had worked with for more than four years. Canadian Davis Cup captain Martin Laurendeau was hired as his replacement. Shapovalov said earlier this year that he and Fuorivia are on good terms despite parting ways. \"Adriano thought that someone with more experience like Marty would be a good benefit to my team,\" he said. \"It was nothing that happened between us, it was just more of a decision that we made together.\"\n\n--\n\nHE'S STILL A KID: Shapovalov showed a flash of immaturity when a ball he carelessly hit in frustration during a Davis Cup match in February struck a chair umpire in the eye. He dealt with the fallout like a man however, making no excuses for the incident, saying he lost control of his emotions and behaved unprofessionally. While he apologized to the umpire, his teammates and tennis fans, the International Tennis Federation didn't let him off the hook. He was fined US$7,000.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-10", "textEnd": 170, "textStart": 155}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T16:28:00Z", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "source": {"uri": "citynews.ca", "title": "CityNews", "id": "2068"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:28:00", "url": "http://www.citynews.ca/2017/08/11/on-the-rise-get-to-know-budding-tennis-rising-star-denis-shapovalov/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8660336", "image": "http://www.citynews.ca/wp-content/blogs.dir/sites/10/2017/08/11/pch151419875_hd.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "16:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

If you'd like to learn more...\n\nThe umbrellas and ponchos came out at the Rogers Cup on Saturday as play was delayed by rain, but nothing could dampen the crowd's enthusiasm for breakout star Denis Shapovalov.\n\n\"Everybody is talking about Denis in Montreal, in Canada, and you know what? Across the world,\" said tournament director Eugene Lapierre.\n\nIn a tournament that boasted some of the biggest names in tennis going in, suddenly Shapovalov is the top story.\n\nStory continues below\n\nREAD MORE: Canada's Denis Shapovalov advances to semifinals after downing Mannarino\n\n\"Now he's just like it, you know?\" said attendee Martine Doiron.\n\n\"To go this far, especially at his age, is impressive. He's having a great run,\" said Colin Morrell, who had traveled from Shapovalov's home province of Ontario for the event.\n\nAt just 18 years old, Shapovalov already has many other young players looking up to him following his historic upset of tennis legend Rafael Nadal.\n\n\"It's very inspiring,\" said Dalhousie University tennis player Aaron Yip. \"It shows that if he can do it, we can do it, too. We just have to work hard.\"\n\nShapovalov mania has even had an effect on ticket sales.\n\n\"Ticket sales were not so bad at the start, [but] now it's even better,\" Lapierre told Global News.\n\nHe added he's certain attendance this year will break the tournament's previous record of 213,000.\n\nREAD MORE: Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov upsets Rafael Nadal at Rogers Cup\n\nFor many tennis fans, the icing on the cake would be a Shapovalov-Federer final.\n\n\"I don't even want to think about it -- that would be so great. promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nFederer is looking for a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open beginning Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old Federer has his longest winning streak since 2012. I still have to work really hard every day.\"\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic, but Zverev was too strong, winning 81 percent of the points off his serve compared to 64 percent for Shapovalov.\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. already out with injuries. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nFederer is looking for a third Rogers Cup title but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old has his longest winning streak since 2012.\n\nIn Sunday's final, he will face the winner of the second semifinal between 18-year-old Denis Shapovalov of Richmond Hill, Ont., and 20-year-old Alexander Zverev of Germany.\n\n\"I think those young players don't quite know what to expect, and (neither) do I, because nobody quite knows,\" said Federer. \"Even though, Zverev is a more experienced player than Shapovalov at this stage.\n\n\"It's a huge opportunity for them. It's exciting. To have a player at 18 or 20 years old in the finals of a Masters 1000 is not something we've seen very often. Very rarely, except maybe when Andy, Novak and Rafa (Nadal) were coming up. They were such great teenagers that we maybe saw it more often. Not even I probably achieved finals of a Masters 1000 at that age. It's very exciting for tennis.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Alexander Zverev ended a dream week for 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the semifinals of the Rogers Cup on Saturday night.\n\nThe fourth-seeded Zverev, seeking a second tournament title in as many weeks, advanced to the final on Sunday against second-seeded Roger Federer, a 6-3, 7-6(5) winner over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands. Federer holds a 2-1 edge in career meetings with the German, including a victory on grass in June.\n\nZverev stretched his match winning run to nine.\n\nShapovalov, who was playing Challenger-level tournaments only two weeks ago, became the youngest player to reach a Masters 1000 Series tournament with a winning run this week that included knocking off top seed Rafael Nadal and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro.\n\nIt will raise his world ranking from 143rd to about 66th. He earned US$220,760 -- more than doubling his career prize money.\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic in the battle of youngsters against the 20-year-old Zverev. But the German was too sharp, winning 81 per cent of the points off his serve compared to 64 per cent for Shapovalov.\n\nShapovalov, of Richmond Hill, Ont., held his serve through a more than 14-minute game early on, but lost it to go down 4-5 in the opening set, double faulting on break point. It was the fourth time in five matches he lost the first set, but this time there was no coming back.\n\nHe wasted two break points at 4-3 in the second, and Zverev was able to get the break for 6-5 after two Shapovalov double faults. It set up a wild final game, with Shapovalov saving two match points and Zverev erasing three break points before it ended with a misfired backhand by the Canadian.\n\nFederer reached his sixth final of the year, and will be seeking a sixth win.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me.\n\n\"If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old, coming off victories in Germany and at Wimbledon, is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nWhoever won the other semifinal, Federer knew he would be facing a much younger opponent.\n\n\"I think those young players don't quite know what to expect, and (neither) do I, because nobody quite knows,\" said Federer. \"Even though, Zverev is a more experienced player than Shapovalov at this stage.\n\n\"It's a huge opportunity for them. It's exciting. To have a player at 18 or 20 years old in the finals of a Masters 1000 is not something we've seen very often. Very rarely, except maybe when Andy, Novak and Rafa (Nadal) were coming up. They were such great teenagers that we maybe saw it more often. Not even I probably achieved finals of a Masters 1000 at that age. It's very exciting for tennis.\n\n\"But even Zverev, same thing. I haven't played him that much yet. Never really on a hard court, except at the Hopman Cup. It will also be a good match to watch, I think.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"\n\nIn a semifinals, seventh-seeded Rohan Bopanna of India and Ivan Dodig of Croatia defeated sixth-seeded Raven Klaasen of the Netherlands and Rajeev Ram of the United States 4-6, 7-6 (8), 11-9; and fifth-seeded Pierre-Hugues Herbert and Nicolas Mahut of France downed eighth-seeded Oliver Marach of Austria and Mate Pavic of Croatia 7-5, 6-3.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 2931, "textStart": 2924}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:52:00Z", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "source": {"uri": "torontosun.com", "title": "Toronto Sun", "id": "2657"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:52:00", "url": "http://www.torontosun.com/2017/08/12/canadas-denis-shapovalov-falls-to-alexander-zverev-in-semifinals?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=recommend-button&utm_campaign=Canada's Denis Shapovalov falls to Alexander Zverev in semifinals", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8864876", "image": "http://storage.torontosun.com/v1/suns-prod-images/1297982038593_LARGE_BOX.jpg?quality=80&stmp=1502592770692", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:52:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Denis Shapovalov's dream week ended, but a rivalry may have been born with rising star Alexander Zverev.\n\nThe stirring comebacks that 18-year-old Shapovalov used to become the youngest player to reach the semifinals of a Masters 1000 Series tournament died out when 20-year-old Zverev proved a little sharper and downed the Richmond Hill, Ont., lefthander 6-4, 7-5 on Saturday night.\n\nOn Saturday night, 20-year-old Alexander Zverev proved a little sharper and downed Shapovalov 6-4, 7-5.\n\nFourth-seeded Zverev, coming off a win last week in Washington, D.C., and seeking a fifth tournament win this year, will face Swiss legend Roger Federer in the final on Sunday. Federer dispatched unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6 (5).\n\n\"Like the media was putting it, it was a dream week for me,\" said Shapovalov. \"Obviously I didn't expect it.\n\n\"I saved four match points the first round (against Rogerio Dutra Silva). I just played loose after that, just went with it. I mean, I beat one of my idols.\"\n\nIndeed, Shapovalov's run included consecutive wins over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro and top-seeded Spanish star Rafael Nadal. The victories, and the shaggy-haired youngster's style and skill on the court, announced his presence not only to Canadian fans but to the tennis world.\n\nWith the win, his world ranking will rise from 143rd to about 67th. The US$220,760 he earned by reaching the semifinals more than doubled his career prize money.\n\n\"My whole life has changed in the past five days,\" he said. \"It's crazy how it is.\n\n\"I mean, I go from being not known to being so known in the tennis world, in Canada in general. It's going to be a little bit of a change to me. I'm going to have to adapt. But that doesn't change things. I still have to work really hard every day.\"\n\nWhen match point landed wide, Zverev told Shapovalov during handshakes at the net that the two are sure to meet again and will likely be rivals for many years. Shapovalov, the 2016 Wimbledon boys champion, hopes that is the case.\n\nZverev told Shapovalov during handshakes at the net that the two are sure to meet again and will likely be rivals for many years.\n\n\"Sascha is an unbelievable player, he's going to be a champion,\" said Shapovalov. \"Hopefully I can get there one day.\n\n\"Hopefully I can get to his level. I mean, he's still better than me. But I'll keep working hard and hopefully we could start a little bit of a rivalry.\"\n\nFederer holds a 2-1 edge in career meetings with the Zverev, including a victory over the German on grass in June.\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic, but the German was too strong, winning 81 per cent of the points off his serve compared to 64 per cent for Shapovalov.\n\nShapovalov held his serve through a more than 14-minute game early on, but lost it to go down 4-5 in the opening set, double faulting on break point. It was the fourth time in five matches he lost the first set, but this time there was no coming back.\n\nHe wasted two break points at 4-3 in the second, and Zverev was able to get the break for 6-5 after two Shapovalov double faults. It set up a wild final game, with Shapovalov saving two match points and Zverev erasing three break points before it ended with a misfired backhand by the Canadian.\n\nFederer reached his sixth final of the year, and will be seeking a sixth win.\n\nFederer reached his sixth final of the year, and will be seeking a sixth win.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me.\n\n\"If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old, coming off victories in Germany and at Wimbledon, is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"\n\nIn doubles semifinals, seventh-seeded Rohan Bopanna of India and Ivan Dodig of Croatia defeated sixth-seeded Raven Klaasen of the Netherlands and Rajeev Ram of the United States 4-6, 7-6 (8), 11-9; and fifth-seeded Pierre-Hugues Herbert and Nicolas Mahut of France downed eighth-seeded Oliver Marach of Austria and Mate Pavic of Croatia 7-5, 6-3.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 4552, "textStart": 4545}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T12:09:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"uri": "huffingtonpost.ca", "title": "The Huffington Post Canada", "id": "355"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:30:00", "url": "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2017/08/13/denis-shapovalov-rogers-cup-semifinals_a_23075991/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8914582", "image": "https://o.aolcdn.com/images/dims3/GLOB/crop/2239x1177+0+34/resize/1200x630!/format/jpg/quality/85/http%3A%2F%2Fo.aolcdn.com%2Fhss%2Fstorage%2Fmidas%2F1b9088d468c2451c25d3fbe889124f27%2F205562814%2FRTS1BKCR.jpeg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "12:09:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL - Alexander Zverev ended a dream week for 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the semifinals of the Rogers Cup on Saturday night.\n\nThe fourth-seeded Zverev, seeking a second tournament title in as many weeks, advanced to the final on Sunday against second-seeded Roger Federer, a 6-3, 7-6(5) winner over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands. Federer holds a 2-1 edge in career meetings with the German, including a victory on grass in June.\n\nZverev stretched his match winning run to nine.\n\nShapovalov, who was playing Challenger-level tournaments only two weeks ago, became the youngest player to reach a Masters 1000 Series tournament with a winning run this week that included knocking off top seed Rafael Nadal and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro.\n\nIt will raise his world ranking from 143rd to about 66th. He earned US$220,760 - more than doubling his career prize money.\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic in the battle of youngsters against the 20-year-old Zverev. But the German was too sharp, winning 81 per cent of the points off his serve compared to 64 per cent for Shapovalov.\n\nShapovalov, of Richmond Hill, Ont., held his serve through a more than 14-minute game early on, but lost it to go down 4-5 in the opening set, double faulting on break point. It was the fourth time in five matches he lost the first set, but this time there was no coming back.\n\nHe wasted two break points at 4-3 in the second, and Zverev was able to get the break for 6-5 after two Shapovalov double faults. It set up a wild final game, with Shapovalov saving two match points and Zverev erasing three break points before it ended with a misfired backhand by the Canadian.\n\nFederer reached his sixth final of the year, and will be seeking a sixth win.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me.\n\n\"If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old, coming off victories in Germany and at Wimbledon, is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nWhoever won the other semifinal, Federer knew he would be facing a much younger opponent.\n\n\"I think those young players don't quite know what to expect, and (neither) do I, because nobody quite knows,\" said Federer. \"Even though, Zverev is a more experienced player than Shapovalov at this stage.\n\n\"It's a huge opportunity for them. It's exciting. To have a player at 18 or 20 years old in the finals of a Masters 1000 is not something we've seen very often. Very rarely, except maybe when Andy, Novak and Rafa (Nadal) were coming up. They were such great teenagers that we maybe saw it more often. Not even I probably achieved finals of a Masters 1000 at that age. It's very exciting for tennis.\n\n\"But even Zverev, same thing. I haven't played him that much yet. Never really on a hard court, except at the Hopman Cup. It will also be a good match to watch, I think.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"\n\nIn a semifinals, seventh-seeded Rohan Bopanna of India and Ivan Dodig of Croatia defeated sixth-seeded Raven Klaasen of the Netherlands and Rajeev Ram of the United States 4-6, 7-6 (8), 11-9; and fifth-seeded Pierre-Hugues Herbert and Nicolas Mahut of France downed eighth-seeded Oliver Marach of Austria and Mate Pavic of Croatia 7-5, 6-3.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 2929, "textStart": 2922}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:51:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"uri": "lethbridgeherald.com", "title": "lethbridgeherald.com", "id": "6076"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:51:00", "url": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/sports/national-sports/2017/08/12/canadas-denis-shapovalov-falls-to-alexander-zverev-in-semifinals-of-rogers-cup/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8864629", "image": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/wp-content/uploads/cp/PCH503420122.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:51:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

knobby-kneed Canadian boy who barely makes it up to the Spaniard's chest. It was 2008. The boy was a star-struck 9-year-old from Ontario named Denis Shapovalov.\n\nBy Friday, that boy had vaulted above his idol's shoulders.\n\nSeemingly overnight, Shapovalov secured a spot in Canadian sports history as the teen from Richmond Hill who went up against a tennis titan and didn't flinch. The world No. 143 beat the world No. 2. Denis \"the Tennis Menace\" was born. The 18-year-old's victory at the Rogers Cup in the Round of 16 wowed the tennis world (sample international headline: \"Nadal upset by Canadian teenager\"). Even Shapovalov's coach seemed a little stunned when the nearly three-hour battle on Centre Court was over.\n\n\"It's a bit surreal to be able to - start to finish - last that long, and produce quality tennis, go toe-to-toe with a legend like that,\" his coach, Martin Laurendeau, said at a news conference at Montreal's Uniprix Stadium. \"It's just remarkable.\"\n\nShapovalov's magic continued on Friday as he overcame a lacklustre opening set to defeat France's Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 to advance to Saturday's semi-final against either Alexander Zverev or Kevin Anderson, who were facing off in the late game.\n\nShapovalov's historic run in Montreal makes him the youngest Masters series quarter- and semi-finalist in tennis history, and has earned him a spot in the constellation of the sport's rising Canadian stars.\n\nTo admirers, he offers a form of fearlessness that kept his nerves steady on Thursday after a first-set loss to Nadal, and again on Friday when facing Mannarino. His all-or-nothing approach, highlighted by nine aces and seven double faults, paid off against the conservative Mannarino, whose consistent, but light-hitting, game was in the end no match for Shapovalov's riskier ways. Tied 4-4 in the third set, Shapovalov converted a crucial break point, allowing him to serve for the match.\n\n\"He revels in that kind of an atmosphere,\" Laurendeau said. \"He's like a fish in water when you put him on a big court against a big player. I don't know if you can teach that. But he has that, and he's making the most of it.\"\n\nShapovalov served notice last summer when he won Junior Wimbledon - something Roger Federer had also done as a teen. Since then, he's had some notable wins earned as a wild-card at ATP events, beating No. 19 Nick Kyrgios at the 2016 Rogers Cup in Toronto and No. 47 Kyle Edmond at Queen's Club.\n\nHe also had a brush with infamy, and for a while was known as the kid who whacked a ball in frustration during a Davis Cup match in February and hit a chair umpire in the eye. The umpire, Arnaud Gabas, required surgery to repair a fractured bone. That outburst earned Shapovalov a $7,000 fine, and it cost Canada the match and a shot at beating Britain.\n\n\"I did a very stupid thing and I'm really embarrassed and ashamed,\" a contrite Shapovalov said at the time.\n\n\"I went into complete shock after I hit it. The worst part was I had no idea how badly I may have hurt him. I've never hurt a single person in my whole life - never even wanted to hurt someone. That was so unprofessional of me. It was such a fluke accident. I promise I am going to mature from it and learn from it.\"\n\nThat display of hot-hotheadedness appears to be behind him. This week at the Rogers Cup, he'd won over not just Wayne Gretzky and Penny Oleksiak, who watched him in the stands in Montreal, but regular fans who gave him a standing ovation.\n\nGretzky, the hockey great, gave Shapovalov his stamp of approval.\n\n\"The great athletes want to be at centre stage. They want to play out here and be under that microscope,\" Gretzky said during a TV interview earlier in the week. \"I think he has ice in his veins and I think he's one of those guys who's going to love the pressure and take on that responsibility.\"\n\nAnother \"Great One\" also endorsed the lefty's skills and potential. Federer, widely considered the greatest tennis player in history, had praise for the teen's game, observing that the Canadian seemed to have \"an extra gear,\" while predicting a bright future for Shapovalov.\n\n\"I like his game. I think he's going to be a wonderful player. Seems to have a good attitude, too,\" Federer said on Friday, after he downed the 12th-ranked Roberto Bautista-Agut in straight sets to advance to the semi-final. \"It was a joy to watch.\"\n\nThe Canadian \"kept moving forward, hitting the ball hard.\" Nadal, Federer added, \"will never give away a match.\"\n\n\"You have to go and earn it. He did it. It's good for him,\" Federer said. \"It's good for tennis too.\"\n\nIt's too soon to say whether the country is witnessing the start of Shapo-mania. Canada has been here before with its tennis darlings. Milos Raonic, currently No. 6 in the world, didn't make his first Grand Slam appearance until he was 20, and didn't crack the top 100 until he was 21. Raonic, who peaked at No. 3 at the end of last season, bowed out in the second round this week.\n\nPerhaps a more cautionary tale is that of Eugenie Bouchard. Bouchard, who climbed as high as the No. 5 ranking on the WTA Tour, has tumbled all the way to No. 70. Though she's still only 23 years old, it serves as a reminder that fast success is not always sustained.\n\nStill, when the teen rolled up in a golf cart for a late-afternoon practice in Montreal on Friday, a sizable crowd gathered to watch him and hope for a chance at an autograph. Shapovalov seemed relaxed as he stepped onto the court under a blazing sun, gave his mother, Tessa, a hug and started hitting. His mother, a former professional player in the Soviet Union who runs a tennis academy in Vaughan, Ont., helped develop her son's talent.\n\nShapovalov may be living his moment in the sun in Montreal, but what's next? Last year, he was crowned Junior Wimbledon champion. This week, he began his run in Montreal with a breakthrough victory over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro, before ending up the youngest player to advance to the tournament's final eight since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nNow he is expected to break into the top 100 after the Montreal tournament.\n\nHis coach is looking at the long term.\n\n\"He's got his identity. He's got his game style. I mean, he's got the strokes to hurt, and he's got the game that's taking shape,\" Laurendeau says. \"But he's got a lot of weapons.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:18:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "id": "1409"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:18:00", "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/how-denis-shapovalov-vaulted-over-his-idol-and-carved-a-spot-in-canadian-sports-history/article35976832/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8732867", "image": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/e93/sports/article35976831.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/shapovalov11sp1.JPG", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:18:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"id": "1278336", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 3, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Any misgivings Roger Federer may have had about playing in the Rogers Cup are behind him now that the Swiss master has reached the final.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer used a 6-3, 7-6 (5) victory over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands on Saturday afternoon to reach his sixth final of the year, where he will be seeking a sixth win.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me.\n\n\"If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old, coming off victories in Germany and at Wimbledon, is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nIn Sunday's final, he will face the winner of the second semi-final between 18-year-old Denis Shapovalov of Richmond Hill, Ont., and 20-year-old Alexander Zverev of Germany.\n\n\"I think those young players don't quite know what to expect, and [neither)] do I, because nobody quite knows,\" said Federer. \"Even though, Zverev is a more experienced player than Shapovalov at this stage.\n\n\"It's a huge opportunity for them. It's exciting. To have a player at 18 or 20 years old in the finals of a Masters 1000 is not something we've seen very often. Very rarely, except maybe when Andy, Novak and Rafa (Nadal) were coming up. They were such great teenagers that we maybe saw it more often. Not even I probably achieved finals of a Masters 1000 at that age. It's very exciting for tennis.\"\n\nEspecially for Shapovalov, who has been on fire all week with wins over Nadal and Juan Martin Del Potro, among others. And the packed Uniprix Stadium grandstands have been aroar when the teenager plays.\n\n\"I guess this is where my experience kicks in,\" said Federer. \"I've seen some great atmospheres over the years.\n\n\"Almost everywhere I've gone, I've been in such close battles, where the crowd goes wild. You just expect that in a finals like this. I know that's not going to be the problem for me. It will be 'what are his serving patterns? What are his shot-making decisions? How much can I focus on my own game? How much does he allow me to play my own game?' The rest happens by itself really at this stage of my career.\n\n\"But even Zverev, same thing. I haven't played him that much yet. Never really on a hard court, except at the Hopman Cup. It will also be a good match to watch, I think.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament. He earned US$220,760.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"\n\nIn a doubles semi-final, seventh-seeded Rohan Bopanna of India and Ivan Dodig of Croatia defeated sixth-seeded Raven Klaasen of the Netherlands and Rajeev Ram of the United States 4-6, 7-6 (8), 11-9.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 1411, "textStart": 1404}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T23:57:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "id": "1409"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:30:00", "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/tennis/federer-tops-haase-to-advance-to-rogers-cup-final/article35977508/", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8857898", "image": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/d66/sports/tennis/article35977507.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/ROGERS-MEN.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "23:57:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"'Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag.'\n\nIMAGE: Roger Federer hits a return. Photograph: Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images\n\nRoger Federer used a dominant service game to beat Dutchman Robin Haase 6-3, 7-6(5) in Montreal on Saturday, setting up a Rogers Cup final against German Alexander Zverev.\n\nHaase, playing in his first ATP World Tour Masters 1000 semi-final, did well to force a second-set tiebreak but Federer proved too much to handle as the Swiss fired down nine aces and dropped only nine points on serve.\n\nFederer, whose five titles this year include the Australian Open and Wimbledon, credited a positive mindset for helping him extend his winning streak to 16 matches.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said the 19-times Grand Slam champion.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nNext up for the Swiss right-hander, who is seeking his third Rogers Cup title after triumphs in Toronto in 2004 and 2006, is Zverev after the fourth seed advanced with a 6-4 7-5 win over Canada's Denis Shapovalov.\n\nFederer owns a 2-1 edge against Zverev in head-to-head meetings, most recently a 6-1, 6-3 win at Halle in June.\n\nZverev ended Shapovalov's magical week on his third match point when the 18-year-old, who had been the story of the tournament after a stunning run that included an upset win over world number two Rafael Nadal, sent a backhand wide.\n\nShapovalov, who was born in Israel and moved to Canada before his first birthday, had a great chance at 4-3 in the second set but failed to convert on his three break points.\n\n\"I wasn't too sharp on the big points,\" said Shapovalov, who made headlines in February for inadvertently blasting a ball into an umpire's face in a fit of rage during a Davis Cup quarter-final.\n\n\"I had a couple looks at some second serves and I missed some returns. "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Alexander Zverev ended a dream week for 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the semifinals of the Rogers Cup on Saturday night.\n\nThe fourth-seeded Zverev, seeking a second tournament title in as many weeks, advanced to the final on Sunday against second-seeded Roger Federer, a 6-3, 7-6(5) winner over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands. Federer holds a 2-1 edge in career meetings with the German, including a victory on grass in June.\n\nZverev stretched his match winning run to nine.\n\nShapovalov, who was playing Challenger-level tournaments only two weeks ago, became the youngest player to reach a Masters 1000 Series tournament with a winning run this week that included knocking off top seed Rafael Nadal and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro.\n\nIt will raise his world ranking from 143rd to about 66th. He earned US$220,760 -- more than doubling his career prize money.\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic in the battle of youngsters against the 20-year-old Zverev. But the German was too sharp, winning 81 per cent of the points off his serve compared to 64 per cent for Shapovalov.\n\nShapovalov, of Richmond Hill, Ont., held his serve through a more than 14-minute game early on, but lost it to go down 4-5 in the opening set, double faulting on break point. It was the fourth time in five matches he lost the first set, but this time there was no coming back.\n\nHe wasted two break points at 4-3 in the second, and Zverev was able to get the break for 6-5 after two Shapovalov double faults. It set up a wild final game, with Shapovalov saving two match points and Zverev erasing three break points before it ended with a misfired backhand by the Canadian.\n\nFederer reached his sixth final of the year, and will be seeking a sixth win.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me.\n\n\"If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old, coming off victories in Germany and at Wimbledon, is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nWhoever won the other semifinal, Federer knew he would be facing a much younger opponent.\n\n\"I think those young players don't quite know what to expect, and (neither) do I, because nobody quite knows,\" said Federer. \"Even though, Zverev is a more experienced player than Shapovalov at this stage.\n\n\"It's a huge opportunity for them. It's exciting. To have a player at 18 or 20 years old in the finals of a Masters 1000 is not something we've seen very often. Very rarely, except maybe when Andy, Novak and Rafa (Nadal) were coming up. They were such great teenagers that we maybe saw it more often. Not even I probably achieved finals of a Masters 1000 at that age. It's very exciting for tennis.\n\n\"But even Zverev, same thing. I haven't played him that much yet. Never really on a hard court, except at the Hopman Cup. It will also be a good match to watch, I think.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"\n\nIn a semifinals, seventh-seeded Rohan Bopanna of India and Ivan Dodig of Croatia defeated sixth-seeded Raven Klaasen of the Netherlands and Rajeev Ram of the United States 4-6, 7-6 (8), 11-9; and fifth-seeded Pierre-Hugues Herbert and Nicolas Mahut of France downed eighth-seeded Oliver Marach of Austria and Mate Pavic of Croatia 7-5, 6-3.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 2931, "textStart": 2924}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:45:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"uri": "montreal.ctvnews.ca", "title": "Montreal", "id": "1064"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:45:00", "url": "http://montreal.ctvnews.ca/canada-s-denis-shapovalov-falls-to-alexander-zverev-in-semifinals-of-rogers-cup-1.3543694", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8864342", "image": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/polopoly_fs/1.3543701.1502590111!/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_620/image.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Swiss looked a little rusty in his second competitive match since Wimbledon. Federer lost his serve three times before winning in three sets.\n\nRoger Federer overcame a third-round blip to beat Spain's David Ferrer in three sets and reach the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup in Montreal.\n\nThe Australian Open and Wimbledon champion trailed for over an hour against his dogged opponent before clawing his way back to record a 4-6 6-4 6-2 victory in an hour and 56 minutes.\n\nFor large spells of the match, the Swiss appeared unusually frustrated, as his first serve dwindled and his much-improved backhand regularly misfired.\n\nHowever, as great champions usually do, the Swiss improved as the match went on and found a way to win.\n\nHe'll now meet another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista Agut, in the last eight.\n\nEmbed from Getty Images\n\nFerrer dominates from the baseline\n\nFederer had dominated the pair's previous meetings, winning all 16 of them while dropping just six sets to the Spaniard.\n\nGoing by that stat, Ferrer's chances were extremely slim, however the Spaniard - who dropped out of the world's top 30 for the first time since 2005 earlier this year - has appeared rejuvenated in recent weeks after winning an ATP 250 title in Bastad last month.\n\nFerrer had also come through two tough matches at this event, beating Britain's Kyle Edmund and world number 17 Jack Sock, and he applied immediate pressure on Federer from the off.\n\nFederer served two double faults in his opening service game but still managed to save three break points to fend off his bullish opponent.\n\nTwo games later, though, Ferrer took his chance, converting his seventh break point in the fourth game before racing into a 5-2 lead.\n\nFerrer's timing from the back of the court was like clockwork in the opening set, as he stepped up onto the baseline and took the match to Federer.\n\nThe Spaniard couldn't serve out the set at the first attempt, however he quickly reapplied the pressure to break Federer again and win the opener in 49 minutes.\n\nEmbed from Getty Images\n\nFederer struggles on serve but finds a way through\n\nFederer took an early lead at the start of the second set, but a loose game - which finished with a missed smash and a double fault- allowed Ferrer to draw level.\n\nThings started to come together for the Swiss midway through the second set, however he was still forced to save two break points when serving at 5-4, before drawing level at a set apiece.\n\nAfter a loose service game at the start of the decider, Ferrer's challenge began to fade.\n\nFederer finally began to hit his spots on serve, while tightening up his game from the back of the court.\n\nPerhaps it was understandable that the Swiss maestro was a little rusty on this occasion, for this was only his second competitive match since winning an unprecedented eighth Wimbledon.\n\nEven so, he will need to improve if he is to win a third title at this event and continue his supremely impressive year.\n\nEmbed from Getty Images", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-10T21:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "source": {"uri": "vavel.com", "title": "VAVEL", "id": "2824"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:19:00", "url": "https://www.vavel.com/en/tennis/815991-federer-comes-through-ferrer-test-to-reach-the-last-eight-at-the-rogers-cup.html", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8548758", "image": "https://img.vavel.com/federer-montrael-183722022.jpg", "date": "2017-08-10", "time": "21:14:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}
