"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backhand", "score": 3, "id": "374056", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Canadian Open (tennis)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Open_(tennis)", "score": 4, "id": "379384", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Adrian Mannarino"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Mannarino", "score": 5, "id": "405343", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kevin Anderson (tennis)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Anderson_(tennis)", "score": 3, "id": "428801", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sascha Zverev"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sascha_Zverev", "score": 3, "id": "1278336", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Diego Schwartzman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Schwartzman", "score": 2, "id": "1339117", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Denis Shapovalov has to come up with some new goals.\n\nThe 18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont., had his sights set on a place in the top 100 in the ATP rankings this year, but a successful run at the Rogers Cup has guaranteed him a place in the mid-60s -- and he's not finished.\n\nShapovalov reached the semifinals of the $4.9-million event Friday night with a 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 win over Adrian Mannarino of France. Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 5-4 lead in the deciding set and then served out the match.\n\nIn Saturday's semifinal, Shapovalov will meet the winner of Friday's late match between fourth-seeded German Alexander Zverev and Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nThe left-handers exchanged service breaks early in the third set. Shapovalov fought off two break points to stay even at 1-1. In the next game, he earned two break points. He put a service return in the net on the first opportunity, but got the break when Mannarino sent a backhand over the baseline. But Mannarino got that one back in the next game. Shapovalov put Mannarino in trouble with a big serve at 30-30, but he rushed an overhead to give the Frenchman the break point.\n\nThe momentum changed in the second set after a brief rain delay halted play for about 10 minutes with Shapovalov holding a 3-2 lead on serve. Because the delay wasn't more than 10 minutes, there was no warm-up for Mannarino and he was broken at 15-40. Shapovalov held his serve the rest of the way to knot the match at a set apiece.\n\nThe first set was a disaster for Shapovalov. He double-faulted twice to give Mannarino a break in the opening game and Mannarino broke him again for a 3-0 lead.\n\nThe first signs of the player who beat Rafael Nadal less than 24 hours earlier came in the fifth game when Shapovalov fought off five break points to win his first game, but Mannarino served out the set.\n\nMeanwhile, Roger Federer continued his pursuit of a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal.\n\nFederer eased into the semifinals with a workmanlike 6-4, 6-4 win over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista-Agut of Spain.\n\nNext up is unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who said he was lucky to come back for a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 win over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nFederer, who is playing his first tournament since winning his eighth Wimbledon title, struggled a bit at the beginning of his Thursday match against Spanish veteran David Ferrer and was forced to play three sets. But he seemed more composed Friday.\n\n\"I believe I served better earlier in the match, but I don't think Bautista-Agut returned as well as Ferrer,\" Federer said. \"Both things combined, two major factors in a beginning of a match, I was able to get into the match better. Of course, it was tough until 4-all. But my game plan worked better against Bautista-Agut than against Ferrer. I believe it's because today I was more aggressive coming to the net.\n\nHaase and Schwartzman were both looking to reach their first semifinal in an ATP Masters 1000 event. Haase said it was difficult for both players after playing tough three-set matches against seeded players earlier in the week.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially yesterday against (seventh-seeded Grigor) Dimitrov,\" Haase said. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level. I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting. You could see that we were both mentally (tired). It took a lot of us. We beat good guys. We've been playing really well. Then to do it on this stage again for your first semis, it's not easy.\"\n\nThe 30-year-old Haase said he always believed he could be competitive at this level, but he had to overcome a serious knee injury early in his career.\n\n\"I didn't even know if I could ever play tennis again,\" Haase said. \"After one-and-a-half years, I got back. I came back really fast, from zero to 60 in eight months. However, from that moment, I wasn't the player I was before my injury. I was not as fast. I was insecure. I had a lot of problems with other injuries after.\n\n\"Then this kind of eats you up inside mentally,\" he said. \"It drains you because you know you can do better, but actually your own body is not letting you. That took me, honestly, a couple of years to get more calm in my head, that I have to deal with it. \"\n\nphickey@postmedia.com\n\nRelated", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:47:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"uri": "montrealgazette.com", "title": "Montreal Gazette", "id": "2649"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:47:00", "url": "http://montrealgazette.com/sports/tennis/wunderkind-denis-shapovalov-blasts-into-rogers-cup-semifinals", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8730647", "image": "http://wpmedia.montrealgazette.com/2017/08/830576580.jpg?w=640", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:47:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

18-year-old from Richmond Hill, Ont., had his sights set on a place in the top 100 in the ATP rankings this year, but a successful run at the Rogers Cup has guaranteed him a place in the mid-60s -- and he's not finished.\n\nShapovalov reached the semifinals of the $4.9-million event Friday night with a 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 win over Adrian Mannarino of France. Shapovalov broke Mannarino to take a 5-4 lead in the deciding set and then served out the match.\n\nIn Saturday's semifinal, Shapovalov will meet the winner of Friday's late match between fourth-seeded German Alexander Zverev and Kevin Anderson of South Africa.\n\nDon't call him #NextGen ! Shapovalov fought off two break points to stay even at 1-1. In the next game, he earned two break points. He put a service return in the net on the first opportunity, but got the break when Mannarino sent a backhand over the baseline. But Mannarino got that one back in the next game. Shapovalov put Mannarino in trouble with a big serve at 30-30, but he rushed an overhead to give the Frenchman the break point.\n\nThe momentum changed in the second set after a brief rain delay halted play for about 10 minutes with Shapovalov holding a 3-2 lead on serve. Because the delay wasn't more than 10 minutes, there was no warm-up for Mannarino and he was broken at 15-40. minutes.\n\nBy clinching his seventh straight win over the Spaniard in the men's singles event, Federer leads the ATP this season with five titles, including two grand slams, and improved his 2017 "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 5, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canada's Denis Shapovalov fined for smashing ball in tennis umpire's eye\n\nCanadian teen tennis sensation Denis Shapovalov had the biggest win of his young career on Thursday night when he upset top-seeded Spaniard Rafael Nadal in the round of 16 at the Rogers Cup.\n\nWhile the 18-year-old Richmond Hill, Ont., native's profile -- not to mention his world ranking of 143 -- is sure to climb thanks to his success in Montreal, he's still a relatively new face on the ATP Tour.\n\nHere are five things to help Canadian tennis fans get to know the budding star:\n\nThe win over Nadal put Shapovalov into the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup, making him the youngest player to advance to the tournament's final eight since Bjorn Borg in 1974. He's also the youngest quarter-finalist ever at an ATP Masters event, the highest level on the pro tour. In 2016, he became just the second Canadian to win the Wimbledon boys singles title. Filip Peliwo in 2012 was the first.\n\nLike tennis greats John McEnroe, Martina Navratilova, Jimmy Connors and Nadal, Shapovalov is left-handed. But being a southpaw may not give him the same advantage it gave some of his predecessors. Technical advances in rackets and court surfaces as well as a changes in game strategy and the rise of the two-handed backhand have levelled the playing field in recent years.\n\nTennis analyst Craig O'Shannessy once described the young Canadian as \"a left-handed version of Federer, with that one-handed backhand,\" according to the Telegraph in Britain. O'Shannessy also said there is \"no ceiling\" for Shapovalov, and praised his \"great energy and rapport with the crowd.\" He's certainly made an impression this week in Montreal, with Wayne Gretzky and star swimmer Penny Oleksiak among his boosters in the stands.\n\nBefore the start of the season, his first full campaign as a pro, Shapovalov split with his coach Adriano Fuorivia, who he had worked with for more than four years. Canadian Davis Cup captain Martin Laurendeau was hired as his replacement. Shapovalov said earlier this year that he and Fuorivia are on good terms despite parting ways. \"Adriano thought that someone with more experience like Marty would be a good benefit to my team,\" he said. \"It was nothing that happened between us, it was just more of a decision that we made together.\"\n\nShapovalov showed a flash of immaturity when a ball he carelessly hit in frustration during a Davis Cup match in February struck a chair umpire in the eye. He dealt with the fallout like a man however, making no excuses for the incident, saying he lost control of his emotions and behaved unprofessionally. While he apologized to the umpire, his teammates and tennis fans, the International Tennis Federation didn't let him off the hook. points on serve.\n\nFederer, who is seeking his third Rogers Cup title after triumphs in Toronto in 2004 and 2006, will face either German Alexander Zverev or Canadian Denis Shapovalov in Sunday's final.\n\nFederer, a 19-times grand-slam champion, whose five titles this year include wins at the Australian Open and Wimbledon, credited a positive mindset for helping him extend his winning streak only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 3, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "After knocking off world No. 2 Rafael Nadal at the Rogers Cup on Thursday night, all eyes are on the teenage tennis phenom from Richmond Hill\n\nThe \"burden of Canada\" Eugenie Bouchard spoke of earlier in the week at Rogers Cup has been placed squarely on the shoulders of Denis Shapovalov. The teenage tennis pheromone seems to be handling the load just fine.\n\nWhile Bouchard was speaking of up and comers on the women's side of the draw, there is no question Shapovalov is this week carrying the torch for all of Canadian tennis - male or female - after his upset of world No. 2 Rafael Nadal in Thursday's round of 16 at the Rogers Cup in Montreal. With Bouchard and leading Canadian men's player Milos Raonic both eliminated, it is safe to say all eyes are on Shapovalov.\n\nThe win Thursday makes the teenager from Richmond Hill, Ont., the youngest Masters series quarter-finalist of all time, and the youngest Rogers Cup quarter finalist since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nAfter dropping the opening set to Nadal, who, with Andy Murray's withdrawal from the W&S Open next week could soon become world. No. 1, Shapovalov stormed back to win the second and third set's 6-4, 7-6 (4).\n\nIt was his second upset in as many days. On Wednesday, the 18-year-old knocked off former top-5 and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro. He'll face the frenchman Adrian Mannarino, world No. 42, in Friday evening's contest. Mannarino knocked off Raonic earlier in the tournament.\n\nAmong Shapovalov's supporters this week has been hockey great Wayne Gretzsky and Canadian olympic swimmer Penny Oleksiak. Gretzky has been court-side for Shapovalov's matches this week, and said he believes the Richmond Hill left-hander has what it takes to be a superstar athlete.\n\n\"The great athletes want to be at center stage. They want to play out here and be under that microscope,\" Gretzky said during a television broadcast. \"I think he has ice in his veins and I think he's one of those guys who's going to love the pressure and take on that responsibility.\"\n\nWho is Denis Shapovalov?\n\nFor a thorough explanation, read Rachel Brady's profile from last summer. In a nutshell, he could be Canada's next-big-thing. Last year he on the junior Wimbledon title before making a name for himself by offing Nick Kyrgios in the round of 64 at last year's Rogers Cup.\n\nHe is the son of Tessa Viktor Shapovalov, who moved to Canada from Tel Avivthe same year Denis was born.\n\nTessa runs an academy in Richmond Hill, which opened in 2012. It's where Shapovalov refined his skills after he making his way onto the Tennis Canada radar at age 9. By 13, it was clear he'd need a team around him to make it to the next level.\n\nBy 2015, he was Canada's U18 national outdoor champion, and by this time last year, he'd won three Futures titles.\n\nHe popped up on the radar again in for less desirable reasons in February, when he was fined $7, 000 for smashing a ball into the eye of umpire Arnaud Gabas during a decisive Davis Cup match, ultimately costing Canada a shot at victory over Great Brittain.\n\nICYMI, Denis Shapovalov hits a ball out of anger that accidentally hits the chair umpire in the eye during @daviscup pic.twitter.com/ZBadhJmnww -- Tennis Channel (@TennisChannel)\n\nFebruary 7, 2017\n\nWhat are his chances?\n\nConsidering the kind of season Nadal is having (which, going by total points is the better than anyone, even Roger Federer) then anything is possible.\n\nIn Mannarino, he he facing a 29-year-old left-handed whose 2017 record is 17-18. Mannarino plays his best tennis on a grass surface, where he boasts a .567 win percentage. On hard courts, he's 7-9 on the season and 75-99 for his career.\n\nShapolvalov's ATP sample size is too small to be a barometer, he has posted a 27-5 record on hard surfaces between his appearances on the Futures and Challenge tours.\n\nPrior to Nadal, he had never faced another lefty at the ATP level. Mannarino's career record against southpaws, meanwhile, is 17-17.\n\nMORE FROM THE GLOBE AND MAIL", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-02-07", "textEnd": 3253, "textStart": 3237}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T14:36:00Z", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "id": "1409"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:36:00", "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/tennis/dennis-shapovalov-rogers-cup/article35959187/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8637670", "image": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/381/sports/article35959235.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/Shapovalov7.JPG", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "14:36:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup", "score": 4, "id": "321521", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nick Kyrgios"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Kyrgios", "score": 3, "id": "350450", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "ATP Challenger Tour"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Challenger_Tour", "score": 1, "id": "359693", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "2009 "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Laurendeau", "score": 4, "id": "1048441", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Denis Shapovalov"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Denis Shapovalov's coach wasn't surprised that the teenager was able to keep his head while upsetting a tennis legend on centre court at the Rogers Cup.\n\nMartin Laurendeau said Friday that he saw it a year ago when Shapovalov beat Australian star Nick Kyrgios in the Rogers Cup first round in Toronto and the 18-year-old's cool head was evident again this week with wins over 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro and former world No.1 Rafael Nadal.\n\n\"All the guys he's played up to, he takes it to them,\" said Laurendeau, who coaches Shapovalov and serves as Canada's Davis Cup captain. \"He revels in that kind of atmosphere.\n\n\"He's like a fish in water when you put him on a big court against a big player. I don't know if you can teach that, but he has that and he's making the most of it.\"\n\nShapovalov, of Richmond Hill, Ont., posted one of the biggest wins in Canadian tennis history when he battled Nadal for two hours 45 minutes on Thursday night and pulled out the victory in a third-set tiebreaker. It was a back-and-forth match, with several break points saved on both sides. Shapovalov fell behind 3-0 in the tiebreaker, but a Nadal double fault and two aces gave the youngster the match.\n\nAt no time did the left-hander show any sign of cracking under the pressure. Instead, he fed off the deafening sound from the sellout crowd of 11,000 that cheered every point he won.\n\n\"It's a bit surreal to be able to, start to finish, last that long, produce quality tennis and go toe-to-toe with a legend like that,\" said Laurendeau. \"It's just remarkable.\n\n\"I'm glad I was there to witness it. I'll remember it for a long time. It will certainly be a reference for him because he still has a lot of steps to go through. That's always going to be there for him, what he's able to do. Just continue to work towards his goal, which is being top 100, top 50, top 10 and, one day, contend for a Grand Slam.\"\n\nHe said Shapovalov is still developing the physical and mental sides of the game. A major test came in February at a Davis Cup World Group series against Britain in Ottawa.\n\nIn a fit of anger, Shapovalov tried to smash a ball into the crowd, but instead struck chair umpire Arnaud Gabas in the face. Gabas needed surgery to repair a broken bone under his left eye. Shapovalov defaulted the match, which cost Canada the series, and was fined US$7,000 by the International Tennis Federation.\n\n\"How he's handled the February incident from the beginning was very impressive from anybody, even a veteran and a mature man, to face the consequences of what happened,\" said Laurendeau. \"I think even more so for a teenager.\n\n\"He's never shied away. The first thing on his mind was to apologize to everybody. He understood the consequences. He manned up. The biggest progress to me is that aspect -- the mental, psychological aspect of his game. I mean, tactically, technically, physically he's improved. His biggest improvement to me has been how he's competing, how he's channelling and managing his emotions.\"\n\nOnly three weeks ago, Shapovalov was winning a Challenger event -- one step below the ATP Tour -- in Gatineau, Que.\n\nHe started the week ranked 143rd in the world, but the first three wins alone put him into the top 100.\n\nBut he will not be an ATP regular quite yet. "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- Alexander Zverev ended a dream week for 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the semifinals of the Rogers Cup on Saturday night.\n\nThe fourth-seeded Zverev, seeking a second tournament title in as many weeks, advanced to the final on Sunday against second-seeded Roger Federer, a 6-3, 7-6(5) winner over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands. Federer holds a 2-1 edge in career meetings with the German, including a victory on grass in June.\n\nZverev stretched his match winning run to nine.\n\nShapovalov, who was playing Challenger-level tournaments only two weeks ago, became the youngest player to reach a Masters 1000 Series tournament with a winning run this week that included knocking off top seed Rafael Nadal and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro.\n\nIt will raise his world ranking from 143rd to about 66th. He earned US$220,760 -- more than doubling his career prize money.\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium were hoping for more magic in the battle of youngsters against the 20-year-old Zverev. But the German was too sharp, winning 81 per cent of the points off his serve compared to 64 per cent for Shapovalov.\n\nShapovalov, of Richmond Hill, Ont., held his serve through a more than 14-minute game early on, but lost it to go down 4-5 in the opening set, double faulting on break point. It was the fourth time in five matches he lost the first set, but this time there was no coming back.\n\nHe wasted two break points at 4-3 in the second, and Zverev was able to get the break for 6-5 after two Shapovalov double faults. It set up a wild final game, with Shapovalov saving two match points and Zverev erasing three break points before it ended with a misfired backhand by the Canadian.\n\nFederer reached his sixth final of the year, and will be seeking a sixth win.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray as well as Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. But Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me.\n\n\"If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old, coming off victories in Germany and at Wimbledon, is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nWhoever won the other semifinal, Federer knew he would be facing a much younger opponent.\n\n\"I think those young players don't quite know what to expect, and (neither) do I, because nobody quite knows,\" said Federer. \"Even though, Zverev is a more experienced player than Shapovalov at this stage.\n\n\"It's a huge opportunity for them. It's exciting. To have a player at 18 or 20 years old in the finals of a Masters 1000 is not something we've seen very often. Very rarely, except maybe when Andy, Novak and Rafa (Nadal) were coming up. They were such great teenagers that we maybe saw it more often. Not even I probably achieved finals of a Masters 1000 at that age. It's very exciting for tennis.\n\n\"But even Zverev, same thing. I haven't played him that much yet. Never really on a hard court, except at the Hopman Cup. It will also be a good match to watch, I think.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"\n\nIn a semifinals, seventh-seeded Rohan Bopanna of India and Ivan Dodig of Croatia defeated sixth-seeded Raven Klaasen of the Netherlands and Rajeev Ram of the United States 4-6, 7-6 (8), 11-9; and fifth-seeded Pierre-Hugues Herbert and Nicolas Mahut of France downed eighth-seeded Oliver Marach of Austria and Mate Pavic of Croatia 7-5, 6-3.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 2931, "textStart": 2924}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:25:00Z", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "source": {"uri": "toronto.ctvnews.ca", "title": "Toronto", "id": "3006"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:25:00", "url": "http://toronto.ctvnews.ca/shapovalov-loses-rogers-cup-semifinal-match-to-germany-s-zverev-1.3543704", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8863356", "image": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/polopoly_fs/1.3543698.1502589896!/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_620/image.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:25:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

German Alexander Zverev.\n\nHaase, playing in his first ATP World Tour Masters 1000 semi-final, did well to force a second-set tiebreak but Federer proved too much to handle as the Swiss fired down nine aces and dropped only nine points on serve.\n\nFederer, whose five titles this year include the Australian Open and Wimbledon, credited a positive mindset for helping him extend his winning streak to 16 matches.\n\n\"Confidence can get you a long way, and if you're feeling fine physically and you are ready to fight mentally you have a lot of things in the bag,\" said the 19-times grand slam champion.\n\n\"And then the only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. It's all about the matches at some stage.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nNext up for the Swiss right-hander, who is seeking his third Rogers Cup title after triumphs in Toronto in 2004 and 2006, is Zverev after the fourth seed advanced with a 6-4 7-5 win over Canada's Denis Shapovalov.\n\nFederer owns a 2-1 edge against Zverev in head-to-head meetings, most recently a 6-1 6-3 win at Halle in June.\n\nZverev ended Shapovalov's magical week on his third match point when the 18-year-old, who had been the story of the tournament after a stunning run that included an upset win over world number two Rafael Nadal, sent a backhand wide.\n\nShapovalov, who was born in Israel and moved to Canada before his first birthday, had a great chance at 4-3 in the second set but failed to convert on his three break points.\n\n\"I wasn't too sharp on the big points,\" said Shapovalov, who made headlines in February for inadvertently blasting a ball into an umpire's face in a fit of rage during a Davis Cup quarter-final.\n\n\"I had a couple looks at some second serves and I missed some returns. Bautista-Agut as he inched closer to his sixth title of the season with a 6-4, 6-4 win in the quarterfinals of the Montreal Masters on Friday.\n\nFederer hammered five aces, made just two double faults and won 81% of his first serve points in the 68-minute centre court match. He dominated at the net, winning 21 of 25 points.\n\nFederer posted his seventh consecutive win over the Spaniard and improved his season record to 34-2. He has a ATP Tour high five titles in 2017.\n\nFederer has an opportunity to regain his World No.1 ranking. He would need to win here and have an equal or better finish than Rafael Nadal at the Western & Southern Open in Cincinnati next week to become the World No.1 on Aug. 21.\n\nFederer will next face Robin Haase of the Netherlands, who defeated Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 earlier in the day.\n\nIt will be just the second career meeting between the two. The pair met in a Davis Cup World Group play-off in 2012 with Federer winning 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.\n\nDenis Shapovalov continued his dream run on Friday by rallying to beat Frenchman Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.\n\nMannarino became the fourth established ATP player this week to fall at the hands of the 18-year-old left-handed Canadian.\n\nShapovalov's win over Mannarino came just 24 hours after he defeated 10-time French Open champion Nadal to get into the quarters. Shapovalov also upset former US Open winner Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round.\n\nFourth seeded Alexander Zverev defeated South Africa's Kevin Anderson in straight sets 7-5, 6-4 to set up a clash of rising stars with Shapovalov.\n\nZverev, 20, is the youngest player ranked in the top 20 in the world and Shapovalov is the youngest since 1990 to reach a Masters 1000 quarterfinal.\n\nIn doubles, Rohan Bopanna and Ivan Dodig powered past Gael Monfils and Benoit Paire of France 6-2, 7-5 in the quarterfinals.\n\nA marathon\n\nAt the Toronto WTA event, Caroline Wozniacki defeated World No.1 Karolina Pliskova 7-5, 6-7(3) 6-4 in a marathon quarterfinals match marred by four rain delays.\n\nThe victory marks Wozniacki's first career win against a No.1 and gives the 27-year-old a 6-2 advantage in head-to-head matches with Pliskova.\n\nWozniacki next faces Sloane Stephens after the American beat Czech Lucie Safarova 6-2, 1-6, 7-5.\n\nThe results:\n\nQuarterfinals: At Montreal: Robin Haase bt Diego Schwartzman 4-6, 6-3, 6-3; Roger Federer bt Roberto Bautista-Agut 6-4, 6-4; Denis Shapovalov bt Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4; Alexander Zverev bt Kevin Anderson 7-5, 6-4. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Donaldson", "score": 1, "id": "1339257", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Andy Murray will remain number one for another week after 18-year-old Canadian Denis Shapovalov stunned Rafael Nadal at the Rogers Cup.\n\nThe top seed needed to reach the semi-finals to replace the injured Murray at the top of the rankings this week but was beaten in a thrilling last-16 tie against the world number 143.\n\nShapovalov delighted the home crowd late in the night in Montreal as he recorded a 3-6 6-4 7-6 (7/4) victory in two hours 45 minutes.\n\nThe youngster responded impressively to Nadal easing through the first set to force a decider, where Shapovalov saved three break points before winning an epic 14-minute third game, which included 10 deuces.\n\nThe pair continued to trade games up until a tie-break, where Nadal saw a 3-0 lead evaporate by the first change of ends.\n\nHe edged ahead again but Shapovalov won the next three points to bring up match point, which he took at the first attempt with a forehand winner.\n\nNadal will overtake Murray in the rankings after next week's Cincinnati Masters, but faces a challenge from Roger Federer, who could prevent the Spaniard reaching top spot for the first time since 2014.\n\nFederer saw his streak of winning 32 consecutive sets end against David Ferrer but bounced back to reach the last eight.\n\nWimbledon champion Federer, who celebrated his 36th birthday on Tuesday, prevailed 4-6 6-4 6-2 in just under two hours in Montreal.\n\nFerrer took the first set 6-4 against world number three, who had not dropped a set since his shock defeat to Tommy Haas at the Mercedes Cup in June.\n\nBut Federer, a three-time winner of the tournament, recovered to seal a last-eight clash against of sixteen play at the Rogers Cup tennis tournament Thursday August 10, 2017 in Montreal. (THE CANADIAN PRESS/Paul Chiasson)\n\nCanadian teen tennis sensation Denis Shapovalov had the biggest win of his young career on Thursday night when he upset top-seeded Spaniard Rafael Nadal in the round of 16 at the Rogers Cup.\n\nWhile the 18-year-old Richmond Hill, Ont., native's profile -- not to mention his world ranking of 143 -- is sure to climb thanks to his success in Montreal, he's still a relatively new face on the ATP Tour.\n\nHere are five things to help Canadian tennis fans get to know the budding star:\n\nHE'S MADE HISTORY ... A FEW TIMES: The win over Nadal put Shapovalov into the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup, making him the youngest player to advance to the tournament's final eight since Bjorn Borg in 1974. He's also the youngest quarter-finalist ever at an ATP Masters event, the highest level on the pro tour. In 2016, he became just the second Canadian to win the Wimbledon boys singles title. Filip Peliwo in 2012 was the first.\n\nHE'S A LEFTY: Like tennis greats John McEnroe, Martina Navratilova, Jimmy Connors and Nadal, Shapovalov is left-handed. But being a southpaw may not give him the same advantage it gave some of his predecessors. Technical advances in rackets and court surfaces as well as a changes in game strategy and the rise of the two-handed backhand have levelled the playing field in recent years.\n\nHE'S BEEN COMPARED TO ROGER FEDERER: Tennis analyst Craig O'Shannessy once described the young Canadian as \"a left-handed version of Federer, with that one-handed backhand,\" according to the Telegraph in Britain. O'Shannessy also said there is \"no ceiling\" for Shapovalov, and praised his \"great energy and rapport with the crowd.\" He's certainly made an impression this week in Montreal, with Wayne Gretzky and star swimmer Penny Oleksiak among his boosters in the stands.\n\nHE RECENTLY CHANGED COACHES: Before the start of the season, his first full campaign as a pro, Shapovalov split with his coach Adriano Fuorivia, who he had worked with for more than four years. Canadian Davis Cup captain Martin Laurendeau was hired as his replacement. Shapovalov said earlier this year that he and Fuorivia are on good terms despite parting ways. \"Adriano thought that someone with more experience like Marty would be a good benefit to my team,\" he said. \"It was nothing that happened between us, it was just more of a decision that we made together.\"\n\nHE'S STILL A KID: Shapovalov showed a flash of immaturity when a ball he carelessly hit in frustration during a Davis Cup match in February struck a chair umpire in the eye. He dealt with the fallout like a man however, making no excuses for the incident, saying he lost control of his emotions and behaved unprofessionally. While he apologized to the umpire, his teammates and tennis fans, the International Tennis Federation didn't let him off the hook. He was fined US$7,000.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-10", "textEnd": 171, "textStart": 156}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T16:09:00Z", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "title": "CTV News", "id": "30"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:09:00", "url": "http://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/on-the-rise-get-to-know-canadian-rising-tennis-star-denis-shapovalov-1.3541841", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8656442", "image": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/polopoly_fs/1.3541853.1502466725!/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_620/image.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "16:09:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Canada.\n\nThe Spaniard, who is the top seed at the tournament, was in complete control and raced to a 5-0 lead in the first set before Coric held a serve. However, the 18-year-old fought back and showed he is ready for tough tests when he saved five break points at 5-5 in the second set before winning the match 4-6, 7-6(8), 6-4.\n\nIn the second round, Shapovalov faced one of the biggest tests of his career against former US Open champions Juan Martin del Potro. "1278336", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "#Denis Shapovalov is the toast of Montreal for a night as he defeated Rafael Nadal on Thursday at the 2017 #Rogers Cup. It will be interesting to see how Shapovalov approaches his next match. On the one hand, he did beat the World No. 2 on Thursday. But on the contrary, it was just in the round of sixteen of a Masters Series event. A lot of players that pull off big early-round upsets often go out in the next round ahead of getting big-time ranking points. Shapovalov will certainly have to stay focused on Friday if he is to advance to the semifinals.\n\n#The Canadian will face Adrian Mannarino, a name that not a lot of Canadian tennis fans will know.\n\nMannarino, at the age of 29, is a well-established veteran on tour. He has been a bit of a journeyman who has struggled to keep his ranking high at times. However, a couple of months ago he appeared to figure something out. He made the final of a grass-court event in Turkey ahead of making the Wimbledon fourth round.\n\nLast week he played well down in Los Cabos before falling in a well-contested match to Tomas Berdych. Now Mannarino is into the Montreal quarters with the distinguished form at the tournament. He has not dropped a set nor has anyone extended him to a tiebreaker so far this week. Mannarino was able to break Milos Raonic, and the French national will almost certainly defeat Shapovalov on Friday if the 18-year-old is too busy relishing in his Nadal victory instead of focusing on the match at hand.\n\nWith an appearance in the quarterfinals of the Rogers Cup, the Canadian is now threatening the top 100 on tour. But his draw is still active in Montreal, and that means that there is plenty of room to grow. With a win on Friday, he would threaten the top 70, and that would mean not needing a wild card or a qualifying draw for entry into the Grand Slams. Furthermore, it would also mean being a high seed in any challenger events that he participates in and getting a direct entry into scores of tour-level tournaments. In effect, there is a ton on the line for him on Friday.\n\nShapovalov's ceiling in the rankings to come on Monday is actually something close to a top-30 ranking. If he can beat Mannarino, then the Canadian will be looking at a semifinal against either Alexander Zverev or Kevin Anderson. Certainly the former is the beast on top of the draw now that Nadal has gone out. But Zverev and Anderson were the finalists last week in Washington. These are two players that might be running out of gas right now as they have logged a lot of matches and court mileage in recent days. Shapovalov can do more than just dream about a spot in the final against Roger Federer. Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nRafael Nadal admitted his defeat to wildcard Denis Shapovalov at the Rogers Cup in Montreal was his 'worst of the year'.\n\nWorld number two Nadal took the first set comfortably but was helpless to prevent 18-year-old Shapovalov from springing a huge upset.\n\nWhy no-one can stop the Premier League title from heading back to Manchester this season\n\nNadal's defeat means Andy Murray hangs on to his world number one ranking for one more week until the Cincinnati Masters, where Nadal or Roger Federer will overtake him.\n\nSpeaking after the 3-6 6-4 7-6 (6-4) upset, Nadal said: 'It's my worst loss of the year because it's my loss to the opponent with the lowest ranking and because I had the chance to be world number one.\n\nAnd the crowd goes WILD.\n\nSensational get from the 18-year-old.#CoupeRogers pic.twitter.com/5Exxh1EdRY\n\n-- Tennis TV (@TennisTV) August 11, 2017\n\n'Denis played well, he has great potential and I wish him all the best.\n\n'He has everything to become a great player. He played with the right determination in the important moments.'\n\nShapovalov was almost caught speechless after the biggest win of his fledgling career but gathered himself to reflect on a quite sensational comeback.\n\n'This is what I've dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa, Roger, Andy,' the teenager said.\n\n'You know, my dream came true today.'\n\nWimbledon champion Federer will join Shapovalov in the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup after he came from a set behind to beat Spaniard David Ferrer.\n\nThe Swiss legend said: 'I actually feel really happy because I know I can play a lot better. David could have played better, too.\n\n'We battled and both tried to find a way to win. "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nMONTREAL (AP) -- Roger Federer advanced to the Rogers Cup final with a 6-3, 7-6 (5) victory over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands on Saturday.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title to go with wins in 2004 and 2006. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nIn Sunday's final, the Swiss veteran will face the winner of the second semifinal between 18-year-old Denis Shapovalov and 20-year-old Alexander Zverev.\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. followed his upset of Rafael Nadal with another three-set victory to put him in the the semifinals of the Rogers Cup, where he will be joined by Roger Federer.\n\nThe 18-year-old left-hander, now from Richmond Hill, Ontario beat France's Adrian Mannarino 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 and will face fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev of Germany on Saturday.\n\nShapovalov beat 2009 US Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round and then knocked off the top-seeded Nadal in a third-set tiebreaker on Thursday in the round of 16.\n\nHe broke service for a 2-1 lead in the third set Friday only to hand it back in the next game, but a roar went up when Mannarino wasted a chance to put away a game point and Shapovalov jumped on the chance to break for a 5-4 lead. He leapt in the air as he closed out the match.\n\nAdrian Mannarino of France congratulates Denis Shapovalov of Canada on his 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 victory during day eight of the Rogers Cup presented by National Bank at Uniprix Stadium on August 11, 2017 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. (Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images/AFP)\n\n\"I've been against the wall a couple times this week and I'm very happy I've come out several times just playing really good tennis in those situations,\" said Shapovalov, who moved with his family to Canada before his first birthday. \"I think it really shows how I've improved mentally, along with just finding my game at the right moments.\"\n\nAfter facing a run of veterans, he will be up against the 20-year-old Zverev, who beat Kevin Anderson of South Africa 7-5, 6-4.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer continued his mastery over 12th-seeded Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain with a 6-4, 6-4 victory. The 36-year-old Swiss will next face unseeded Dutchman Robin Haase, a 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Diego Schwartzman of Argentina.\n\nRoger Federer of Switzerland hits a return against Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain during day eight of the Rogers Cup presented by National Bank at Uniprix Stadium on August 11, 2017 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. (Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images/AFP)\n\nFederer has won all seven career matches and taken all 16 sets against the 29-year-old Bautista Agut. He is 1-0 against Haase after a straight-sets win in Davis Cup play in 2012.Federer said he knows Haase well from serving with him on the ATP player council and from practicing together.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to a tough match because he can serve very well and he mixes up his tactics a lot,\" Federer said. \"Sometimes he tends to just roll the ball in and use the big serve, or he uses a slice a lot and comes in.\n\n\"So I don't quite know with Robin what I'm going to get. But, as I have practiced with him quite a bit, maybe I am better prepared than if I would have never hit with him before.\"\n\nFederer broke serve for a 5-4 lead in the first set and broke again for 2-1 in the second en route to the victory in a little more than an hour. Federer was coming off a three-set win over another Spaniard, David Ferrer, against whom he is 17-0.\n\n\"My game plan worked better against Bautista Agut than against Ferrer,\" he said. \"I believe it's because I was more aggressive coming to the net.\"\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, reached his first career Masters Series semifinal. The 30-year-old Haase, back to 52nd in the world after battling injuries for much of his career, improved to 5-0 against 36th-ranked Schwartzman.\n\n\"I played a lot of good matches, especially against Dimitrov,\" said Haase. \"It's tough to come back and play that same level.\n\n\"I didn't, but I managed to win because I kept fighting.\"\n\nIsrael-born Denis Shapovalov of Canada celebrates his victory over Rafael Nadal of Spain during day seven of the Rogers Cup on August 10, 2017 in Montreal, Canada. (Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images/AFP)\n\nShapovalov was born in Tel Aviv to parents who had immigrated from the former Soviet Union. His mother Tessa, who has also been his coach for much of his budding career, is a Russian Catholic and his father is Jewish.\n\nDenis Shapovalov of Canada reaches for the ball against Rafael Nadal of Spain during day seven of the Rogers Cup on August 10, 2017 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. (Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images/AFP)\n\nHis victory over Nadal earned him big headlines in Canada, with the Montreal Gazette declaring, \"Star is born.\"\n\nDenis Shapovalov of Canada falls to the ground after his victory over Rafael Nadal of Spain during day seven of the Rogers Cup at Uniprix Stadium on August 10, 2017 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. Shapovalov defeated Nadal 6-3, 4-6, 6-7. (Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images/AFP)\n\nShapovalov battled back after Nadal cruised through the first set, then erased a 3-0 deficit in the tiebreaker for the biggest victory of his career.\n\nRafael Nadal of Spain congratulates Denis Shapovalov of Canada for his victory during day seven of the Rogers Cup at Uniprix Stadium on August 10, 2017 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. Denis Shapovalov of Canada defeated Rafael Nadal of Spain 6-3, 4-6, 6-7. (Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images/AFP)\n\nShapovalov became the youngest player to reach the tournament's quarterfinals since Bjorn Borg in 1974. With hockey great Wayne Gretzky and Olympic swimming star Penny Oleksiak cheering for him from the seats, he also became the youngest quarterfinalist at a Masters Series tournament ever and is the youngest to beat a player ranked in the top two in the world since Nadal beat Federer in 2004 in Miami.\n\n\"He played well,\" Nadal said. \"He has a great potential.\n\n\"I wish him the best. He has everything to become a great player. his bid alive for a first title in Montreal, improving his 2017 hard-court record to 21-1 and bumping his overall win streak to 14 straight. Meeting for the first time in three years, Federer extended his impressive FedEx ATP Head2Head advantage over Ferrer to 17-0.\n\n\"I already beat other players 17 times,\" said Federer. \"Sometimes I played them maybe 30 or 40 times. They ended up beating me at a certain stages, like Roddick, Gonzalez and Soderling. Sometimes I beat them 10 times in a row. At the end they always ended up beating me. That's why I have a lot of respect for this match today. I know it can't continue that way. 17 is a lot.\n\n\"The last match we played were three tight sets in Toronto, then three sets Cincinnati, and again today. So these statistics are a bit ridiculous, because I have a lot of respect for David. As a person, he's very nice. He's a great fighter on the court. So this type of head-to-head is a bit strange.\"\n\nFerrer was on the front foot throughout the opener and he would halt Federer's dominant sets-won streak at 32. The ruthless run began in the first round of the Gerry Weber Open in Halle and included his title at Wimbledon and straight-set win over Peter Polansky on Wednesday.\n\nStriking his forehand with great depth and relying on an efficient first serve, Ferrer was unflappable in closing out the 43-minute opener. The Spaniard, who is in top form after claiming his 27th ATP World Tour title two weeks ago in Bastad, struck a deep, penetrating return to snatch the initial break for 3-1. Serving for the first set at 5-4, he would fire a return at Federer's feet, which the Swiss hit into the net. The second seed struck an uncharacteristic 19 unforced errors in the first set, but the tide would take an abrupt turn in the second. After exchanging early breaks, Federer rediscovered his groove, surging ahead with another break in the fifth game.\n\nFederer's Most Dominant Rivalries\n\nComing forward more often and playing more aggressive, vintage Federer tennis, the Swiss would turn aside a set point at 5-3 and force a decider in the next game. He would pull away from then on, breaking twice in the third and closing out a spot in the quarter-finals with a volley winner on his first match point.\n\n\"For me it was more of a struggle,\" Federer said about the match. \"As you know, you don't always feel the same and each opponent is a different problem. He started very well, especially on the return on my second serve. I was not able to serve my first serve where I wanted to, and he hurt me on the second serve.\n\n\"From the baseline, I didn't have enough rhythm. The court is fast here. Of course, because of the surface, that it's fast, you can't just decide to put the ball in because physically David is very strong. You can't do that. You have to go into the battle. You have to accept you're going to make mistakes. But you have to keep moving forward.\n\n\"I tried with my intensity and focus to change the match, and this is what I was able to do. I was able also to change the angles, and that helped me win the match.\"\n\nA two-time champion at the Canadian ATP World Tour Masters 1000 event (2004 & '06 in Toronto), Federer advanced to the quarter-finals in Montreal for the first time since 2009. He will next face Roberto Bautista Agut, after the 12th seed edged Gael Monfils 4-6, 7-6(5), 7-6(2) earlier on Thursday. Federer owns a 6-0 edge in their FedEd ATP Head2Head, most recently prevailing at the Masters 1000 event in Miami earlier this year.\n\n\"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. He had a good start, I had a better finish. That was important. For me, take it how it is and hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David today.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-10T21:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "source": {"uri": "atpworldtour.com", "title": "ATP World Tour", "id": "9695"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:19:00", "url": "http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/montreal-2017-thursday-federer-bautista-agut", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8548733", "image": "www.atpworldtour.com/-/media/images/news/2017/08/10/22/20/montreal-2017-thursday-federer2.jpg", "date": "2017-08-10", "time": "21:14:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

only thing that maybe is missing is practice, but sometimes practice is overrated. Zverev ended a dream week for 18-year-old Denis Shapovalov with a 6-4, 7-5 victory in the semifinals of the Rogers Cup on Saturday night.\n\nThe fourth-seeded Zverev, seeking a second tournament title in as many weeks, advanced to the final on Sunday against second-seeded Roger Federer, a 6-3, 7-6(5) winner over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands. Federer holds a 2-1 edge in career meetings with the German, including a victory on grass in June.\n\nZverev stretched his match winning run to nine.\n\nShapovalov, who was playing Challenger-level tournaments only two weeks ago, became the youngest player to reach a Masters 1000 Series tournament with a winning run this week that included knocking off top seed Rafael Nadal and 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin del Potro.\n\nIt will raise his world ranking from 143rd to about 66th. He also earned $220,760 U.S., more than doubling his career prize money.\n\nFlag-waving fans in the packed grandstands at Uniprix Stadium had hoped for more magic in the battle of youngsters against the 20-year-old Zverev, but the German was too sharp, winning 81 per cent of the points off his serve compared to 64 per cent for Shapovalov.\n\nShapovalov, from Richmond Hill, Ont., held his serve through a more than 14-minute game early on, but lost it to go down 4-5 in the opening set, double faulting on break point. It was the fourth time in five matches he lost the first set, but this time there was no coming back.\n\nHe wasted two break points at 4-3 in the second, and Zverev was able to get the break for 6-5 after two Shapovalov double faults. It set up a wild final game, with Shapovalov saving two match points and Zverev erasing three break points before it ended with a misfired backhand by the Canadian.\n\nFederer reached his sixth final of the year, and will be seeking a sixth win.\n\nHe had considering skipping the event, which would have been disastrous for the promoters with world No. 1 Andy Murray, Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka already out with injuries. However, Federer decided to play and now has a chance to add to a tally that includes Australian Open and Wimbledon titles this year.\n\n\"I'm very happy that I've made it here,\" he said. \"It was a good decision for me.\n\n\"If I would have known I would have gone to the finals, I would have said 'yes' right away. Sometimes you've just got to wait and see how you feel. I'm most happy that I'm actually really healthy going into the finals. I haven't wasted too much energy. I've been able to keep points short. I've been really clean at net. I think my concentration and just my playing has gone up a notch. I'm just playing better.\"\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title, but his first in Montreal, having won in 2004 and 2006 in Toronto. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old, coming off victories in Germany and at Wimbledon, is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament.\n\n\"I hope it gives me a lot of confidence,\" Haase said of his performance for the week. \"Next week (in Cincinnati), different conditions, different courts, so it's tournament by tournament. But, in general, to make an achievement like this is good because it shows you can do it.\"\n\nIn a semifinals, seventh-seeded Rohan Bopanna of India and Ivan Dodig of Croatia defeated sixth-seeded Raven Klaasen of the Netherlands and Rajeev Ram of the United States 4-6, 7-6 (8), 11-9; and fifth-seeded Pierre-Hugues Herbert and Nicolas Mahut of France downed eighth-seeded Oliver Marach of Austria and Mate Pavic of Croatia 7-5, 6-3.\n\n-- Bill Beacon, The Canadian Press", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "textEnd": 2923, "textStart": 2916}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:34:00Z", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "source": {"uri": "ottawacitizen.com", "title": "Ottawa Citizen", "id": "1720"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:34:00", "url": "http://ottawacitizen.com/sports/tennis/canadian-denis-shapovalov-ousted-in-rogers-cup-tennis-semifinals", "storyUri": "eng-3353129", "id": "8863739", "image": "http://wpmedia.ottawacitizen.com/2017/08/ten-rogers-cup-men-20170812.jpg?w=640", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:34:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

the head-to-head I have against David because I have so much respect for him.\"\n\nFederer said he goes out to win every match he plays, but admitted there were times when he felt sorry for his opponents.\n\n\"In the juniors, yeah (and) probably my two times when I beat (Marco) Chiudinelli, because we grew up together in Basel, we played soccer against each other,\" Federer said. \"We were best friends way back when. We played twice on the Tour, once in Qatar, once in Basel in our home tournament, in the semis. Both times I won, I was like, ah, s-t. I wished he won as well because it would have done much more for his career than for me. \"Yeah, in the juniors, I just felt sometimes when I used to play guys, you know, somewhere in the world where I felt like technically maybe they were struggling. I just felt like, oh, he's trying so hard, he's such a fighter,\" Federer said. \"I don't know, I feel like probably he works harder than I do, so he probably deserves it more. Then he beat me and I'm like, I feel so bad. I'm such an idiot for falling into that trap.\n\n\"Ever since I came on Tour, I just feel like you go out there, try your best,\" he added. \"Afterward, if everything's relaxed, again after the match, you can go for coffee or whatever you want to do. {"eng": "Bill Stoneman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Stoneman", "score": 4, "id": "1331317", "type": "person"}], "body": "MONTREAL -- It was not quite 10 minutes after he had kissed the blue court, thanked the Montreal crowd and waved to his mother - who anxiously sat in the corner, behind the baseline and above the wall. It was not long after he'd left the court, to the kind of thunderous roar that Jarry Park had reserved for a Bill Stoneman no-hitter or Gary Carter home runs. It was not quite 11:00 on Thursday evening, after he'd passed the throng of hundreds waiting for him along the outdoor concourse, through a dark tunnel into an indoor building and a plush, empty, carpeted locker room.\n\nIt was not quite 10 minutes after the greatest accomplishment of Denis Shapovalov's young life that this 18-year-old stood shirtless in the middle of that locker room with his physiotherapist, Nick Martichenko, his coach, Martin Laurendeau, and Canadian Olympic doctor, Nick Sauve, and breathlessly wondered aloud, \"What the hell just happened?\"\n\nAnd nobody in the room could really answer his question.\n\n\"You told me you like sushi,\" Laurendeau told him, holding two containers of rolls and sashimi.\n\nShapovalov grabbed one of the boxes and went into the back shower area for a 15-minute ice-bath session as part of his recovery. Martichenko followed him. The sounds of laughter and joy came from that adjacent room, while the coach and Sauve tried to put into context what they'd just witnessed.\n\nLaurendeau: \"Doc, he just took it to him and took his chances and pulled the triggers. And he went for it.\"\n\nSauve smiled.\n\nLaurendeau continued. \"How many times was Shapo in the hole? In trouble? Break points. That game at one-all in the third set, I mean, how long did it go?\"\n\nOver 14 minutes.\n\n\"Unbelievable,\" Laurendeau said, shaking his head. \"That was Maddux versus Jeter at the plate. Thirty-two pitches. Unbelievable. I just don't know what to say.\"\n\nJust down the hall, Nick Kyrgios did. He'd watched the final match of the night in its entirety. After it was done he walked through the players' lounge, a beer lifted in the air and chanted \"SHA-POH-VAH-LOV.\" Then he got everyone's attention and yelled, \"Here's to Denis!\"\n\nMeanwhile, back beside the locker room, Shapovalov sat in that ice bath, trying to get his legs back, not touching the sushi, checking his phone, yelling at how damn cold the 11-degree pool was. \"Do I look like I'm enjoying this?\" he asked to anyone who would listen.\n\nThen he cramped up, and Sauve applied pressure to his quad, and all was okay for a minute, as Shapovalov sat in the inflated pool of cold water, his feet extended wide. Then his coach arrived to continue the match breakdown.\n\n\"You kept coming at him,\" Laurendeau said. \"You lost seven, eight points, but you kept hitting unbelievable shots and the last three you won - because you kept at it.\"\n\nShapovalov didn't seem to be paying attention. All was quiet for a while. And then he repeated three times: \"I don't know how I did it. I don't know what happened.\"\n\nThe poignant moment lasted a minute. Then his quad cramped again and Sauve went back to work on him, and when it calmed down, everyone but Denis started laughing. \"You love my pain!\" Shapovalov yelled at them.\n\nSports culture: deriving joy from the misery of those closest to you.\n\nOut of the ice bath and with his post-match recovery duties all but done, he went to say hello and goodbye to the friends and family he'd had in the crowd -- his friend Penny Oleksiak (see sidebar), and his mother, Tessa Shapovalov, among them.\n\nAs Oleksiak and others looked on, Levine also bombed southpaw serves at him, plenty of which went to the body to get Shapovalov used to the spin. At one point, a serve handcuffed the teenager and Levine yelled, \"That's Randy Johnson out there, baby,\" likely unaware a kid born in 1999 probably doesn't even know who the towering, former big league pitcher even is.\n\nBut the leftie prep paid off. And as he got a final wind-down massage that night, Shapovalov said the in-match moment he remembered most from the win over Nadal was his forehand approach shot on match point. \"I played it so loose, so clean,\" he said.\n\nSomeone talked about getting Shapovalov some real food to eat, and the sushi was pushed aside and a plate of noodles and chicken arrived. He began to stab away at it when his phone rang. His long-time junior coach, Adriano Fuorivia, was calling.\n\n\"We did it!\" Shapovalov yelled at Fuorivia on speakerphone. \"And I'm cramping and trying to eat some pasta!\"\n\nFuorivia told him how proud he was of him, and then mocked him about a moment or two in the match that had Shapovalov in hysterics.\n\n\"I'm not going to talk about your volleys,\" joked Fuorivia.\n\nLaurendeau retreated to the back of the room, away from the noise. The enormity of the moment was sinking in for the 53-year-old Canadian tennis lifer. This was Nadal, dammit, on Centre Court, at home, of the Rogers Cup. No player this young has ever reached a quarterfinal of a Masters 1000. Laurendeau is a former tour pro, now coaching and captaining the country's Davis Cup team. He was there when Daniel Nestor upset then-World No. 1 Stefan Edberg in 1992; he wore the maple leaf at the Olympics; he's a walking encyclopedia of Canadian tennis history.\n\n\"It's one of the greatest moments in Canadian sports,\" he said. \"There's been some great nights of tennis here, and this one was really unbelievable. To beat a legend like this.... It was just a magical night of tennis.\"\n\nShapovalov continued to eat pasta, but did so standing up, hoping his body wouldn't tighten up on him again. He guzzled water. His media session was a few minutes away now. He jammed more food down and a grin broke across his face.\n\n\"If I'm cramping, can I take the elevator?\" he asked.\n\nThere's a rule at Tennis Canada's high-performance complex: juniors, until the age of 19, must take the stairs. It's a seniority thing. And no, not even beating Nadal would allow him to skirt the laws of the land at the national tennis centre. Shapovalov can ride the elevator next year. For the next nine months, including Thursday night, the stairs it is.\n\nNow he's in the quarterfinal Friday against Adrian Mannarino, a winnable match that could propel him to No. 66 in the world. With No. 99 watching, Shapovalov could end up with Mario's number next to his name. Go figure.\n\nIf he gets past Mannarino, he's one win away from Sunday's final. Roger Federer is the top seed remaining and on the opposite side of the draw. Imagine that meeting. And just when you want to write off Shapovalov's chances of winning it all - even at the mere thought - you remember the Nadal match. The clutch shots he made and the lack of nerves he showed in big moments.\n\nSo, what did just happen Thursday night and what does it mean? Well, from here on in, that's anybody's guess.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:20:00Z", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "source": {"uri": "sportsnet.ca", "title": "Sportsnet", "id": "1184"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:20:00", "url": "http://www.sportsnet.ca/tennis/inside-post-match-celebration-denis-shapovalov/", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8646993", "image": "http://assets1.sportsnet.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Denis-Shapovalov-Rogers-Cup.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:20:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Cabinet apprised of MOU between India and Spain on India-Spain cooperation in renewable energy\n\nSecond-seeded Swiss Roger Federer coasted into the semi-finals of the Rogers Cup in Montreal with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over Spain's Roberto Bautista-Agut here.\n\nAlthough the 12th-seeded Spaniard managed to make the score of both sets respectable, Federer was much sharper than in his Thursday round-of-16 match against Spain's David Ferrer and never appeared threatened throughout the one-hour, eight-minute contest on Friday, reports Efe.\n\nThe 36-year-old, whose titles at the Australian Open and Wimbledon -- the 18th and 19th of his legendary career -- have made him the story of the 2017 tennis season, squandered a service-break lead early in the second set when he was broken for the lone time in the match.\n\nBut he broke Bautista-Agut's serve in the ensuing game and never looked back.\n\n\"I struggled against Ferrer early on, so today was better. youngest Masters 1000 quarter-finalist ever while he also boasts the distinction of being the second youngest player to defeat Nadal after Borna Coric.\n\nThe world number 143 already beat Rogerio Dutra Silva and former US Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro and will now face France's Adrian Mannarino in the quarter-final on Friday (11 August).\n\nAs for Nadal, the performance was a big blow, not only as he failed to break Shapovalov six times in the third set but also missed the chance to regain his world number one ranking.\n\nIf the Spaniard had reached the semi-final stage in Montreal, he would have been guaranteed to return to the summit of tennis following world number one Andy Murray's withdrawal from the event due to injury. would have regained for the first time since 2014 had he advanced to the semi-finals.\n\nShapovalov showed no sign of nerves in their first ever meeting, the left-hander playing the more aggressive tennis by utilising his huge forehand on roundhouse swings and frequently attacking the net.\n\nThe teenager's quixotic bid looked doomed in the third set tiebreaker when he fell 3-0 behind but the world number 143 refused to buckle and only coughed up one more point in the decider.\n\nFederer was sloppy from the outset on centre court, sending routine forehands wide and providing the underdog Ferrer with early break opportunities in the Montreal encounter.\n\nFerrer capitalised by winning the opener to end Federer's streak of 32 consecutive sets won, a record that dates back to his defeat to Tommy Haas at the Stuttgart Open on June 14.\n\n\"He had a good start, I had a better finish,\" Federer told reporters after the match.\n\nFrustration boiled over for the Australian Open and Wimbledon champion in the second set after he misfired with an overhead smash.\n\nFederer, who turned 36 this week, responded by hitting a ball into the stands, earning a reprimand but no official ball abuse call from the umpire.\n\nThe outburst appeared to steady the Swiss, whose serve and overall accuracy improved as the two-hour match progressed.\n\nFerrer has now lost all of his 17 contests enjoyed your trial.\n\nAdd a payment method\n\nTo read the remaining 325 words of this article.\n\nPay only 27\u00a2 for others you wish to read.\n\nCanadian teen tennis sensation Denis Shapovalov had the biggest win of his young career on Thursday night when he upset top-seeded Spaniard Rafael Nadal in the round of 16 at the Rogers Cup.\n\nWhile the 18-year-old Richmond Hill, Ont., native's profile -- not to mention his world ranking of 143 -- is sure to climb thanks to his success in Montreal, he's still a relatively new face on the ATP Tour.\n\nHere are five things to help Canadian tennis fans get to know the budding star:\n\nHE'S MADE HISTORY ... A FEW TIMES: The win over Nadal put Shapovalov into the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup, making him the youngest player to advance to the tournament's final eight since Bjorn Borg in 1974. He's also the youngest quarter-finalist ever at an ATP Masters event, the highest level on the pro tour. In 2016, he became just the second Canadian to win the Wimbledon boys singles title. Filip Peliwo in 2012 was the first.\n\n---\n\nHE'S A LEFTY: Like tennis greats John McEnroe, Martina Navratilova, Jimmy Connors and Nadal, Shapovalov is left-handed. But being a southpaw may not give him the same advantage it gave some of his predecessors. Technical advances in rackets and court surfaces as well as a changes in game strategy and the rise of the two-handed backhand have levelled the playing field in recent years.\n\n---\n\nHE'S BEEN COMPARED TO ROGER FEDERER: Tennis analyst Craig O'Shannessy once described the young Canadian as \"a left-handed version of Federer, with that one-handed backhand,\" according to the Telegraph in Britain. O'Shannessy also said there is \"no ceiling\" for Shapovalov, and praised his \"great energy and rapport with the crowd.\" He's certainly made an impression this week in Montreal, with Wayne Gretzky and star swimmer Penny Oleksiak among his boosters in the stands.\n\n---\n\nHE RECENTLY CHANGED COACHES: Before the start of the season, his first full campaign as a pro, Shapovalov split with his coach Adriano Fuorivia, who he had worked with for more than four years. Canadian Davis Cup captain Martin Laurendeau was hired as his replacement. Shapovalov said earlier this year that he and Fuorivia are on good terms despite parting ways. \"Adriano thought that someone with more experience like Marty would be a good benefit to my team,\" he said. \"It was nothing that happened between us, it was just more of a decision that we made together.\"\n\n---\n\nHE'S STILL A KID: Shapovalov showed a flash of immaturity when a ball he carelessly hit in frustration during a Davis Cup match in February struck a chair umpire in the eye. He dealt with the fallout like a man however, making no excuses for the incident, saying he lost control of his emotions and behaved unprofessionally. While he apologized to the umpire, his teammates and tennis fans, the International Tennis Federation didn't let him off the hook. He was fined US$7,000.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T16:06:00Z", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "source": {"uri": "brandonsun.com", "title": "Brandon Sun", "id": "2087"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:06:00", "url": "https://www.brandonsun.com/sports/breaking-news/on-the-rise-get-to-know-budding-tennis-rising-star-denis-shapovalov-439867273.html", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8655898", "image": "https://media.brandonsun.com/images/644*432/pch162419904.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "16:06:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov", "score": 4, "id": "1322539", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Canadian teen tennis sensation Denis Shapovalov had the biggest win of his young career on Thursday night when he upset top-seeded Spaniard Rafael Nadal in the round of 16 at the Rogers Cup.\n\nWhile the 18-year-old Richmond Hill, Ont., native's profile -- not to mention his world ranking of 143 -- is sure to climb thanks to his success in Montreal, he's still a relatively new face on the ATP Tour.\n\nHere are five things to help Canadian tennis fans get to know the budding star:\n\nHE'S MADE HISTORY ... A FEW TIMES: The win over Nadal put Shapovalov into the quarter-finals of the Rogers Cup, making him the youngest player to advance to the tournament's final eight since Bjorn Borg in 1974. He's also the youngest quarter-finalist ever at an ATP Masters event, the highest level on the pro tour. In 2016, he became just the second Canadian to win the Wimbledon boys singles title. Filip Peliwo in 2012 was the first.\n\n---\n\nHE'S A LEFTY: Like tennis greats John McEnroe, Martina Navratilova, Jimmy Connors and Nadal, Shapovalov is left-handed. But being a southpaw may not give him the same advantage it gave some of his predecessors. Technical advances in rackets and court surfaces as well as a changes in game strategy and the rise of the two-handed backhand have levelled the playing field in recent years.\n\n---\n\nHE'S BEEN COMPARED TO ROGER FEDERER: Tennis analyst Craig O'Shannessy once described the young Canadian as \"a left-handed version of Federer, with that one-handed backhand,\" according to the Telegraph in Britain. O'Shannessy also said there is \"no ceiling\" for Shapovalov, and praised his \"great energy and rapport with the crowd.\" He's certainly made an impression this week in Montreal, with Wayne Gretzky and star swimmer Penny Oleksiak among his boosters in the stands.\n\n---\n\nHE RECENTLY CHANGED COACHES: Before the start of the season, his first full campaign as a pro, Shapovalov split with his coach Adriano Fuorivia, who he had worked with for more than four years. Canadian Davis Cup captain Martin Laurendeau was hired as his replacement. Shapovalov said earlier this year that he and Fuorivia are on good terms despite parting ways. \"Adriano thought that someone with more experience like Marty would be a good benefit to my team,\" he said. \"It was nothing that happened between us, it was just more of a decision that we made together.\"\n\n---\n\nHE'S STILL A KID: Shapovalov showed a flash of immaturity when a ball he carelessly hit in frustration during a Davis Cup match in February struck a chair umpire in the eye. He dealt with the fallout like a man however, making no excuses for the incident, saying he lost control of his emotions and behaved unprofessionally. While he apologized to the umpire, his teammates and tennis fans, the International Tennis Federation didn't let him off the hook. He was fined US$7,000.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:46:00Z", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "source": {"uri": "metronews.ca", "title": "Metro Toronto", "id": "391"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:46:00", "url": "http://www.metronews.ca/news/canada/2017/08/11/on-the-rise-get-to-know-budding-tennis-rising-star-denis-shapovalov.html", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8652009", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

first title in Montreal and improve his 2017 hard-court record to 21-1.\n\nThe final score of a thrilling second-round clash that lasted one hour and 57 minutes read 4-6, 6-4, 6-2, in favour of Federer.\n\nWith the win, Federer has also extended his impressive ATP Head-to-Head advantage over Ferrer to 17-0.\n\nFederer will now cross swords with Roberto Bautista Agut of Spain for a place in last-four.\n\nIn another men's singles clash, fifteen-time grand slam champion Rafael Nadal's bid to regain top spot suffered a major blow as he knocked out of the tournament after going down against bid for No. 1 ranking on Monday ended at the hands of young Canadian Denis Shapovalov. The 18-year-old stunned the 3-time tournament champion 3-6, 6-4, 7-6(4) in the third round of the Canadian Open.\n\nAfter squeezing out the second set, Shapovalov had to save six break points against him from Nadal. Then had to overcome a 3-0 deficit in the third set tiebreaker and he did it in magical style winning seven of the last eight points to the roar and delight of his home crowd.\n\n\"It's so tough. A lot of the times he just hits a shot that's way too good. I was managing to get a lot back when I could. But, you know, he's honestly the best player I've ever played in my life,\" Shapovalov said.\n\n\"You could tell why he's won so many Grand Slams. His ball was just so heavy. He's such a warrior out there. So it's honestly, like a dream come true for me to beat a player like that.\n\n\"I don't know if a lot of players fold or if he just outplays them at the end,\" he added. \"I was down 3-0 in the tie-break. I did a good job to regroup. I knew I had to win both the points off my serve. Yeah, then he gave me a double [fault] to tie it up.\n\n\"I just tried to stay calm, tried to play every point, go for my shots. At the end of the day I really tried to keep playing my game and stick to my tactics.\"\n\nNadal, who needed only to beat the 143rd-ranked Shapovalov and then Adrian Mannarino to return to No. 1 on Monday, will have to win until after Cincinnati to get back to the top.\n\n\"It probably is the worst lose of the year, without a doubt, for me,\" Nadal said. \"He played well. I played really bad. When this kind of thing happens, the only thing you can do is wish the opponent the best.\n\n\"It is probably my worst loss of the year because I lost against a player with a lower ranking. At the same time, because of the opportunity I had here to come back to No. 1. Always tough, but the draw was not that impossible after all the matches that were happening. So it was an important mistake from me.\"\n\nAt 18 years, 3 months, Shapovalov is the youngest quarterfinalist in ATP Masters 1y (since 1990) and he's the youngest quarterfinalist at the Canadian Open since Bjorn Borg (18 years, 2 months) in 1974.\n\nFrom the youngest to the oldest, Roger Federer register his 17th straight win over David Ferrer, but had to work to do. Federer didn't play his best and struggled with his serve for much of the day, but prevailed in the end 4-6, 6-4, 6-2.\n\n\"From the baseline, I didn't have enough rhythm. The court is fast here. Of course, because of the surface, that it's fast, you can't just decide to put the ball in because physically David is very strong. You can't do that. You have to go into the battle. You have to accept you're going to make mistakes. But you have to keep moving forward.\n\n\"I tried with my intensity and focus to change the match, and this is what I was able to do. I was able also to change the angles, and that helped me win the match.\"\n\nNext for Federer is another Spaniard he has dominated in Roberto Bautista Agut. Agut outlasted Gael Monfils in a third set tiebreaker 4-6, 7-6(5), 7-6(2). The Swiss has won all six meetings with Agut, never having dropped a set.\n\n\"We battled, both tried to find a way to win. He had a good start, I had a better finish,\" Federer said. \"That was important. For me, take it how it is and hope that this match gives me some better rhythm and confidence against Bautista Agut, who plays actually very similar to David today.\"\n\nAlexander Zverev stayed hot rolling past Nick Kyrgios 6-4, 6-3. But I'm playing Anderson tomorrow,\" said Zverev who has won his last seven matches. \"He's played a lot of matches. He's playing very, very well.
