Just a month ago he had clinched his record eight Wimbledon title at SW19 and now he his up for yet another, not a Grand Slam final though. Breezing past Dutchman Robin Haase 6-3 7-6(5) in the semi-final round of the Rogers Cup 2017, Roger Federer has eased into yet another ATP Tour final on Sunday.\n\nIt was almost a fortnight after his 19th Grand Slam victory at the All England Club, Roger Federer had announced his entry into the Canadian hardcourt tournament. He had last played the event back in 2011 where he had lost to Frenchman Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the third round. After almost six years of gap, the Swiss maestro returned to tennis action at Montreal.\n\nIt wasn't much of a hassle for the recently turned 36-year-old at Rogers Cup 2017. It had all been straight set victories till his road to the semis. Up next was Netherlands tennis player Hasse, who was playing his first ATP World Tour Masters 1000 semi-final. Federer served nine cutting edge aces and lost just nine points on his serve as he stormed into his sixth final of the year.\n\n\"I'm happy I'm playing as well as I am this year on the match courts. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year, he said.\n\nWith a yet another comfortable victory in the tournament, Roger Federer extended his winning streak to 16 matches, a record he had scripted back in 2012. The Swiss tennis ace will now be aiming for his third Rogers Cup title, having last won the trophy in 2004 and then in 2006. However, this will be his first trophy in Montreal, the other two were clinched in Toronto, owing to the format of the game.\n\nIn the final, he is up against fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev, who stopped Dennis Shapovalov's dream run in the campaign, early on Sunday. This will be Federer's 141st tennis final and he would be chasing his 94th ATP World Tour title, clinching which he could find his name alongside Ivan Lendl for second-most titles in Open Era. Jimmy Connors still leads the race with 109.\n\nNow the most important...will the win on Monday make him closer to the World No. 1 spot on the ATP rankings? Yes, it is.\n\nUp untill now, the discussion was about Rafael Nadal. With the announcement of Andy Murray's withdrawal from Rogers Cup 2017, it kept a clear road to numero uno spot on the rankings chart for Rafael Nadal. With just few hundred points behind the Brit, the 31-year-old had the opportunity to reclaim the No. 1 spot for the first time since June 2014, with the condition of a semi-final showing. But unfortunate for the Spaniard, he was shown the exit door by Shapovalov in the very third round of his tournament, putting his bid to World No. 1 spot on hold.\n\nSpeculations were also that Federer was in the race for the numero uno spot and now with Nadal's shock exit, the road seems clear for him. If he is able to win the Rogers Cup tomorrow, then he is bound to become the World No.1 yet again, on August 21 with an equal or a better finish than Nadal at the Cincinnati masters.\n\nWell, Federer does hold a 2-1 advantage over Zverev which includes his recent victory at Wimbledon. absent Andy Murray at the top of the rankings, a position the Spaniard would have regained for the first time since 2014 had he advanced to the semi-finals.\n\nShapovalov showed no sign of nerves in their first ever meeting, the left-hander playing the more aggressive tennis by utilising his huge forehand on roundhouse swings and frequently attacking the net.\n\nThe teenager's quixotic bid looked doomed in the third set tiebreaker when he fell 3-0 behind but the world number 143 refused to buckle and only coughed up one more point in the decider.\n\nAs a reward for his unlikely victory, the THE CANADIAN PRESS/Paul Chiasson\n\nRoger Federer advanced to the Rogers Cup final with a 6-3, 7-6 (5) victory over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands on Saturday afternoon.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title to go with wins in 2004 and 2006. A victory would give Federer, currently ranked third in the world, one of the top two seeds at the U.S. Open that begins Aug. 28 in New York.\n\nThe 36-year-old, coming off victories in Germany and at Wimbledon, is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012.\n\nIn Sunday's final, the Swiss veteran will face the winner of the second semifinal between 18-year-old Denis Shapovalov of Richmond Hill, Ont., and 20-year-old Alexander Zverev of Germany.\n\nHaase, who upset seventh-seeded Grigor Dimitrov in the third round, was in his first career semifinal of a Masters Series tournament. Africa.\n\nShapovalov beat 2009 U.S. Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro in the second round and then knocked off the top-seeded Nadal in a third-set tiebreaker on Thursday in the round of 16.\n\nDenis Shapovalov, of Canada celebrates, after defeating Adrian Mannarino, of France, during the quarterfinals at the Rogers Cup tennis tournament Friday, Aug. 11, 2017, in Montreal. No. 10 Agnieszka Radwanska; 6-3, 6-1\n\nDenis Shapovalov Pulls Massive Upset over Rafael Nadal\n\nRafael Nadal had his eyes on becoming the new No. 1 player in the world, but instead, it was a magical night for 18-year-old Denis Shapovalov.\n\nAfter dropping the first set, Shapovalov showed no fear in the second, bringing fans to their feet as they cheered on the Canadian youngster. This exchange was arguably the best of the day:\n\nSupplementing these finishes with five aces (after zero in the first set), he was able to win the second set 6-4.\n\nHis grit was apparent once again in the third set with one game especially lasting a long time, via Ben Rothenberg of the New York Times:\n\nThe decisive set eventually went to a tiebreak, and while Nadal took a 3-0 lead, Shapovalov closed out the victory.\n\nHe entered the week ranked No. 143 in the world, but the biggest win of his career will ensure he doesn't get overlooked ever again.\n\nThe theme of the day in the men's draw was come-from-behind wins. Roberto Bautista Agut and Diego Schwartzman both overcame first-set losses to win, with Schwartzman even losing 0-6 in the opening frame.\n\nRoger Federer continued the trend, following up a 4-6 loss in the first set with a 6-4, 6-2 finish. Jose Morgado of Record Portugal reacted to the performance:\n\nFederer was sloppy throughout the first set, struggling to get his first serve in play and handing his opponent plenty of points through unforced errors. He cleaned things up in the last two sets, totaling eight aces with just one double fault in that stretch.\n\nHe was broken just once in nine service games after the first set.\n\nFerrer played well at times, but few men in the world can beat Federer once his serve is going.\n\nIf you were going to predict this match to end in less than one hour, you would probably expect the No. 3 seed to get the win over the opponent ranked No. 934 in the world. That was not the case Thursday.\n\nUnseeded Sloane Stephens dominated the third-seeded Angelique Kerber with a two-set win, dropping just four games in a dominant third-round showing.\n\nStephens has had to overcome injuries in recent years and didn't have a single win in 2017 coming into the Rogers Cup. However, she now has three in a row, including a victory over No. 14 seed Petra Kvitova.\n\nWTA Insider noted how long it has been since the American had this big of a win:\n\n\"Everything is good,\" Stephens said after the match, per Matt Cronin of TennisReporters.net. \"Body is good. Nothing is hurting. So I'm on the right track.\"\n\nAs long as she remains healthy, she can be a threat for the rest of the tournament and the rest of the year.\n\nThere were two matchups between top-10 seeds in the women's draw Thursday and neither ended up being particularly close.\n\nThe biggest disappointment of the day was No. 9 Venus Williams, who provided almost no resistance against No. 5 Elina Svitolina.\n\nSvitolina was outstanding defensively, winning 55 percent of return points on Williams' first serves. She was even more dominant against the second serve with a 70 percent success rate.\n\nThis second-set point showed her ability to pick up almost everything:\n\nWilliams is coming off a finals appearance at Wimbledon, but she didn't perform anywhere near this level in the third-round battle.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T02:14:00Z", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "source": {"uri": "bleacherreport.com", "title": "Bleacher Report", "id": "3199"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:19:00", "url": "http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2726832-rogers-cup-2017-rafael-nadal-venus-williams-angelique-kerber-eliminated", "storyUri": "eng-3347316", "id": "8548766", "image": "https://img.bleacherreport.net/img/images/photos/003/688/551/hi-res-c485f1936e26d78a31254ee820b97514_crop_exact.jpg?w=1200&h=1200&q=75", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "02:14:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Shapovalov delighted his home fans when he battled from a set down to record a stunning upset victory over top seed Rafael Nadal in the third round of the Rogers Cup on Thursday.\n\nThe lanky wild card kissed the Montreal court after completing a rousing 3-6 6-4 7-6(4) triumph as the 18-year-old became the youngest player to ever reach the quarter-finals of an ATP Masters 1000 event.\n\nThe early exit also denied world number two Nadal a chance to take over from the absent Andy Murray at the top of the rankings, a position the Spaniard would have regained for the first time since 2014 had he advanced to the semi-finals.\n\nShapovalov showed no sign of nerves in their first ever meeting, the left-hander playing the more aggressive tennis by utilising his huge forehand on roundhouse swings and frequently attacking the net.\n\nThe teenager's quixotic bid looked doomed in the third set tiebreaker when he fell 3-0 behind but the world number 143 refused to buckle and only coughed up one more point in the decider.\n\nAs a reward for his unlikely victory, the 2016 Wimbledon junior champion will next face 29-year-old Frenchman Adrian Mannarino in the quarter-finals on Friday.\n\nAdrian Mannarino (France) beat Chung Hyeon (South Korea) 6-3 6-3\n\n4-Alexander Zverev (Germany) beat 16-Nick Kyrgios (Australia) 6-4 6-3\n\n2-Roger Federer (Switzerland) beat David Ferrer top-seeded Rafael Nadal 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7-4) in the third round.\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov from Richmond Hill, Ontario, advanced to a quarter-final with France's Adrian Mannarino, who defeated Hyeon Chung of South Korea 6-3, 6-3.\n\n\"It's what I dreamed of all my life growing up, playing guys like Rafa, Roger [Federer], Andy [Murray],\" Shapovalov said. \"You know, my dream came true today.\"\n\nShapovalov has taken major strides this week to reach his goal of cracking the world's top 100 with wins over Rogerio Dutra Silva and 2009 US Open champion Juan Martin Del Potro.\n\nHe also halted Nadal's bid to regain the No. 1 ranking, which the Spaniard could have achieved by reaching the semi-finals.\n\nShapovalov battled back after Nadal cruised through the first set, then erased a 3-0 deficit in the tiebreaker for the biggest victory of his career.\n\nShapovalov became the youngest player to reach the tournament's quarter-finals since Bjorn Borg in 1974.\n\nWith hockey great Wayne Gretzky and Olympic swimming star Penny Oleksiak cheering for him from the seats, he also became the youngest quarter-finalist at a Masters Series tournament ever and is the youngest to beat a player ranked in the top two in the world since Nadal beat Federer in 2004 in Miami.\n\n\"He has a great potential. I wish him the best. He has everything to become a great player. At the end that's what matters because I spent hours and hours on the practice courts in the last year.\"\n\nNext up for the Swiss right-hander, who is seeking his third Rogers Cup title after triumphs in Toronto in 2004 and 2006, is Zverev after the fourth seed advanced with a 6-4 7-5 win over Canada's Denis Shapovalov.\n\nFederer owns a 2-1 edge against Zverev in head-to-head meetings, most recently a 6-1 6-3 win at Halle in June.\n\nZverev ended Shapovalov's magical week on his third match point when the 18-year-old, who had been the story of the tournament after a stunning run that included an upset win over world number two Rafael Nadal, sent a backhand wide.\n\nShapovalov, who was born in Israel and moved to Canada before his first birthday, had a great chance at 4-3 in the second set but failed to convert on his three break points.\n\n\"I wasn't too sharp on the big points,\" said Shapovalov, who made headlines in February for inadvertently blasting a ball into an umpire's face in a fit of rage during a Davis Cup quarter-final.\n\n\"I had a couple looks at some second serves and I missed some returns. definir\u00e1n hoy el certamen, que se disputar\u00e1 desde las 17; televisa ESPN\n\nAlexander Zverev------Roger Federer------\n\nMONTREAL (AP).- No importa lo que suceda de ac\u00e1 a fin de a\u00f1o, Roger Federer puede asegurar, a los 36 a\u00f1os, que ha tenido una de las temporadas m\u00e1s gratificantes de su carrera. No s\u00f3lo porque volvi\u00f3 a conquistar dos Grand Slam, sino adem\u00e1s porque ha podido compartir el circuito junto a sus cuatro hijos. Ahora, los herederos podr\u00e1n volver a ver festejar a su padre. Es que esta tarde, desde las 17, el suizo jugar\u00e1 ante el alem\u00e1n Alexander Zverev la final del Masters 1000 de esta ciudad\n\nEl suizo accedi\u00f3 a la final del torneo que se alterna cada a\u00f1o entre Montreal y Toronto, al imponerse el s\u00e1bado por 6-3 y 7-6 (5) sobre el holand\u00e9s Robin Haase. As\u00ed, se instal\u00f3 en su sexta definici\u00f3n del a\u00f1o, en el que jug\u00f3 pocos torneos y siempre brill\u00f3.\n\n\"Fue una buena decisi\u00f3n. Si hubiera sabido que llegar\u00eda a la final, habr\u00eda dicho que s\u00ed de inmediato\" Roger Federer\n\nFederer (2do preclasificado) se coron\u00f3 en este certamen en 2004 y 2006, pero nunca lo ha ganado en Montreal. A sus 36 a\u00f1os, ostenta una racha de 16 triunfos consecutivos, la m\u00e1s larga que ha montado desde 2012.\n\nLleg\u00f3 a considerar la posibilidad de ausentarse de este certamen, lo que habr\u00eda sido desastroso para los organizadores, luego que el brit\u00e1nico Andy Murray, primero del escalaf\u00f3n, qued\u00f3 fuera por una lesi\u00f3n, lo mismo que el serbio Novak Djokovic y el suizo Stan Wawrinka.\n\nA fin de cuentas, Federer decidi\u00f3 jugar. Ahora, tiene la oportunidad de conseguir un trofeo m\u00e1s en una temporada que incluye t\u00edtulos del Abierto de Australia y de Wimbledon.\n\n\"Estoy muy contento por estar jugando aqu\u00ed\", coment\u00f3. \"Fue una buena decisi\u00f3n. Si hubiera sabido que llegar\u00eda a la final, habr\u00eda dicho que s\u00ed de inmediato. A veces hay que esperar y ver c\u00f3mo te sientes. Lo que m\u00e1s me alegra es estar saludable de verdad para llegar a esta final. No he gastado demasiada energ\u00eda. He sido capaz de disputar puntos breves y he estado muy bien en la red\".\n\nFederer, tercero del ranking mundial, se medir\u00e1 al alem\u00e1n Alexander Zverev, quien dobleg\u00f3 por la noche a la sensaci\u00f3n local Denis Shapovalov, en un duelo de promisorios tenistas, que con el paso de los a\u00f1os podr\u00eda volverse m\u00e1s frecuente.\n\nZverev, de 20 a\u00f1os, se impuso por 6-4, 7-5 a Shapovalov, de apenas 18, ante la desaz\u00f3n del p\u00fablico local. Sin embargo, Shapovalov se mostr\u00f3 contento tras una gran actuaci\u00f3n en el torneo, donde elimin\u00f3 a Juan Mart\u00edn del Potro y al espa\u00f1ol Rafael Nadal, primera cabeza de serie.\n\n\"En la primera ronda, me salv\u00e9 de cuatro match points (ante el brasile\u00f1o Rogerio Dutra), y luego de eso me relaj\u00e9\", coment\u00f3 el canadiense. \"Dej\u00e9 que las cosas fluyeran y venc\u00ed a uno de mis \u00eddolos\".\n\nEn esta nota:Roger FedererAlexander ZverevTenisLA NACIONDeportesEl circuito ATP", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "dateEnd": "-06-07", "date": "-03-06", "textEnd": 767, "textStart": 758}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3353129", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T14:26:00Z", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "source": {"uri": "lanacion.com.ar", "title": "La Nacion", "id": "1012"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:26:00", "url": "http://www.lanacion.com.ar/2052714-roger-federer-alexander-zverev-masters-1000-de-montreal", "storyUri": "spa-1072399", "id": "8926782", "image": "http://bucket.glanacion.com/anexos/fotos/14/2511814.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "14:26:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}], "page": 1, "totalResults": 444, "count": 1}}}

The men's Rogers Cup set a record for attendance at a one-week tournament of 216,097 spectators.\n\nTournament director Eugene Lapierre said Sunday it topped the 213,760 who attended in 2011.\n\nThe presence of Wimbledon champion Roger Federer and a run to the semifinals by Canadian teenager Denis Shapovalov certainly helped pack fans into Uniprix Stadium.\n\n\"There was a tennis craze in our city in the last few weeks and it shows in our attendance numbers,\" Lapierre said in a release. \"There were compelling storylines throughout the tournament and the Montreal crowd once again demonstrated their love of tennis.\n\n\"It has been a while since we experienced such excitement for our sport.\"\n\nThe 18-year-old Shapovalov beat World No. 2 Rafael Nadal in the third round earlier in the week and lost to fourth seed and World No. 8 Alexander Zverev in the semifinals on Saturday night.", "timeCrawl": "18:00:00", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "extractedDates": null, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Canada"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Montreal"}}, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "id": "8950187", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "id": 256, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis", "id": 568, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/College_and_University", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/College and University", "id": 960, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Outdoors/Fishing", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Outdoors/Fishing", "id": 991, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Tennis", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Tennis", "id": 1075, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}], "page": 1, "pages": 456, "totalResults": 456}}}
